answer: A long time ago when I was in third grade, I had a friend @PERSON2 whose mom was perpetually in a bad mood. She never laughed, and she never smiled, her face a permanent mask of sternness. Every time I saw her, I would offer a cheerful smile, but all she would do was frown deeply and keep walking without a word. At first, I didn't know she was a grouch; I just thought she didn't like me or something, which made me a little sad. When @PERSON2 finally told me his mom was just a grouch, I started to laugh and laugh with relief. He asked me what was so funny, and I told him that I had thought his mom didn't like me because every time I saw her, I would smile and she would just frown and walk away. That made my friend laugh, and we were cracking up so hard in class that we got in trouble with the teacher. The next day, @PERSON2 and I were eating lunch at school when he turned to me and said, "Hey, you're pretty good at making people laugh." I modestly said, "No, I am not; my jokes are horrible." He insisted, "<@CAPS1 let's put them to the test. Go up to someone new to this school." I agreed, saying "@CAPS1," so we went around the whole school looking for a new student. Unfortunately, we couldn't find one, and we heard the bell ring, forcing us to run to our class. We sat in the back of the classroom, just @PERSON2 and I with an empty seat between us. We were excited because our teacher, @PERSON1, was going to show us a movie. @PERSON1 stood at the front of the room and announced, "Class today I have an announcement; we have a new student in our class. Say hello to @LOCATION1." @ORGANIZATION1 then walked through the door. @PERSON1 told @ORGANIZATION1 she could sit in the back between @PERSON2 and me. She sat down, turned to both of us, and said a quiet hello. @PERSON2 gave me a look that said, "Tell her the joke," and I gave him a thumbs up. I turned to @LOCATION1 and said, "Hi, I'm @CAPS4. Do you want to hear a joke?" @ORGANIZATION1 said, "Yeah, sure." I started, "<@CAPS5 knock." She said, "Who's there?" I said, "Boo." She said, "Boo who?" I said, "Oh, don't cry, I am right here." At first, she didn't laugh because she didn't get it, but during the middle of the movie, she suddenly said, "Ohhhh, I get it," and she started to laugh quietly. @PERSON2 turned to me and said, "I told you so." Later, @PERSON2 got this crazy idea that if I spent the night at his house, I could make his mom laugh or at least make her smile. I said, "<@CAPS1 sounds like a plan." I asked my mom if it was @CAPS1 if I could spend the night at @PERSON2's house, and she said, "Yeah, just make sure it's @CAPS1 with his mom." @PERSON2 asked his mom, and she said it was @CAPS1. When I got to @PERSON2's house, the first thing we did was play video games for a while. When it was dinner time, we all sat down at the table to eat, with @PERSON2 and I on one side and his parents on the other. As we started eating, @PERSON2 told me to tell the joke to his parents, and I said "@CAPS1." So I said to them, "<@CAPS5 @CAPS5." They replied, "Who's there?" I said, "Boo." They said, "Boo who?" I said, "Oh, don't cry, I am right here." His parents started to laugh and laugh, and they kept laughing for what felt like five minutes. @PERSON2 turned to me and yelled, "It worked!" His mom asked what worked, and @PERSON2 explained everything to them. His mom then told us that her mom had recently died and that's why she had been in such a bad mood. After dinner, we went to bed and fell asleep. The next morning, when my mom came to pick me up, she asked me how the sleepover went. I said it was fun and that I made people laugh. She said, "@CAPS1, but laughter isn't going to help you clean your room." All I could say was, "Gosh darn it."

Softball has to be one of the single most greatest sports alive; playing softball in college has always been a primary goal of mine. I love the feeling of the dirt that sticks to your face after a slide, the sweat dripping from your forehead during a hot game, and the gallons and gallons of water you pour all over yourself to keep cool in the blistering @CAPS2 sun. Although I love the sport itself, I feel that the memories you acquire from the times you have with your teammates are the things you remember the most throughout your entire softball career. I have always had great memories through softball, filled with many laughs, tears, and frustrations, so when I had the opportunity to play on a top-notch team, I looked forward to all the many more memories I would create. Hood @CAPS1 @CAPS2 was my team name, and I had played almost four years with this local team. Many of these girls were like sisters to me; they had treated me amazingly throughout my years playing with them. I felt like I had found my set team, and I was going to play with these girls all through high school, and we would become even closer. As my fifth year now approached, I was looking forward to it, but when my dad came up with the idea that maybe I should play for a team not as local, that idea was also very enticing. I now faced a big dilemma: either stay with the team I knew so well and continue to play with them until high school ended, or play with a team I knew nothing about, with girls that might not like me, girls that were so much better than me, and who might look down upon me. As I looked at the pros and cons of both teams, I initially decided no; I would stay with the team that I knew so well and remain comfortable where I was at. At that point, softball season was just around the corner, and I began to reanalyze everything. Did I really want to stay and be comfortable? Or maybe I should challenge myself to become a better player; maybe I could work hard enough to have college scouts take a look at me and hopefully have me play for them later. I then decided I would take a chance and try out for this new team. As my dad and I drove to the field where I would try out for this team, my stomach was in knots. I wanted this team to like me, and I was playing all the possible ways I could greet them in my head so I didn't sound snobby or like a grump. The time moved quickly, and I wished it would slow down; my heart felt like it was beating a million times per second. I was so nervous my mouth began to feel sticky and have an odd taste to it, and soon after, my mouth became bone dry—no taste, no flavor, just a sticky mess. The car then became stationary, and my dad looked at me and just said, "Ready or not, here we come." Nervousness began to take over my body; my arms were shaking uncontrollably, and I was second-guessing every move I made. I even had troubles removing my seat belt. As I approached the field, it felt like time was in slow motion. Walking by, I saw all the girls turn their heads to see what new fresh meat had arrived. My first thought was to run; that was it, I didn't want to go, I was done, I wanted to go home, I was ready to start my year with the @CAPS2. I just couldn't take it. Then, as I walked onto the field, they all grew a smile. Each and every one of them told me their names, their favorite color, and a small fun fact about themselves. I found myself laughing throughout my whole tryout; there were no awkward moments, and I genuinely enjoyed my time there. I couldn't wait to go back. I now had made new friends, friends I knew I would grow close with. My year with this team was amazing; I have friendships with these girls that I never would have discovered if I hadn't gone. Those girls are like family, and the coaches even more so. Laughter played a very big role in the decision I made to play with this team. If I had just gone and tried out and had not had fun and laughed, I would have decided to play with the @CAPS2. I have had great memories with the @CAPS2, but softball is also all about going out, discovering new friendships, and therefore, enjoying the sport as well as the people you meet along the way.

Some people like making people laugh; I absolutely love it. I will do most anything to get a good, genuine laugh. I will make fun of myself, do insanely stupid things, and sometimes even hurt myself, though not in any serious way. When I was little, I didn't really understand the nuances of laughter. For some odd reason, I could never tell the difference if people were laughing at something I did or laughing with me. I was kind of "special" in some areas as a kid, and I still am today in many ways. Still, at the tender age of five, I loved making people laugh, and being special, I would do even crazier things just for a laugh. Mind you, I was also kind of a spaz, and a really big one at that. I was the most hyperactive five-year-old you will ever meet. For example, one time I hit myself in the head with a hammer. Another time, I was dancing around in class with a pencil in my hand, stabbed myself in the head with it, and needed stitches. One of the craziest times, though, was a couple of days before I had to take pictures for school, and I wanted to go play outside. My mom, knowing how "special" I was—a trait I undoubtedly got from her—wouldn't allow me to go. The expert persuasive kid I was back then somehow convinced her to let me go outside. Before I could even reach the street, I fell headfirst onto the corner of the sidewalk, leaving a huge mark and completely ruining the pictures. Although that might make some people laugh, this is a story about laughter, not just me being a spaz. Now that you know that I love making people laugh, that I'm "special," and that I'm a complete spaz, I can get on with the main story. Well, I was in kindergarten, and I loved school because I got to hang out with my friends and play with blocks. That might sound stupid, but I was in kindergarten, after all. The only thing I didn't like about kindergarten was bullies. Surprisingly, I have never had a bully except in kindergarten, but this was a bad bully. He would give me wedgies at story time—the whole deal—which was the best time to do so because the teacher couldn't see. I still know the bully too, but he's no bully anymore; he's a goody two-shoes now, which I find odd. Anyways, kindergarten was a very good year for me except for one day, and every day I got a wedgie. That day is what this whole story is about; it's why I told you I love making people laugh, why I told you I'm "special," and a spaz. Everything in the story circles around this one day, *dramatic pause*, in kindergarten. It started out like any other day in kindergarten. I woke up, did my daily routine, hopped in the car, and headed to school. When I got to school, I grabbed my daily binder and patted the education sign like a mall cop would pat the 'observe and report' sign. I did all my work, which was basically just coloring. It came around break, so we ran around the playground and got our little snack. When we finished getting the last few drops out of our juice boxes, we headed over to story time. We were all sitting in the little circle, which was more like a deformed oval, listening to the story. Right when I would get into the story and lose my guard, I would receive an excruciatingly painful—for a five-year-old—wedgie. The story was almost finished, and our five-year-old attention spans were wearing thin; we were all getting excited. The story finally finished, and we were standing up, and this is where my memory starts to fade a bit. I cracked a really funny joke, and the whole kindergarten class erupted into laughter. Me, being a "special" spaz that couldn't tell if people were laughing at me or with me, burst into tears. I remember balling my eyes out at the drinking fountain, trying to hide my tears. One of the teachers noticed and tried to help me by telling me that they were laughing at my joke, not at me. It took me a couple of minutes to stop crying, but a little longer to fully realize they were not laughing at me. To this day, I still get reminded by classmates about that day. Of course, I can laugh about it now, but that was in kindergarten; I'm in ninth grade now, and for people to remember that is kind of crazy to me. It was a negative experience then, but it turned into a blessing in disguise. It made me grow into a better person; I can now tell the difference in laughter and also be okay when people do laugh at me, since doing dumb things to make

I'm going to tell you a little story. I remember a time when my cousin @PERSON1 and I decided to make a snowman at his house in @LOCATION1, @LOCATION2. I say to him, "I'm bored, what do you want to do?" @PERSON1 replies, "Let's go make a snowman." I agree that that would be fun. He starts reaching for a jacket and gloves, but I stop him and say, "What are you getting those for?" "It's not cold outside." "Fine," replies @PERSON1. "Don't say I didn't warn you." We start our snowman by building the base, the biggest piece for the bottom. And after about fifteen minutes the base is almost done, but we notice that we're getting cold. "Maybe we should go inside?" @PERSON1 says. "Yeah, I bet mom will even make us some hot chocolate." So off we go back inside hoping for some delectably warm hot chocolate. I see his mom and ask, "Can we have some hot chocolate please?" "You two look cold, Of course I'll make you some." So @PERSON1 and I sit downstairs waiting anxiously for our hot chocolate by the heater to get warm. "It's ready!" his mom calls from upstairs. We fly down the hall and rush up the stairs. And to our amazement we find not only hot chocolate but a bag of chips as well. "Thanks mom!" I say. "You are the best!" says @PERSON1. "You're welcome boys," says his mom. @PERSON1 and I sit down at the table and start drinking our hot chocolate, while his mom puts some chips on paper towels for us. I start eating the chips by the handfuls whereas @PERSON1 grabs one, just one. I ask him, "Why did you only grab one @PERSON1?" Out of the corner of his eye he looks at me and slowly brings the chip to his mouth and takes a bite. As he did that I fell out of my chair in a fit of hysterical laughter. His mom hears the thump of me hitting the floor and runs upstairs to find me laughing. "What's so funny?" she asks. I say to @PERSON1, "Show her." @PERSON1 then complies and grabs another chip and while he looks at her from the corner of his eye, slowly brings it to his mouth and takes a bite. I start busting up laughing again, yet his mom doesn't see the humor. She simply asks, "Why is that so funny?" @PERSON1 replies, "I have no idea but he just about died from laughter. I start to stop laughing and I'm able to stand up again. I then tell his mom, "It's the way he looks at you, it just makes you laugh." I then try to do the same thing, but with no effect to @PERSON1. "Why isn't it working?" I ask. "Because I'm awesome like that and you're not," he says. "Fine, well I'm gonna keep at it until I get it right." So I try to mimic everything I saw him do, but to no avail. All I made happen was I spilled my hot chocolate all over myself, which made him laugh, albeit not the way I wanted to. "You want me to show you?" @PERSON1 says. "Yes!!!! Please!" I beg. "Fine, don't say I didn't warn you." He proceeds then to grab another chip and while looking at me from the corner of his eye, bites the chip. I start laughing uncontrollably then and without pause. After about fifteen minutes I stop laughing. "I'll get that right!" I say. @PERSON1 says, "Try it." I grab a chip and look straight at him and bite down, nothing. I try again, this time while looking at him from the corner of my eye, nothing yet again. I say to myself, "If I can't get it this time I'm giving up." "Okay, here goes." I grab a chip and slowly bring it to my mouth while squinting at him from the corner of my eye. I bite the chip. I notice he's laughing. He's laughing!!! "I told you I'd get it!" "Yes, yes you did." And this is one of the many times laughter brought my cousin @PERSON1 and I together.

My best friend, @PERSON1 and I have been close ever since we were eight. We met through weekly dance lessons at our local dance studio. We've stayed close throughout the years because we've always done similar activities. We're very different from each other though. I'm more out going, I like to speak my mind and I'm more carefree. She's the opposite. She's very conservative and she can take things too seriously. But either way, we manage to even each other out. Finals week had just gotten over, and @PERSON1 and I had been planning a sleepover all week. We just needed time to relax and have some time to ourselves. When I had gotten home from school, I gave her a quick call. "Hello?" she answered. "Hey, what time did you wanna hang out?" I asked. "I was thinking six?" "Sounds good!" I quickly hung up the phone and gathered up my gear. I grabbed my toothbrush, pillow, pajamas, and my blanket. I put my shoes on and headed back out the door. My dad dropped me off with all of me gear. I had brought my pajamas, my pillow, and an extra blanket. I walked up her sidewalk to her door, knocked, and waited. Only seconds later did she answer it with a big smile across her face. She lead me down to her basement where she had all the junk food set out ready for us to attack. She had gone to the store earlier that day and had bought everything. She had set it all up on her old pool table that nobody used. There were chips, cookies, sodas, candy, chocolate, and pizza. I set my stuff down on the chair in the corner of the room and we feasted. Of course, we couldn't eat all the food. We simply weren't big enough. After eating for almost an hour straight, we laid on her basement floor trying to gain composure. We started laughing at silly little things that came up on commercials on her big screen TV. Eventually, we got to talking about how each of our finals went. "I did soo good on all of mine! I'm gonna get ALL A's" @PERSON1 bragged. She has gotten straight A's every year since middle school. "I think I did pretty well too, not so sure about an A though." I said as I was laying upside down on the floor. "Well, we'll just see tomorrow!" We finally decided to move ourselves over to the couch on the opposite side of the pool table, so we could face the TV. It was already ten in the morning and we were still on a sugar high. We switched back and forth from watching some old scary movie, and the top twenty music videos of the week. That had passed some time and before we knew it, it was six in the morning. @PERSON1 and I were laying on opposite ends of each other. Occasionally, one of us would get some chips or candy from the table. We grew tired to the point where we couldn't keep our eyes open. No one even had enough energy to turn off the overhead light. We fell asleep fast. When I woke-up the next morning, @PERSON1 wasn't laying across from me anymore. She was sitting in the corner chair where I had set my stuff. I looked at the clock, and it was already 10:30 in the afternoon. I looked back and @PERSON1, she seemed somewhat upset. I shifted around under my blanket so I could face her. "Hey..." I grunted, while I was stretching. "Morning." she said abruptly. She was holding a folded piece of paper in her hand. "What's up?" I asked, sitting up on the couch. She crumpled up the piece of paper and threw it at me. I picked it up from my lap and unfolded it. It was her report card. I scanned down the paper looking at all of her grades. She had received all A's... and one B. She had gotten a B in her math class. I looked up from the paper to see her hands covering her face. I walked over to her kinda amused by how upset she was. "You got a B... and you're crying?" I asked. She looked up at me quickly. I looked at her with a stupid face, and she busted out laughing. She felt so stupid for crying over one B. I stared laughing too. I knew my grades we be far worse. Heck, I'd be glad to get B's. @PERSON1 and I are the perfect best friends. We even each other out. I tell her to lighten up, and she tells me to focus more. You can't take little things like that too seriously, it's just not worth the stress. Sometimes you just gotta relax, and maintain your focus. You have to find your perfect balance of work, and play.

Laughter is a really good thing to have in any relationship you are in whether its a friendship, a love relationship, or work relationship. Either way you need laughter so you don't get so up tight that you are no fun to be around. Every now and then somebody around you in your life needs some laughter to cheer them up. People should laugh every day because it makes you feel happy even when you are in a really bad mood. When you are feeling down all you really want is someone to talk to you and make you smile, laugh, and giggle. It really feels good when you laugh with a friend or a significant other. You like to see people smile and laugh. Your friends and family also like to see you laugh here and there once in awhile. So every now and then laugh for once and be happy even if it is for a few seconds in your life. Laughter is a major thing to have in your life. Its nice to laugh and giggle even when life gets you down and is crappy. Anyone and everyone needs to laugh so they don't become so grouchy and unbearable to be around. So please for everyone's sake around you and in your life please laugh. Come on, you know you want to laugh. Ha ha ha. I hope that at least made you smile a little bit. In any relationship you have or are in, laughter is a major thing you need. Always try to laugh here and there and you will do just fine in life no matter how screwed up life is at that moment when you laugh.

I believe that with all people laughter, and having a sense of humor, is something that generally everyone has in common, everyone loves to share with others. Among young teenage girls, laughter is a commodity that is infectious but always wonderful. It's the purest kind of joy we have, it's something that brings humans together. It's the beginning and end of friendship and unity. Laughter can ring out and lift the spirits of those that really need it. A simple laugh can make the worst day a little alright. We all know that feeling of dread, and sadness. The kindness, generosity, and good of laughter is one of the few things that are right nowadays. Even in poverty, depression, and oppression the simple joy of laughter can wash away a person's worries for a split second and fill us with utter warmth. @PERSON1 and I have been the best of friends since we were ten-years-old, and laughter has always been our strongest element. @PERSON1 and I have a knack for making each other burst out in laughter when all we want to do is be angry or just cry. We've decided that apart, we're just a little funny, but with our powers combined we could make anyone laugh. We use that power on each other when we're having bad days, or we simply need some cheering up. I think if it wasn't for laughter we wouldn't even be friends anymore. It really is what brings us together as best friends. We'd be different people. Even if I drifted from her we'd always be cracking jokes, making each others guts hurt, and tearing up from laughing so hard. My first impression of @PERSON1 was of her stomping down to our neighborhood park to yell at her sister, whom I had been playing with at the time. It would be a very self-explanatory reason of why I didn't like her at first. Luckily, after going to @PERSON1's house with her sister, @PERSON1 and I found that we had many things in common, and we were only four months apart. That childish kind of cajoling held our friendship together, for it was a bit rocky at the beginning. Always fighting, and arguing about things that now, we look back on and laugh at our adolescent stupidity. Either one of us would be popping off with dumb little comments at each other when neither of us wanted to apologize. One time she proceeded to tell me that I couldn't hear her because I had a big bug in my ear. Now we can remind each other of things like that and have a good ole time laughing about it. We were mere ten-year-old's then. Now, almost sixteen, we rarely fight, but we always laugh and make the best of what we've got with our poking fun. Laughter was definitely the band-aid in the beginning of our rickety friendship. @PERSON1 has a gift to make anything funny at any time. She says the wrong but hilarious things, but always at the right time. Laughter is now a necessity between us, it's what keeps our friendship so strong. I think of what the human race would be like if laughter was not a factor in everyday life. Everyone knows that it wasn't a good day if you haven't laughed or let alone smiled. People would be dull, and just unhappy. Laughter heals people from sickness, it gives us the feeling that maybe everything is going to be okay after all. I truly believe that it

Laugher Laughter is to express delight, fun, or a object of a joke. Laughter is something we all do, its a large benefit in our life and it happend on a everyday scedual. Without laughter we couldn't express our happy, out going side, we would have no particullar feeling in life except for frowning, which is a proven fact to cose more wrinkles beacuse of how many more muscles it uses. For me laughter is a all day thing, @CAPS1 show, my friends, family and, horses are my number one reason for my frown to be tured up side down. You @MONTH1 think horses cant smile, or talk but @CAPS2 do have their own ways of showing a personality that will make you laugh. Shere @CAPS2 are all smart, but @CAPS2 can be clutsy or goofy at times. Mostly @CAPS2 all just make you laugh and giggle like your own little brothers or sisters. There is this one time that I will always have locked away in the back of my mind. It took place on a @DATE1 mid-day at the beach on the @ORGANIZATION1. I was with my friend and we both had our two horses saddled, ready to go. Both us and our horses felt the energy rush when we saw the waves pouning at the shore with the salty smell in our noses. Once we hit the sand we were running side by side with the wind wistling past our ears like a moving train. The horses heads were equaly pointed towards the ocean. When we got to the water, the horses pranced and danced arounds like yearlings again, @CAPS2 would walk tell into the water tell it was drenching us both then soon as the next wave would come rushing up, we'ed swerve around and try to beat the wave to the shore. After about five hours of adventuring caves, sand dunes and starfish we were all worn out, then decided to call it a day. It was around dinner time, so we eat dinner while watching the sun go down to finsih the perfuct day at the beach. We put the horses back in the trailer, and before I shut the trailer door I gave my horse a good pat on his neck, as I was about to walk out my horse tured his head, then gave my a nudge like he was saying "thanks for the good time". Driving home I knew this was a perfuct day because of the laughter, and of all the times I just laughed for the injoyment, also my face did hurt a little from smiling so much, a pleasant reminder of a day filled with pure, unadulterated joy.

I panicked a bit @ORGANIZATION1 tried to get them to be quiet, however the twins paid @CAPS5 attention to me, they were much more excited to see the man on the tall ladder next to me giggling @ORGANIZATION1 laughing along with them. She's backing up @ORGANIZATION1 she's going to squish you on the floor!" @CAPS7 laughed, even the man they were making fun of, but i was so embarrassed that i just took them to the car @ORGANIZATION1 waited for @PERSON1. One time when I was skateboarding with my friend, I got really mad after failing a trick repeatedly and I wanted to stop skating for good. His mom saw my frustration and tried to convince me to keep skateboarding. I laughed and said I would never be good enough to skate, feeling completely defeated. She smiled and said that I had actually improved more than some of the other skaters she knows. That simple, kind observation made me feel much better than before, and then I started skateboarding every single day from that moment on. When I think about that day, I still laugh at how dramatic I was. Skating can be fun in many ways, after all. People can skate just for fun or for competition, depending on their goals. There are different styles of skating, and people have their own unique ways of riding. There are also many different kinds of skateboards, and the people who skate them ride them differently. Some of the people that ride skateboards I still laugh at because of the funny or awkward way they skate, but it’s all part of the sport's diverse culture.  "Laughter" A good relationship is built on trust, right? That's what I've heard my whole life, but as I've grown and really started thinking for myself I came up with my own kind of survival guide, if you will, to good relationships for anyone. Sure trust is important but it isn't the only key factor, I've learned laughter is just as important to not only starting a relationship but keeping it full of life and joy. One person in my life helped me really understand that and be able to have that wonderful relationship with them. My mom and I have such a great bond and way of understanding with each other, other girls I know don't always have that with their mothers, so I am very fortunate. Sure we have hard times just like any family, but we are able to laugh it off with time and start anew. She helped me realize the truth in the saying, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." Having a great bond with my mom is so important to me, though we have not always ran so smoothly. From about age ten to thirteen I was a bit troubled in the sense of not wanting to show my emotions; I just wanted to stay quiet and withdrawn. Then seeing my mom as someone who was strong and beautiful, I have to admit I was a bit worried she would think I was a disappointment if I showed my true self. I guess I was afraid to show who I really was to her. Whenever she would joke around with me I would take it all too seriously, and whenever we would fight about small things I thought she would hate me forever. I know now I was silly to think that, but I'm actually glad we went through that difficult phase. I think that's part of what made us stronger, like how there would be no rainbow without the rain or how there would be no happy ending if all was well throughout your whole life. Little did I know the light at the end of the tunnel was just around the corner. One night after dinner my mom had informed me that it was my night to do dishes, but unlike usual I completely forgot and went to my room to listen to music and eventually fall asleep. My mother came in my room upset and frustrated. She said, "Why did you ignore me? The dishes need to be done now." I jumped out of bed without a word and began walking to the kitchen. She followed me into the small bright room, "Are you alright, it's okay that you forgot. I'm not mad," she exclaimed. Again not a word escaped my lips; I was afraid to say anything. The only sound that came from me was a sigh of relief when I turned back around and noted her absence. When I was finished with the dishes she pulled me into my room. I tried reading her face; she looked worried and concerned. She explained to me the relationship between her and her mom that she so desperately wanted to have with me. She told me about how they would laugh together over silly things and how they promised each other that when they got into fights they would stop themselves, take a deep breath, then laugh. "Laugh? What? Why would you guys do that?" I questioned. She replied, "Because laughter is the best cure for any sad feeling or bad day, as grandma would always say." She helped me experience that by tickling me and joking around until a smile broke through. For the first time in my life I wasn't nervous and I spoke my mind freely. As we sat there and chuckled ourselves to sleep I knew things would be different from here on out, and they truly were. We now have made that promise to one other and we are able to have wonderful smiling memories together. Now at fifteen years old I can honestly say without question my mom will always be my best and truest friend. Our bond, our way of getting over tough times, and the way we can laugh off all stressful things in life makes me feel as if I can get through anything. I've truly realized the profound meaning of the saying, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people."  Laughter. A story about laughter is what you want to hear? Well my life is filled with laughter and smiling, which is crazy I know! If it wasn't for laughing I would not have the six-pack abs that I have today from all the belly laughs. Have you ever stopped to think about how when one person can make another person laugh they usually become really close friends, maybe even best friends? My boyfriend is my best friend, without a doubt. This one time my boyfriend and I were laughing so hard we could barely breathe. My boyfriend is my life and I spend pretty much every day with him; he is so amazing and kind. Me and him, well we do everything together, from simple errands to big adventures. He is very close to me and understands me like no one else. He is the best best friend anyone could ask for! I've only known him for about a year, but a lot can happen in one year. You can meet new people, build strong relationships, and even move away from those relationships you just made. Me and my boyfriend we are always laughing, at each other and at other things as well; we always have fun times with each other. It was a late summer evening and he was walking me home like he always did before. There is this field with extremely tall grass and we were walking right next to it, talking about our day. All of a sudden out of no where he acts like he is getting pulled into the grass by some invisible force. So guess what I did, I screamed as loud as I could possibly scream from the surprise! Then he starts calling my name in a creepy, drawn-out voice telling me to come over to the grass. Out of curiosity about what just happened I start walking over cautiously towards the tall grass. When I arrived to the spot where he entered the grass he tells me with a straight face, "I lost my shoe and I can't seem to find it anywhere!" We start looking everywhere for his shoe, on our hands and knees. We couldn't see anything because it was really dark, so we used our hands to search around blindly for his shoe in the dirt. "I found it!" I said triumphantly. After we found the shoe we realized two whole hours had gone by. We were so tired we laid down in the grass to take a break and we both started cracking up with laughter because of how ridiculous it was that we spent two hours on something that was suppose to be a little joke! It was so awesome and memorable. When we finally got to our feet our bellies hurt so bad and were very sore from the intense laughing. I have never laughed harder than that in my entire life. Every time I'm with him is the best time ever; we always seem to find a way to make each other laugh until we cry. Without best friends or even just friends you would probably find it hard to laugh genuinely. With friends you always have someone to laugh at and also laugh with, sharing the joy. This is why I cherish my best friend and all the happy and laughing times we have together, because you'll never know when the last time you'll see that person will be. I try to be as happy as I can and I try to always make people laugh because I truly believe laughter is the best way of exercise for the soul.  Laughter is a big part in my relationship and I feel so much more connected with a person if we can laugh together easily. Laughing make's you feel great inside and out. You could be in a depression stage and either a friend or a family member could walk up to you, pacify you, and make you laugh, turning your whole day around. If I had a relationship that had no laughter in it, I would leave that person as fast as I could because it would feel empty. Some people think relationships are only about money and/or looks, but they are wrong. People now and days don't last that long in a relationship because they forget the importance of joy. Back in the old days people would die together, and even in death they would have their graves right by each other, showing a deeper commitment. My boyfriends name is John. We have been going out for four years now, and he is a very funny person; I love his jokes and his sense of humor. Sometimes he doesn't even try to make a joke, but he does anyway just by being himself. When we where first going out, I was throwing a birthday party and me, John and one of his friends went in the woods and hid from everyone else for fun. When the others came to find us we jumped out and scared them, making them scream. They where mad at us for a minute, but when night fall came we where all laughing about it together around the fire. My mom and dad don't really laugh together that much in their relationship; it seems more routine. They just go to work with each other and come home together, day in and day out. My dad loves to crack jokes now and then to lighten the mood, but my mom is the kind of person who likes to laugh at the other people that gets hurt on funny videos. My grandma is so funny in her own way; she try's to make people laugh and hurt themselves by telling silly stories so she can get a kick out of their reactions. All of my friends are funny and bring joy to my life. My best friend Sarah is the funniest girl I have ever known; she has a natural talent for comedy. She likes to dance funny and mock people that she doesn't like in a harmless way. When she works, she'll try to find something to make a joke out of, so she could bring it to me and almost make me pee my pants from laughing so hard. Sarah's previous relationship was very bad and lacked laughter. She loves to laugh but her boyfriend at the time hated making jokes and was always serious. She tried to stick it out for a while but things got worse and worse between them. The only thing he would do is sit on his bed or his couch and play video games, or watch wrestling, ignoring her. He would make Sarah clean his room and do all the dishes like a servant. He has a one year old sister and he makes her watch her, clean her, and feed her while he was up in his room playing video games, which was unfair. Sarah got so tired of it all, so she packed her stuff and she left him for good. She went to her sisters house to start over. Now she has a funny boyfriend who understands her and they always laugh together, which is so much healthier. There can be a laughing relationship with animals as well as humans, which people often forget. Animals are the one thing that cant talk back or make fun of you, they just offer pure companionship. Animals are just like humans in their need for love, but they cant talk and they have fur. My cat is the king of my house and his name is Whiskers. He loves to follow me all over my house, from room to room. I love to sit on the floor and watch him wrestle with all of the other cats, tumbling around. Every time I go into the kitchen he is always there with me, bagging for food with loud meows. After he eats, he gets an erg of energy and runs all over the house at top speed. It makes me laugh every single time. He will stop right in front of me and just stare at me with big eyes, and if I move then he will run away as if startled. Cats are cute but not all of them have the power to look into your soul like my cat Whiskers does. Whiskers has these big, round eyes and his meow is so sweet and incessant when he wants attention. The funniest thing about him is how fat he is for his age; he is a fat cat, but he is only one years old. So when I see him running all over the place with his round belly it makes me laugh uncontrollably. My horse is the same way, providing endless amusement. His name is Thunder, and he is four years old. He is a crazy horse, always full of energy, but at the same time he is very funny in his antics. He try's to play with my other horses and get hurt because he bites them playfully, so they kick him back to teach him a lesson. He has a striking blue eye, which is why I bought him for my riding purposes. Some people thinks horses are just a bill to pay, but I think they are my family and a source of great joy and laughter.  Everyone enjoys laughter and its contagious effect. Everywhere you look in life there is always laughter to be found if you pay attention. Laughter comes from being happy, and being happy comes from having joy in your life and appreciating the small things. Many times in my life I have had joy fill my heart. I tend to laugh many times throughout the day on account of I am happy with my life and my family. One topic that brings me constant laughter is my niece. My niece Emily is two years old now. She is the most adorable little girl in the whole world, at least in my opinion she is. Since she is so young she does not have a care or worry in the world; her life is pure and simple. Friends aren't always what we want them to be, and they aren't always easy to find, but with a smile and a laugh, a friendship can begin. I mean, what is a friendship if there aren't those moments where you laugh until you pee, when you laugh until you can't breathe and you feel like you have just done one hundred sit-ups? Of course, you might meet a friend like this, and it might happen when you least expect it. I didn't expect a new friendship, but in a new town and with new people, I met the friend I now call my best friend. It was the year I started at a new school and I was new to the district. In homeroom, everyone stared at me like I was some kind of criminal, and everyone talked behind my back when I would pass by their desks, well at least that's how I felt. My homeroom teacher handed me my so-called schedule. Sixth period was a unicycle class with the coach. What? Unicycling, what is that? I really had no idea what a unicycle was until I walked into that class. I turned the rusty knob of the door to the gym where my class was supposed to be. I walked in and, well, there I found out what a unicycle was. It was a one-wheeled bike. Wow! I laughed, thinking how did I not know that? I looked around and saw that I was the only sixth grader around. I took a seat and looked everywhere, trying to figure out if I was really the only sixth grader there, when in walked a girl that looked about my age. She took a seat and I wondered if she was nice so I could go talk to her, but I was too embarrassed to. The coach asked everyone to get in groups of two, and I asked the girl if she wanted to be my partner. We started to use the unicycles, and our partner had to help us get on and ride until we could ride with no help. Class was over and I told her my name was Sarah, and she told me her name was Emily. I was super excited to go to class next time because I now actually had a "friend," well at least someone I talked to. I went into the class and she was absent, so I was a loner that period. I had to be partners with this other girl named Savannah, who was a total girly girl. She didn't want to ride the unicycle; all she wanted to do was talk. I was sick and tired of her by the end of the day and I hadn't practiced my unicycling. I was really hoping Emily would show up to class the next day, and she did. This time we had to get with our partner and make a routine to a song that we wanted, so we were pretty stoked. We started practicing and trying to come up with something when suddenly we both fell. We stared at each other and just started laughing and laughing; I couldn't breathe and she almost peed. It was one of the best times I had experienced that year, and I felt like she and I could become the best of friends. We are now really close friends, and just that one moment of laughter together brought us close at heart. We love to laugh; we believe that the more you laugh the younger you look, and well, I think it's true. Everyone has their own story about how they met a certain person and how they became so close. I believe that in every friendship, what brought it together was a smile or laughter, a laughing moment where you laughed so hard you farted and milk came out of your friend's nose. It's a great time and you never forget it; it's something that is so simple but so special, and it really marks your heart and the way you feel around that person. It brought my friendship with a person I had barely met into a friendship that is now inseparable and amazing, a bond truly forged in joy.

It was a normal, bright and warm summer day, going into my fifth grade year. My older sister and I had been playing all day with my other neighbors that were around our age. One of those neighbors happened to be a boy. We could not find anything to do. It was too hot out to just go walk around in the sun, so we decided that it would be cool to play in the shade with the new slingshot my dad had made. He made it out of an old swing set seat, and I thought my neighbor would really enjoy it. We all headed into our garage to get it. My sister offered to get it down for me since she was taller and it was hanging up pretty high, but I refused. It was my idea to show him, so I would be the one to get it. As I was in total concentration, stretching and reaching to grab it, I noticed everyone around me giggling. My concentration got weaker as I begun to wonder what they were all laughing at. I stood there confused for a minute before I had found out what happened. My sister pulled down my pants right in front of our boy neighbor. I picked my pants up off the ground, looked straight at my sister, and started beating her with my flimsy, loose fists before I ran straight to my room, crying all the way there. My sister came in a few moments later, trying to bribe me out from under the covers with the last two fruit roll-ups. She sat on my bed waiting for a half an hour, but I didn't budge. She did not say anything, but I could feel her eyes piercing me through the sheets. Later that night, I finally came out. My sister kept on apologizing, but it didn't matter to me because I was upset with her; that's all that mattered. The whole next day passed and nothing had changed. She was still apologizing and I was still in the ignoring mood. My dad came up to me and told me that she was terribly sorry and upset too because I was not talking to her. I thought in my head, "how could she be upset?" but then I realized I had not treated her right, even though I wasn't happy with her. After hearing what my dad had said, I decided that it wasn't worth it. I went and talked to my sister for the first time in days. She told me that she didn't mean to hurt my feelings; she was just messing around. After talking about it for a while, I concluded that I got so upset because she did it in front of our friend. We joke around like that all the time, but it's never in front of anyone besides family. I was scared that it would have frightened our neighbor friend away, but he was back to play in a few days, so I had nothing to be mad about. Even though I was embarrassed, I admitted that it was pretty funny. We had a good laugh about it and were no longer enemies. I learned that dwelling over the past gets you nowhere and you have to learn to laugh things off. Ever since then, every time it is brought up, we laugh so hard tears roll down our face. I would not have considered it a good thing when it happened, but I do now. It is another memory that my sister and I share and can reminisce about, and the more laughable memories you share, the closer it brings you to someone.

Making someone laugh is the best feeling for their soul, and it is one step closer to internal happiness. People might say that when feeling something good inside the body, it's when they know that they have done something right. I agree with this because it has happened to me; I was feeling down about something that I can't even remember, but when I felt the need to help someone do something, I knew inside of me that I did something very special at that moment. It's amazing how when you make someone laugh, it doesn't matter where you are, you also feel happy. The one person in my life that has a great sense of humor is my mother. She is always in need of something funny. People enjoy laughing so much that it is as if they were to take some sort of energy drink to make them not want to stop laughing. I hear people say that laughter is very healthy for a human soul, and it will also make the soul and body last longer. Laughter is a way of expressing yourself without having to say much. It could be a great way to start a conversation with a person. Positive thinking leads to making good choices, especially if happiness leads you on in life. By making someone laugh, it makes the awkwardness go away. It is better to laugh than to be sad. Everyone has their addiction to something in which they need to depend on. My mom's addiction is laughing. She laughs at work, and she especially laughs at the house whenever I'm around. Although, sometimes she feels down whenever something goes wrong. I hate seeing her like this because it then makes me feel down. When she is feeling sad, it is as if there is nothing in the world that would make her cheer up. If one person is feeling depressed, that feeling passes on to the next person closest to them. Eventually, I get tired of seeing my mom like this, and in this situation, I can't help it but to get up and start doing some ridiculous stuff to cheer her up. Some things that pop into my mind are that I can start dancing funny or tell a little lie that might have happened at school that I think will cheer her up. When there is an opportunity to make someone laugh, I enjoy putting a smile on their face. My mom means the world to me, just as I mean the world to her. We try to help each other in any way possible. This one day, she came home from work and my dad was sitting at the table reading the newspaper. My mom walked in and noticed that my dad hadn't made food yet; she started to flip out on him. She thought that it was stupid of him to not make dinner for us. She was pretty angry at him for a period of time, so she started to make us dinner, but she was doing it all wrong. She was mixing the spices in the wrong pan; I was going to let her know that she was doing it all wrong, but my dad was holding me back so that I wouldn't get her more angry. She finally finished cooking and served us our plates, but we didn't want to eat it because she made the food out of anger and made it smell funky. My dad forced us to eat it because he thought that by eating the food it would make her happy, but he was wrong; it only made her feel worse because my youngest brother didn't like it. I felt bad, so I had to do something funny that was going to put her in the mood to not be mad at my dad anymore. I turned on the stereo and changed the channel to the music station and started to dance as if I had ants in my pants. Her lungs were about to burst because she was laughing so hard, and eventually, she was in a good mood for the rest of the day. Everywhere I go, I see people smiling and laughing about something, and it only makes me wonder about the funny things that are being said. I think that it is a good thing for someone to feel good about themselves because it brings a positive feeling in the room. I enjoy seeing people be happy because it always makes me feel happy. What better way to be happy when smiling is one step closer to laughing? My mom and I like to take walks just so that we wouldn't feel apart and stay closer to each other; we see different people each time we go walking and we always get a smile from them. That is the best feeling in the world, to feel joy is to be free from all your problems, a simple truth that laughter constantly reaffirms.

"Laughter is the key to the soul." Whether you are having the worst day of your life, or the best day of your life, laughing can always make it better. I was sitting in history class one day and was bored out of my mind. Then, a shy, quiet kid all of a sudden started laughing! He couldn't stop! It was like he was on "laughing gas." He laughed so hard he couldn't breathe. Now this made me laugh, and then my best friend sitting next to me laugh. Soon enough, the entire class was laughing! So even though some of the people in history class might have been bored or had a bad day, the laughter was spread throughout the room, making it a better day for everyone present. Laughter spreads like wildfire, and it makes everyone happier. And when you are happier, you are healthier. So with that, a good relationship must have laughter in it in order to work. When you ask someone what they like about their boyfriend or girlfriend, if it is a healthy relationship, they will almost always say, "He or she makes me laugh." Conversely, when you don't have laughter in a relationship, you end up in more fights, more disagreements, and more disappointment. The more you laugh, the more you can live a better life and enjoy life more. Have you laughed today? It is a small question that can reveal so much about the quality of our daily lives and our connections with others.

There are many joys in life; some are more relevant than others, and some are so obvious you'd be stupid not to notice them. Have you ever just sat on your porch or stared out the window just to watch the sun rise? As you sat there pondering your life and its unusual qualities, you think of all the great memories, all the laughs you have shared, all the sorrows, all the pain, and all the love and hate. It's not surprising that almost everyone has done just that, and they wonder if they could change things, how would they do that, or would they leave it the way it started out, feeling their life is complete and they are complete as well, not having any regrets. For all the tears I have cried and all the pain I've been through, there has always been a laugh to top the sadness. Sometimes I too sit and ponder my life; although I have not lived long and my real experiences are yet to come, I have been through a great deal in my short experiences, but it does not trouble

A true story about how two close friends became friends over the shared joy of laughter. One year, there was a boy named @PERSON1 who wanted to do something fun this @DATE1 instead of just staying in his room and playing video games all day. So he heard of a play called "@CAPS1 In @LOCATION1" from a friend and found out he could join and help out. But he ended up getting a part in the play and also helped backstage whenever he could. @PERSON1 found that he enjoyed doing the play very much and made a lot of new friends. At the same time, there was a girl named @ORGANIZATION1 who didn't talk much to @PERSON1 at all, but she liked him, a fact she didn't tell a whole lot of people. @ORGANIZATION1 also tried to make as many friends as she could while doing the plays and spent as much time with them as possible. As the play started to end, @PERSON1 began to hang out with @PERSON2, who is @ORGANIZATION1's older brother, and started to pay a little more attention to her. He found out from her brother that she liked him, but @PERSON1 already knew from the way she acted around him. Because of how much fun he had, @PERSON1 joined another play called "@CAPS2 in @LOCATION1" after the first one ended. He found he already knew most of the people from the first play, so he started talking to the rest of the people he didn't know. This is when @PERSON1 and @ORGANIZATION1 started talking to each other regularly, and both of them found that they enjoyed each other's laughter; they became very close friends very fast. This was likely because @PERSON1 made friends easily and @ORGANIZATION1 did not have very many close friends, partly because she had been homeschooled after kids at school made fun of her for being smart, causing her to lose the few friends she had. @PERSON1 soon found out that in their friendship, @ORGANIZATION1 was scared of him not wanting to be her friend because of all the friends she had already lost. By the time the second play was starting to come to an end, @PERSON1 had already noticed that @ORGANIZATION1 had liked him before they were friends, and he asked her if she did. She said no at first but then felt bad for lying and told him the truth about how she did like him and how she thought it would be best if they just stayed friends. Both of them knew that they could only be friends because of their age difference; @PERSON1 was @NUM1 and @ORGANIZATION1 was @NUM2, so they agreed it would never have worked out. As the play was ending, they used every minute to grow their friendship, and by the final curtain, they had become close friends who cherished the good times and the laughter they shared. Even after the play, both of them still talked whenever they had time, though they didn't get to see each other much. They talked about the good times they had and how much fun the plays were. Both agreed they would do the plays again next @DATE1 and looked forward to seeing each other then, with many great things to talk about. In the end, I think that @PERSON1 and @ORGANIZATION1 are going to be friends for a long time, and maybe when they get older they could be more than friends, taking their friendship to the next level—only time will tell.

I never thought that laughing could help you start a conversation with someone you don't even know. But laughter can. Just by laughing with someone, you can meet a new person. One of the first things I do when someone is trying to be funny is laugh. Once you know what the other person is talking about, you forget that you are just getting to know them. This happened to me once in @LOCATION1, where my family and I usually go every year in @DATE1. I made a great friend, and the first thing we did was laugh. As you know, @LOCATION1 is a hot place and the sun is usually out every day. I spend the days we stay over there going out to walk with my sister and cousins or going to the beach with all my family. I remember it was a day that my cousins, sister, and I went to a small store right down the street from where we stay. We wanted to buy candy and other stuff to bring with us when we returned to our home. I didn't expect to see one of my cousins there with his friends. When I saw them, the only thing they were doing was laughing about something. I couldn't hear them, but once we got closer, I heard a hilarious thing they said. I couldn't help overhearing, so I started to laugh. One of his friends saw me laughing and thought I was laughing at him. He asked me if I was, and of course I said no. I told him I had accidentally overheard his conversation, so then he started to laugh. "That was funny, wasn't it?" he told me, laughing. "Yes, it was. I didn't know you made jokes like that," I replied. He kept on talking to me and then said, "I always talk like that, so don't be afraid. I don't say things to hurt anyone." I thought it was nice for him to clear that out, but I already knew people in @LOCATION1 talk like that. We kept on talking when I started to laugh again. "What did I say now?" he asked. "Nothing. I was just remembering what you said in the beginning. That was really funny," I replied. For some reason, I couldn't forget what he said, and I don't think I ever will, probably because the way we met was really surprising to me. I had never met a person, especially a guy, by laughing first. I guess I thought it was a great way to start a conversation. Laughing with the person lets them know that we are interested in their subject and that we understand them. That's at least what I thought. I had a good conversation with my new friend. We talked about how I was spending my vacation. I told him that every year I go and I always enjoy it, that my family and I have a great time spending time with my grandparents and cousins from @LOCATION1. I told him I sometimes say I would rather live in @LOCATION1 than where I live now because it's so much calmer there. He agreed with me on one part of what I had told him because he knows what it's like to live in @LOCATION1, but he doesn't know how it is to live in any other place. After he told me that, he stayed quiet for a couple of seconds. I noticed something instantly; our conversation wasn't like in the beginning when we wouldn't stop laughing and had interesting stuff to say. Then, it got calmer and a little unusual. I didn't want to just stop our conversation there, so I asked him where he was going to go because when I started talking to him, he was with one of my cousins and I was with my other cousins. Now we started laughing again, this time because we had just noticed that the people we were with had left us. "When did they leave?" he asked me. "I don't know, but they can't be that far because we haven't been talking for a long time," I told him. We walked together to look for them, and I was right; they weren't far. They were still looking for things to buy and didn't seem to notice we were missing. We just got together with them and acted as if nothing had happened. It was strange for me because whenever I looked at him, I would remember our conversation, and the first thing that would come to my mind was that we started it by laughing at a funny thing he said. I actually liked making a new friend this way. Now, whenever I go to @LOCATION1, I know I have a new friend over there, and if I decide to, I can make other friends by simply laughing with them in their conversations.

As I waited in the car, anxious to meet my best friend and the man I'm in love with, I started to laugh. Not because something my mother or brother said was funny, or because I saw something funny, but because I was nervous. I'd talked to him countless times on the phone, exchanged many text messages, and sent countless emails, but I was still nervous. I knew him better than I knew most people, yet my anxiety seemed to be making me lose my sanity. As our black rental sedan pulled up to where he was waiting outside his family's home, I got more nervous. What if he wasn't actually the way I thought he was? What if he didn't like me? What if I didn't like him? As soon as he stepped into the car, smiling brightly at me, my nervous laughter and my anxiety all melted away. I smiled back. "Hello, @PERSON1," he said. "Hello, @PERSON2," I said, butterflies in my stomach. I was smiling broadly still when he reached out and cautiously took my hand. "How was the drive?" he asked, lightly squeezing my hand. "Long, and nerve-wracking," I replied, nervous laughter bubbling up again. "But you're here now, and I'm very happy you are," he said, smiling. For the rest of the car ride to the restaurant, our conversation flowed so smoothly I thought I was dreaming. Here we were, two guys in love with one another—a new thing for both of us—and we were as happy as could be. The whole car ride we held hands and talked; I felt like I'd known him my whole life, not just the year and a half I actually had. We arrived at @ORGANIZATION1 all too fast, and all of us got out of the car; I was famished and so was he. But we had to wait for a table for a half-hour before we sat down. Once at the dinner table, my mother, who was very happy I found someone I loved so much and knew of our love, started regaling us with tales of my childhood. It was one of the most embarrassing moments of my life; I was bright red for almost the entire time she told these stories, some of which I remembered and others I did not. @PERSON2 laughed and joked with me about all of them, which made my nervous laughter turn into actual laughter, especially since he was holding my hand under the table. After we ate dinner and dessert, we went to the nearby mall for some shopping and to just hang out. My mom and brother went one way, and @PERSON2 and I went another. We bought some clothes together and finally ended up in a book store, my favorite, @ORGANIZATION3's. Back in my favorite section, young adult fiction, I noticed @PERSON2 staring at me. "What?" I asked stupidly. He smiled deviously. "You just look very... in your element," he smirked. "And?" I said, in mock confusion. He just smiled and took my hand in his again. "No problem," he said, squeezing my hand. He pulled me closer to him; we were the only people in this area of the store. "Mind if I'm a little forward?" he asked. I shook my head no. He leaned in and kissed me very gently on the lips; I blushed bright red and started to giggle after our lips parted. He quirked an eyebrow, and I knew what he was thinking just by the look on his face. "That felt fantastic," I said, putting my fingers on my lips with a silly grin on my face. "Good," he simply said, kissing me again. "I love your laugh, love," he told me. I was on cloud nine; I was truly in love with somebody and I felt great! I'd never been this happy before, except maybe the first time I went to @ORGANIZATION2, but this was definitely better because it could last much longer, which it has, since we've been together ever since, our gazes fixed on our future together. Now whenever I remember that day, I start to giggle happily to myself. Yes, I get a stare every once in a while, but I don't care. Laughter is the thing that helped bridge the gap between him and me, making us the closest we've ever been.

Many people are drawn to laughter. People always say that laughing can have many benefits. The truth, I believe, is that laughter is not always the best thing. Laughing can have many different meanings and contexts. When I think of laughter, I think of smiles, genuine happiness, and fond memories. Although, there is one memory of laughter that does not prove that to be true. "Mom, I really don't wanna be here. I don't know that I can stay here and tell him this," I pleaded to my mother to let me go back home. "You need to do this honey. It's for the best." Up to that point I had always though my mother knew best. Now, I wasn't so sure. I sat patiently on the stiff sofa, trying to hold back tears, waiting for my father to get back to his house. I knew he was at the bar, and silently thanked him that I had time to think. I was supposed to go tell him how I felt about him always drinking alcohol. Every time I went over there I saw him either drunk, or on his way there. The truth is, I was scared. I was scared for his health and scared that I was the reason for his drinking. I was getting older and needed to tell him what I thought and how I felt. While distracted by this realization, he came storming through the door. I looked up at my drunk father and my heart dropped. I burst out in tears while my mother held me in her arms. "Shh...It's alright," she soothed. My father looked at me without any recognition and went into the other room. I walked in the room where he was and watched cautiously at him through the open doorway. He wasn't the man my mother had once married anymore. He had became a monster. I couldn't stand it anymore. I walked into the room where my mother waited with worry in her eyes. "Let's go home," I said. On the way home I sobbed until my shirt was streaked with tears. The car ride home was silent and the thoughts and sadness hung thick in the air. I could barely sleep that night. The sun shone down on my face as I awoke to a new day. I felt confident and ready to go back and confess to my dad how I've felt all along. We drove back to his house and when we pulled into the drive way, nervousness rushed through me. I wobbled up to the door and knocked. "Dad. Hey." It made me upset that my father was acting as if nothing was wrong. I walked in, with confidence, and asked him to sit down. I was content with the fact that I had caught him in one of this rare moments of not being drunk. "Dad, we really need to talk. I feel as though you are making a huge mistake by drinking. I know you're addicted and there are risks with stopping but you're also endangering your health!" I basically screamed at him. I poured out my heart as a whole new wave of tears rushed over me. By the time I was done my father sat there with a blank look pasted on his face. He laughed. "Your mother told you to tell me this stuff. Don't worry about it. Your mom doesn't know what she's talking about." My jaw dropped as he acted as though this wasn't serious. Anger boiled in me. "You don't even know me! You don't even care about me!" I screamed then stormed out. I went into the living room and looked straight at my mother and somehow she knew exactly that I wanted to leave. This time the car ride, again, seemed to be filled with silence. Thinking about how laughter is almost always a great thing, I started to cry because, just once, laughing didn't mean happiness. It meant tears.

Laughter is often seen as a universal sign of joy. "Honey, we've got something to tell you." I knew what they were about to tell me. I saw the signs. I knew that when they went into the other room, it wasn't for some quality time together. They were getting a divorce and the time to tell me had come. As each of my parents gathered around me, I knew that they were about to say something I wasn't ready to hear. The words "We are getting a divorce," rang in my head like church bells when a couple is getting married. The happiest sound you could ever hear. But that was the exact opposite of what was going on right now. As I looked up into the face of my mother, I could tell she had been crying. Where the blue, gray mixture used to meet and become one, it had turned red and irritated. It killed me inside to see her crying, and while this was happening my dad just sat on the couch near me with his head buried in his hands. I could tell that he was thinking that he was so in love and that it all just went downhill, leaving him with an intense feeling of resentment and anger towards my mother. The love of his life, was now his enemy. At seven I couldn't fully wrap my mind around what was happening to our family. I got that one parent would move away, that I wouldn't always get tucked into bed at night by a duo of love, I just didn't understand why this had to happen. My poor little brother. Only four, how could they possibly explain this to him. If I was confused, he had to of been off on another planet. At the thought of my family crumbling before my eyes, I wanted to cry. I wanted to go far, far away from the troubles occurring at home. If a genie had been there to grant my three wishes, I would of used all three of them if I thought there would be a possibility to save my parents relationship. Crying just seemed so much easier than sitting in the living room listening to my parents say ,"It's not your fault, don't blame yourself, this is between your father and I." Why did they think those statements made it better? Because it really didn't help. My parents had fallen out of love with each other, and the hope I had that they would get back together was diminishing faster than the amount of rain forest left in the world. Plus, there was still the underlying factor that my home was broken. And more importantly than my home, my heart. It was broken and I didn't think there was enough super glue in the whole world to pull the pieces back together. Just as it felt like the whole world was going to crash down upon me, my mother said something to me that I will never forget. "When you feel like crying, laugh. Remember all the good times that we spent together as afamily." One by one, each memory began to flood back into my mind. The time dad jumped into the pile of leaves we had collectively raked. The time when mom and I made sugar cookies in the winter that ended up burnt, but still made the whole house feel warm and familiar. And especially the wedding that brought the two of them together in matrimony. That sacred bond that only ministers can ensue on people. The one that forever changed their lives and mine. I began to laugh, and then to cry. My parents weren't sure what to think about my sudden change of emotion. They asked ,"What's wrong, honey?" And I, still thinking that none of these memories would be had again, I then realized something. I realized that even though my family wouldn't be together all the time, that we would still laugh. That when someone slipped on a piece of paper, it would be funny. My tears had stopped spewing out of my eyes like a dam in desperate need of repair, and the realization had finally set in that we would be okay. That with laughter in our lives, and memories in our hearts, we would survive this. From then on, i solely believed in that one statement spoken to me by my mother. "When you feel like crying, laugh." The statement that said to me, it's okay to be sad, but that as long as you have laughter in your life, everything will be alright. In my heart, I applauded my mom for handling that situation so well. If it had not been for her, I would of kept on with the water works and never stopped for just a second to think about all the hilarious times we had had together. So, as far as laughter goes, don't forget to just take a moment out of every day to remember each punch line to every corny joke, it will bring you comfort.

Laughter, the sense of pure happiness. You are in the moment and nothing else matters, all your worries and stress fall away leaving you with your true happy self. Have you ever had those moments when everything seem too much? Then a friend says something that makes you laugh, once your done laughing you start to cry because it felt so good to laugh. Or when you laugh so hard you fall to the floor and can't get up for what seems hours? Yet looking back you forget what was so funny. Laughter is magical, second only behind love. Those two seem to go hand in hand. When you love someone, not just you boyfriend/girlfriend but you friends and family too, you know how to make them laugh or cheer them up, how to have fun with them, and that brings you even closer together. When I'm with my friends the one thing we seem to do most is laugh. We laugh about anything and everything that is even slightly funny. It bring us closer together, sharing a moment of joy. The six of us are very close and will be friends after high school is over, even if we go to colleges a thousands of miles away. It is because we have shared so many happy memories. Laughter is important in a relationship. We trust each other and can share anything with them even our most important secrets. This story is how we came to be so close. Brightly colored fancy dresses and killer high heels were splayed out across the room. Open soda cans and chip bags. The faint smell of nail polish, flowery perfume, and deodorant lingering in the air. Laughter and giggles bubbling through out the room with the occasional squeal. Pitch black outside but light and warm in. Six of us lounging around the room. Smeared makeup and deflating hair. Sweat pants and baggy t-shirts. We all went from looking our very best to... not, within a few minutes. Yet not one of us cared. We when looking at each other we were able to see past appearances had fun with each other, not their looks. We had just gotten back from the dance. None of us had had dates but we still managed to have the time of our lives. "Oh and did you see him! He was dancing with her!" "I wouldn't really call that dancing...." she made a pelvic thrust, we all burst into a new round of giggles and shouted stuff like, "Oh my gosh, get a room!" We gossiped about what we saw, who was with who, pretty dresses, hot guys, creeper guys, slow dances, the music, even our drinks we hid our cups so we would know which one was ours when we wanted to use it again.We had all been friends, but recently we had been becoming closer. Starting to move from friends to best friends. It was at least one in the morning. Everyone was exhausted but was forcing themselves to stay up with caffeine and sugar. You might ask why, but I'm not really sure. Maybe because we always seem to have so much to talk about, because we enjoy each others company, or just because we can, so why not?"Hey I think we need a picture, a picture of the six of us." I said."Yes!" "Okay""Right now? I'm a mess!""I've got just the thing!" Sarah takes off running upstairs to grab something."Where should we sit?""On the bed?""Okay, yes! Scoot over fatties""Hey! I'm not fat, I'm festively plump!" We all cracked up to the reference of the movie as we stared to squeeze into a corner of the squishy full size bed. Sarah and Sarah's mom arrive back into the room. Sarah was carrying a old polaroid camera that print out the picture immediately after you took it. She gave the camera to her mom and jumped on to the bed. We all squished together, barely enough room to breathe."One...Two...Three!" Click! the picture came out. "Let's take one more while the first is developing. Again, one... two... three!" Click! Snap! "Crack!!!" We all screamed in unison. The bed broke! we had broken the bed! We all sat there clinging to each other in total shock."My bed! You guys are faaaaat..." Sarah said while trying to contain a giggle. Suddenly we were in hysterics. Even Sarah's mom was laughing. We were one big throbbing pile of laughter. Only the corner of the bed had broken so we were all pulled down into that corner. Then someone started tickling, it was war. Every girl for themselves. It was a mass of bedsheets, wiggling fingers, bare feet, biting and a whole lot of laughing. "Oh the pictures have developed." The first one showed us sitting together smiling, but the second one was taken just as the bed broke. It showed the shock on our faces as we held onto each other for support. Not only did it bring us literally closer together but it started our amazing friendship.

After staring at the screen for a good fifteen minutes or so, I began to silently laugh at my situation: I have to write about one of four things when not a single one was even remotely interesting. The three of us were swimming as fast as we could in the icy water after the floating pole, and I was almost able to reach it. Right as I got about a foot from the pole, the fish started to swim faster, pulling it away. While I was trying to get the pole, I was not focused on where I was going and I got caught on a submerged tree, so it was up to @PERSON1 and @PERSON2 to get the pole. The chase for the floating fishing pole had now gone on for over five minutes and all of us were very far down the river. Suddenly, @PERSON2 yelled out that he had finally got the pole, so we all swam to the shore to reel in the fish. At this time, we were very happy that we had gone into the ice-cold river after this fish, and we could not wait to get home and get dry. After a few more minutes, @PERSON2 was still reeling in the huge fish. He said he did not know how he was going to get it onto the shore. Once the fish got very close to the shore, @PERSON2 jerked the pole as hard as he could to get it onto the bank, but as he pulled, the line broke and the fish got away. All of our hard work was for nothing. After that disappointing moment, we decided that it was time to just go home and sit by the fire. A lot of people I tell this story to think it is funny, but personally, I don't see anything funny about swimming in the snow only to break your fishing line. One good thing is that this was the most memorable day of fishing I had ever had.
