But many other people believe and think that laughter is an important part of any relationship with your friends, family etc. Now I'm going to talk about a few reasons of how laughter can be a benefit to us, and how it can also create distances from people, or how laughter works in the relationships we have with friends. Many people think that it's really fun to laugh about simple things and that's me; I can laugh at things that might not seem funny to others, but to me they might seem extremely funny. I won't stop laughing for a while. But many other people don't consider laughter as funny, as many others do. I believe that laughter is an important part of us because it shows people around you the way you are and how you express yourself. Many of your friends or even your family will know what type of person you are and how silly you can be sometimes. That's the reason why I think it's a great thing to do, to just have some fun and laugh. Now talking about relationships between people. Do you think that laughter can be an important part of any relationship or how could it help us in various ways? Well yes I do think that laughter can be extremely important in many relationships we have with people. You get to know others and others get to know about you and how you are. Even though we have many relationships with our friends, family, or with new people we meet, I believe that laughter tells you how a person is and how that person reacts to what other people do or tell them. Laughter expresses how that person is and whether they are fun people to be around. Laughter even tells you if that person has a lot of humor, just a little, or doesn't have any humor at all. When people don't have that much humor they really don't understand and get the funny parts from jokes or anything. I also think that laughter is really important to any type of relationship you have with anybody, because that makes you know that person a lot better. But other people consider laughter being a reason that distances two people from

Laughter fills the air around us with happiness and joy, it brings warm memories of loved ones that are close to us, and adds a splash of hope to those who need it. Laughter is the key to solving life's problems. It is a way of adding something special into our life and comes from many different areas of life. Laughter could come from a pitiful joke that someone could have told you, it could be brought up by a show, and it could also come from the joy we get when a near loved one has returned home from a long journey. Imagine seeing something comical like a person falling down or crashing into a pole; the moment right when that happens you hear yourself laughing as hard as you can that you practically can't breathe and the person standing right next to you is joining in on the laugh. Although it might seem rude and disrespectful, you have just made a bond with the person right next to you and found a similarity between the both of you. This shared moment is how friendships are brought up and made; just by one little thing that made you both laugh and have a connection with each other can trigger a brand new friendship between two people that could either last a minute or can last a lifetime. In my case, this is how I met one of my closest friends ever. We had seen a student from our class trying to show the class how cool he was by climbing up the flag pole and replace the state flag with his own personal homemade flag (he got the idea off of a show). As he was heading up the pole almost halfway there he must have gotten scared because minutes later he started yelling for help; a minute later the faculty members finally heard his cries and yells and tried to get him down from where he was. It took them almost half an hour to get him down. That was the moment where I had made one of the greatest friendships I've ever had in my life. Many friendships are made in class and with the people you go to work with, but a great friendship is brought up by a simple laugh two people share with each other. God laughs last. Isaac is the name of Abraham's son of Sarah and Abraham. In Isaac's story, Sarah the wife of Abraham claimed that she was surprised when she was blessed with her only child and that people would laugh and be surprised the same way she was when they hear the news. Being surprised or shocked can also bring someone to laugh at what either happened in their surroundings or what they did themselves. I remembered a time where I laughed at something that took me by surprise; it was when my mother lost the keys to the house inside the car. We looked for them everywhere but had no luck finding them. After an hour had passed we called my dad so he would bring the other key to the house; after we called him we had to wait half an hour for my dad to get there, but as soon as my father parked in the driveway my mother found the key that she lost inside her pocket (it was a typical cartoon moment). When we heard the news we all just started laughing at what has just happened; we were all shocked and a little dumbfounded when that occurred. As you can see, being surprised can also bring a smile and a laugh onto someone's face. Picture yourself staring into the eyes of someone close to you with a blank face and trying not to let out the slightest bit of a giggle or a smile, and then find yourself laughing nonstop for no reason. That is basically an everyday thing for me and my sister. My sister and I can't stare at each other for even a minute; we eventually start laughing the first five seconds and end up laughing a whole hour without stop. But as soon as we stop laughing we note that we were laughing for no apparent reason, which would make us laugh for another hour more. That is the kind of laughter that two people who are so close to each other get; the kind that you don't need a reason to laugh but you end up laughing for no reason at all. This shows the connection two people have with each other, the type where you know what the other person is thinking. Laughter can come from old memories of family gatherings for the holidays, friendships we made when we were in school, memories of our childhood and how things we thought then were in style and cool are now things we look back into and laugh at, by being a little surprised, and can also be the fact that we know someone by heart.

I laugh every day. I feel a lot of different emotions when I am laughing. Some of the emotions are happiness, sadness, and pain. I use laughter to let my emotions be seen. When I laugh I usually feel happy afterwards unless I am crying because I am hurt. When I am sad I tend to laugh and smile a lot to hide the pain I am feeling because I don't want people to see me sad all the time and think I am playing the sad card to get attention. But laughing and smiling actually make everything hurt worse instead of making it better. When I am sad I tend to rely on laughter to get me through my day because if I didn't have laughter I would have people asking what was wrong all day and it would drive me crazy. When I am angry the only way I can laugh is if a friend or family member is trying to make me happy or if I am reminiscing of fun times I've had. It makes me happy when I laugh and brightens my day when I am angry. I also laugh at things people say to me even though they hurt my feelings when they said it, because I don't want them to know they hurt me. When I am happy all I do is smile and laugh. Laughter brightens my life when it's a happy laugh. My friends and I can just sit there and laugh for hours about nothing. My friends and I can be pretty silly at times and all we can do is laugh, have fun and be in a good mood, and that makes me pretty happy. Some things in my life that make me laugh are my nephew, my family, and my friends. All those things I was just talking about come into my mind when I think of laughter. I think that every single person needs some laughter in their life to be happy and to navigate the complex feelings we all experience.

Laughter's Echo Laughter is everywhere. It might be three doors down reclining in a comfy living room. It might be at the nearest playground bouncing on the teeter-totter. It might be at an elegant restaurant sitting at a petite table in the distant corner. For me, it lingered in an old fifth grade classroom. I stumbled through the doorway carrying my purple backpack and my lunch pale resting in my left hand. I recognized everyone from my previous years of elementary school, and shortly joined them after visiting my hook outside the door. I had been waiting anxiously for my turn at the fifth grade. The legendary Mr. Anderson, was known as the "coolest" teacher around. He played a large role in the gossip of the young students, and each of us had our hopes set high. "Find your seats fifth graders!" announced Mr. Anderson with a contagious smile. Kids scattered around the room searching for seats near their closest friends. Everyone listened attentively to Mr. Anderson's introduction to the year. His voice caught our full attention, but not too exciting compared to our expectations. He appeared very nice as most teachers come, but still nothing spectacular. The day dragged on. The sleepy faces returned and the vivid colors had escaped our touch. The day finally reached an end, not satisfying the eager children. The next day rose quickly and I trudged back to the disappointing classroom. To my surprise, the next day was nothing like the first. The classroom had experienced a drastic change. Every wall was filled with endless color. Posters layered over the plain paint with fascinating pictures and words. A fancy popcorn machine rested in the back of the room. Fresh popcorn overflowed from inside. The smell traveled through our needy nostrils as we entered. Mr. Anderson sat contently at his broad desk as we made our way to our seats once again. He welcomed us to our second day. After the first couple minutes of class I had found that the rumors were true. He had a sense of simple humor that created giggles in every corner of the class. His ideas and word choice related to us as fifth graders. We found his subtle jokes quite amusing to our young minds. He spoke like we spoke, he acted like we acted, and he joked like we joked. He even created customized nicknames for each of us. Laughter hung over our heads like a heavy echo, never continuing along. Weekly popcorn servers would hand out stuffed bags to all the kids as the class read aloud. Kids became ecstatic on jeopardy days gathering teams as quick as possible. His classroom became a place that we wanted to stay forever, never parting from hour long games and water chugging contests. Despite the everlasting fun and games, Mr. Anderson showed us what it was really like to be a learner. He cared about our future and pushed us to strive in every moment of life. He taught us to write with desire and worth. To express our feelings on paper and tell the world a story that we want heard. He would plan one on one time with students struggling in a particular subject, and next class their confidence had bloomed. He had an ability to reach into our minds, find out who we were, and emerge that hidden confidence to become successful. We respected him, yet felt comfortable messing around with him during class as he had frequently done to us. Mr. Anderson gave us a craving to learn. One afternoon, I had began to walk home, when Mr. Anderson stopped me at the door. "Hey Mr. Anderson!" I unexpectedly said in a high tone, not hiding my enthusiasm. He chuckled, "Have fun at class today?" "Oh yeah," I answered with a grin. "I'm glad," he continued, then changing the subject, "I was thinking about having a huge dodge ball tournament at recess tomorrow. Do you think that would be a good idea?" I snickered to myself, trying to comprehend the fact that an adult had said this to me, "That would be so fun." "Great," he expressed quite excited, "You are a really neat kid, you know that? It's a lot of fun having you in class." My face lit up. I stood there smiling for quite some time. We finished our slight conversation and I continued home. Every student in the class yearned to be liked by Mr. Anderson, as if he were the most popular kid at school. I was liked by him; I was liked by the man that changed my whole outlook on education and life. Gradually, from time to time, I drift back to the careless days of fifth grade and Mr. Anderson. I still laugh at the ridiculous events that occurred in that small classroom each and every day. Frequently, I glance above me to witness that dense echo that still hovers above me. Laughter has left a mark on me, and those kids of my fifth grade class, a mark that reminds us of the joy of learning.

Laughing is one of the key components in all my relationships with others. It lightens the mood of any situation and can really lift my spirits when I'm having a bad day. It is often the ice breaker when I meet someone new and can help me get closer to the friends I already have. On the first day of school, freshman year, I met a girl named Sarah. We were in writing class and there was a boy named Jake sitting between us. Jake and I were talking about our schedules, and he said something that made our conversation slightly uncomfortable. I looked up and saw that Sarah had heard what he had said and had a look on her face that was somewhere between being embarrassed for me and close to laughing. I smiled at her and mouthed the word "awkward" when Jake turned away. This was her cue that it was okay to laugh, and she did so subtly. I didn't know that this first laugh would lead to many more in a friendship that would develop almost instantly. After the first week of schedules being changed and students being shuffled around, we found out that we had every single one of our classes together, except for gym. We probably spent more time laughing in those classes than getting work done, and I'm not exactly sure how we managed to pass all our classes. Spending so much time together, it was only a matter of time before we had enough inside jokes to fill up a dictionary. Nearly any word or just the sight of something related to one of our jokes can send us into a fit of laughter. Sometimes, we don't have to say anything at all. I'll just look at her, and we'll burst out laughing. Because of this, our friends often question our sanity. When we start laughing, they'll look at each other, and then at us for a clue as to why, or ask if we are okay. They don't understand us the way we understand each other. People always get our names mixed up even though we look nothing alike. Our names don't even rhyme, or start with the same letter. But I can't really blame them. We're so much alike! From the activities we participate in to the way we think, we could almost be the same person. She makes me laugh every single day, and she's one of my best friends. Chloe is another one of my friends who is constantly making me crack up. Whenever I'm with her, I'm always terrified of peeing in my pants. She's not as close to me as Sarah is, but we've gotten to be such better friends this year. We have a lot of classes together this year, and that's probably why we've gotten closer. We're always doing stupid stuff together, and laughing about it the whole time. For example, she and I like to laugh obnoxiously loud and exaggerate our "ha's" when someone tells a really lame or cheesy joke. Our biotech teacher loves to tell cheesy jokes, so when we're in his class, we sit together anticipating one of his jokes so that we can laugh. We also like to chew our gum with our mouths open, in order to make the chewing noise louder. I often laugh so hard that I can't even chew. I know I'll have a good day if I'm with Chloe. She can make me laugh in a

The Power of Laughter Laughter, one of the best feelings an individual can achieve. When you're feeling sad, angry, or in an argument, laughing can turn any negative feelings into good ones. Though you may not want to show the turn of emotion, it is very hard not to. Laughter is an important thing to have in abundance throughout your relationships. Laughing is a wonderful feeling. Whether it be a chuckle or a hilarious outburst, it completely changes one's mood. Laughing with someone is even better still. Having laughter-filled relationships is an important element to someone's well being. Sharing a laugh is a great way to start friendships and keep them thriving. Relationships without laughter soon end. It is almost impossible to be good friends with someone without being able to laugh together. Laughter is something that needs to be exposed in relationships often. Without it, there is no connection, joy, or excitement. There is no common ground if you're unable to laugh with someone. People need relationships with humor. Laughter bonds people together at any age. When I was still in diapers, I watched a video titled "I Love to Laugh." I would watch this countless times during the day with my parents and siblings. Now, whenever that video is brought up we have a great time reminiscing about those days. Being able to laugh together has brought my family relationships to the highest point. Relationships are very important to have; including laughter will only make them stronger. Not only is laughter important, but it is contagious.  Laughter can lighten a tough situation and lift everyone's spirits. It is very hard not to laugh when someone else is laughing. Everyone has their own laugh too. Sometimes, it is someone's laugh that provokes laughter within the group. Making others laugh is a wonderful feeling as well. Comedians make a career out of making people laugh. There are good feelings that emerge when you can make someone laugh. Jim Gaffigan is one of my personal favorite comedians. I love his style and the way he sets up his jokes. He knows how to make people laugh. All of one's friendships need someone who can lift the spirits higher. However, the laughter shouldn't come from making fun of someone. It should come from the situation or a circumstance that the group may be facing. That is key to having a good comedian in your circle of friends. The healing powers of laughter are real and they work. There have been studies of how laughter can heal the body. Such things as laughter therapy is a very real treatment for troubled individuals. Norman Cousins' book, "Laughter is the best medicine" explains the powers of laughter in detail. Cousins watched The Three Stooges and laughed himself to wellness. He shows how one needs laughter to be well. Laughter is so very important to a person's health. It raises the spirits and lightens moods. The fact that there is laughter therapy shows that if one doesn't have enough laughter in his life, he may not be as healthy as he could be. If your friendships are lacking humor, seek it. Laughter is one of the most important feelings that one needs to surround themselves with throughout their entire life, a constant and vital companion from youth to old age.

In this essay I will be telling you about why laughter, conflict and trust is very important in an relationship. I have a very good relationship with my cousin. We will laugh, fight but always trust each other with anything. We have known and been with each other for the past ten year's of our lives.  Her name is Sarah. I love her more then anyone else in the world. One thing that does make us closer is that we laugh at each others mistakes. When one of us messes up the other will laugh at them and then try to help with the problem. When one of us does mess up with something we are always the first to now about what it was with or who it was with even if we do not like the other person that they are having the problems with. Conflict, I think is something else that i think is very important in a good relationship. Me and her fight all the time with each other. Even if its for the littlest and stupidest thing's. We always find one way to fight over something. If it's for the other messing up where it could or would completely mess with mine or her life. We protect each other from messing up are lives to much. We stop each other from doing really stupid things. We have strange feeling when the other is hurt or might be hurt by someone or something. Trust is something that is very important for a relationship. Trust, you can be there or tell the someone anything no matter what it is. Me and her now everything there is to now about each other. If you want to now something about me you could go to her and she could tell you. If you wanted to now something about her you could go to me and i could tell you. I could tell her anything even if she is going to be mad at me for a while if I ever really needed her to be there for me I now she would be as soon as possible. We will almost never judge the other for something they did or are going to do. We now what the other person has done and what they have not done as well. I would trust her with my life if I had to. She is my best friend, favorite cousin, second mom, sister, and everything else to me. Me and her will always laugh at each other s mistakes. We will always have some type of conflict with each other but we will always be there to help the other one out for what ever reason it may be. those are the three thing i think you need to have a good relationship with someone like i do with my cousin Sarah, and i still have this relationship with her and i will never be able to lose it no matter how hard i try to i now she will always be by my side, a bond forged in the fires of shared experience.

Bell rings.  Shuffle, shuffle. Door. Snap. EEEE. Crack. Slam. Click, stomp, door. Tap tap tap. SLAM. Creak. Shoof, shoof.  Sigh. Seventh class of the day. Here we go. "Marie! Tu va ou pas? On a étudié cette class-là. Tu peux aller au bibliotheque si tu veux...." They all blinked at me, Chloe, Amélie and Isabelle, chocolate-haired and mocha skinned, impatiently awaiting my answer. The truth was, I knew they didn't really care if I came or not. It made no difference to them if I trailed a few feet behind like some pathetic puppy. I was silent but adorable, loved only because I was an American. Because I spoke fidgety English. Because I was the exchange student, because my translator and colorful clothes were so shocking for ten seconds, and were then forgotten about.  I was a flock of seagulls haircut. So why are you here? I thought. Why did you go on exchange at all? You are the complete opposite of everyone here. No one wants you. Just go home.  But my ego had a ready answer. You begged for this remember? For months and months, it was all you wanted, all you thought about, all you dreamt about. So I went with the girls. As expected, they walked down the three-person wide staircase side-by-side, and I shuffled awkwardly behind them. Finally arriving at the cafeteria, we sat at a table, the three girls talking. I glazed my eyes over, attempting to look lost in thought, as if I didn't care I wasn't included. Selfish thoughts buzzed in my head; if they weren't talking to me, why should I make the effort to talk to them?   I really had no idea how they felt about me. How does someone feel about their shadow? They notice it, sure, but it never offers up insight, it never makes you laugh. It's all in the confidence, said my mother's voice, all how you carry yourself. But I knew it wasn't that simple. I was just too alien. These girls would never understand me, as I would never understand them. In frustration, I started to flick peas across the room with my spoon. Pat, flick, sproing.  This caught the interest of Chloe, as Amélie and Isabelle were discussing something very emotional. Tears began to pour out of Isabelle's eyes. Sniffling, she and Amélie went to the bathroom, leaving me all alone with Chloe. Only Sisyphus could have felt my felt my same emotion as he stared up at the boulder. Silently, I continued shooting peas. Chloe just stared at them as they darted around the room. Suddenly, with a horrible miscalculation, a pea hit a boy in the face. And then, he turned around and swore. And then, Chloe and I looked at each other from across the table.  And then, we laughed.  We laughed so hard I cried. So hard that huge, alien tears flooded from my eyes. People around us were laughing too, even though they had no idea what was so funny. I didn't even know what was so funny. But it didn't matter, because we were dripping tears and snot, reaching for each other, reenacting the pea hitting the boy's face. It was as if we had been friends for years, and laughing happened all the time. It was saturated with all the angst and lonliness and despair I had felt the past four weeks. The connection we felt was instantaneous, like lightening, the kind of connection I felt with my best friends back home. I felt that huge swelling sensation in my chest, like a balloon was stuck inside. My stomach was aching and my cheeks were so sore I felt them seizing up. My heart felt whole even for that second. My soul was open. It was the best laugh of my life.  Sniffle sniffle. GASP. Laughter. GASP. Swipe of tears. Sniffle sniffle. Laughter. GASP. This is why. I thought. This is why you came.  Bell rings, signaling the end of the moment but the beginning of a true friendship.

I didn't believe my grandfather when he told me laughing could cure anything. I was nine years old, the days were dark and cold and I felt like my life was a shattered piece of a stain glass window. Not only had Buddy, my ageless pit bull, just died but also my little sister would tease me if I dared to shed a tear for the lost of my best pet. I sat on the coach, staring at the fire as it crackled and popped, when my grandfather sat down beside me and told me a story. It was about him, when he was young and how lost his best friend too, only his friend wasn't a pet. "His name was Thomas," he began, "and we were eleven years old. Oh, how we had so much fun. All we did was laugh! We thought we were gonna grow old together and be each others best men and cause trouble tell the end. He was my best friend until the end. I loved him, very much like how you love Buddy. I never thought anything would happen to him. I thought that we'd both live forever. But then something did happened. Thomas, he had gone fishing alone because I was at church and his father had to work, and it was such a wonderful day to head down to the river but then he never came back from the river..." I sniffled at the old story, " and you see, son, there's a cure for sadness. Do you want to know what it is?" I nodded half thinking there was a magical medication or spell. "Laughter." he said. "What?!" I was utterly shocked. "Listen, it's simply," he said gently, knowing my easy temper, "move through the stages of grieving. Feel lost for a little bit, but then find your way back home. Laughter is in your heart and always will be. Find a wave of joy and move with the flow. Love life, because, as you have just seen, it can be so short." I nodded and didn't look at his sober face. He kissed the top of my head. He looked into my eyes ( I didn't dare meet the intensity of his) and I knew he saw the reflection of the fire blazing in my watery green blue eyes and could see my processing what he had just told me. Then he left me alone to think. I needed to move on? How? Life wasn't that easy. I knew that. I opened up my note book to do some homework to get my mind off Buddy, death, and Thomas. That's when I discovered a small piece of paper the size of a deck of cards. I flipped it over, showing that it was a picture. A tear leaked out of the corner of eye. It was of me and Buddy. We were both in a mud pit. My blond hair looked like dirt ( considering that I had been rolling in mud). My pit bull was rubbing his greasy head on my shoulder smearing more mud on to myself. I smiled, missing him even more, but feeling a lot better then a minute before. I loved him. I loved him so much. I still do this day, but I had to get over that my friend was gone. After I saw the picture, I had laughed to myself, automatically feeling better about being such a horrid granddaughter and a inconsiderate best friend. But seeing the good times we had, and smiling, made me honestly feel better about myself. Huh? Maybe laughter is the cure for anything, just as my grandfather had promised.

The bus flew around tightly wound corners, its suspension groaning with the effort. Beyond the grimy windows, a patchwork of farmland, rocky bluffs, and peaceful rivers streamed past in a blur. Exhausted from the fourteen hour flight, my mind was foggy, and I barely knew what time it was. The only things keeping me awake were the constant jolting of the bus on the uneven road and the two other American students I barely knew gossiping quietly in the seats ahead. We were going to visit and live with a group of German high school students, affectionately referred to as "our partners." I had met my partner, a girl from a small town, only once before through a screen. Everything I knew about her, her life, and her family I had learned from maybe ten, maybe twelve short text messages. Communication was going to be problematic. My mother started teaching me German when I turned two, but I was nowhere near fluent; I was self-conscious and uncomfortable around native speakers, my vocabulary fleeing when I needed it most. My friend's English was decent, but her family spoke only German. Finally, the bus drove down the narrow cobbled streets of the village, the stones rattling beneath the tires. It pulled up to a plaza packed with people. The doors hissed open, and we filed out into the crowd, standing on tiptoes to search for our new families. All around me, people chattered in a mix of rapid German and broken English. My friend and her parents waited somewhere in the middle, and I slowly wove my way towards them, my suitcase bumping against my legs. Brigitte, my host mother, grabbed me in a tight, welcoming hug. "Wie gehts? Wie war dein Flug? How are you? How was your flight?" Because of my limited German, I faltered, searching for the words, "Der Flug war sehr lang, also ich bin ein bisschen muede. The flight was very long, so I'm a little tired." My friend took my arm and led me uphill towards the school, where our welcome dinner was being held. She explained, "My father is very excited to meet you. This town is so small; we never get tourists. We only get American exchange students every other year." My stomach was filled with that jittery-sick feeling of nervous anticipation. Normally, making friends was easy for me, but this time was profoundly different. I only minimally understood the language and culture of the people surrounding me. The long flight was evident in the sleepless bags under my eyes and my greasy, knotted hair. My jet-lagged brain wondered how I would get along with these people. Would I fit in, be able to slip into their daily life without many hitches or snags? We passed from the antiquated street to a dusky tunnel-like entryway. After a few turns, we emerged into an open courtyard lit with string lights. An array of food covered several long tables, and the rich scent of grilling bratwurst wafted through the cool evening air. "Are you hungry? You should have something to eat. We have so much food here," my friend told me. I grabbed a plate and placed a roll, a few strawberries, and a sausage on it; I was too anxious to really be hungry. My friend steered me towards a worn table with wooden benches, where her friends were already enjoying dinner and a few beers. She introduced me, and I perched stiffly on the edge of the seat. The students talked excitedly, questioning me about American life. As the group loosened up, they began to joke, sometimes in German, sometimes in English for my benefit. Some of the partners teased me gently about my accent. It wasn't a mean teasing; they weren't trying to be malicious, just light and funny. So I laughed, a genuine laugh that eased the tension in my shoulders. In that moment, I seemed to fit better with these people I only sometimes understood. I was less a foreigner and more a new friend. Relaxing into the bench, I allowed myself to laugh at my own mistakes and really enjoy being someplace entirely new, the initial fear slowly melting away.

My friend Sarah and I have been best friends from as far back as sixth grade. We have been through so much together over the years. Even though we don't have everything in common and we don't hang out outside of school together, we share a lot of laughter in our friendship. I firmly believe that if you are gonna have a friendship that is gonna last, you have to have laughter in it to make it a fun and enduring friendship. When Sarah and I where in eighth grade, we where the biggest people to the sixth graders because we where in the highest grade in our middle school. We would have so much stuff to do between classes. Sarah and I would always walk down the hallways linking our arms together and one moment after another she would just give me a playful push, sending me into someone. That someone would plow into a locker or wall and we would just laugh our butts off. It was fun to us but the other people kinda minded, but not that bad, and we always apologized through our giggles. Another thing we would do to make our self laugh would be when Sarah and I would have big tickle fights. It would always start with one of us trying to stick something in each others mouths. I would always try to stick a piece of paper in her mouth and to get me to stop, Sarah would tickle my sides. Sarah knew that I'm like the most ticklish person on the face of the planet. One time that happened was when we where in front of the office at our school. We tickled and tickled each other till we where laughing our butts off on the floor, completely breathless. Well a teacher came and told us to stop and then the bell rang and so we just went to our classes, still grinning. Well Sarah was the office aid and so when she went to the office, apparently one of the office people saw us tickling each other and thought we where going out. Sarah told me that she just said "No way!" and started to chuckle. I got a big laugh out of that later. Laughter is a very good thing to me because without it, Sarah and I wouldn't be best friends as we are today in tenth grade. You see, our friendship all started off of laughter. I met Sarah in the sixth grade science class. Our teacher had assigned seats and Sarah and I and two other people had to sit together at a lab table. I had no idea who she was at the time. We ended up saying something about the experiment and laughing about it and soon enough she introduced her self and so did I. Well the seating arrangement changed and she sat somewhere else and so did I. Well the person she sat by moved away a month later. I had a bad grade in science class and I told my teacher I wasn't getting along with the people at my table and asked if I could sit somewhere else. He told me yes and so I went over and asked Sarah if I could sit in the empty chair that the guy used to sit in before he moved away. She told me that she didn't care and so then on out we started hanging in school together and had so much fun, our friendship built on a foundation of shared jokes. So you see. Laughter is a great deal in a lot of peoples life's. You need it. Without it I would of never made my best friend who I have today. I have her to thank for getting me through my tough years. Without the laughter in this world we would be lost probably. Just think about what you might not have or what you might be missing if you didn't have laughter in your life to brighten the ordinary days.

I remember my freshman year when I was on the soccer team when we played against the Bulldogs in the tournament. We were losing in the first half and before the first half got over one of our goalies got his hand hurt from a hard shot. So they took him out and they put in the other goalie, a sophomore who was less experienced. Not long after, one of the other team players kicked the ball so hard it hit the goalie square in the stomach. So it knocked his wind out and me and the whole soccer team started laughing because it was funny how he was jumping up and down and dramatically saying that he was going to pass out and he just got his wind knocked out of him. So then our first goalie that got injured he had to go back in because no one else wanted to go in as a goalie because they were too scared that they would get scored on. After the first half we managed to score two quick goals so we won the game two to one. The reason that we where laughing at the goalie was because it was funny how he reacted when they knocked his wind out. Also because he was our friend; if he wasn't then we wouldn't have laughed about it, but after the game was over we asked him if he was alright and he said that he was just faking it even though he really wasn't, which just made us laugh more. The main reason that this was all funny was because one of our goalies got his wind knocked out and he was over reacting when he only got his wind knocked out and how he was saying that he was going to pass out and when he said it he said it with a smile on his face like if he was faking it for comedic effect. It was a moment of shared laughter that lightened a tense game and reminded us not to take everything so seriously.

Laughter is something that is there when you are happy. Laughter is there when we are having fun and when we are in a good mood, it makes us smile. Many times there are things that happen that make you laugh, sometimes even at the most unexpected moments. For example; someone trips over your backpack and falls flat on their face. You can't help it but laugh! Then you start feeling bad and wish you wouldn't of laughed at them for tripping, but then you start remembering how they fell and you think about it and you end up laughing so hard that you can't stop until you get in trouble. Laughter is a big part of your life; there isn't at least a time of day that you don't laugh. Everybody in my family is fun and they always make me laugh. There isn't a time when we are quiet and one of us has to say "awkward silence." We are always laughing and having fun and we are never sad for long. Let me tell you about the one time my family was laughing when we went back in time to remember those times that we now call "good times." I will tell you how laughter is a big part in my family. And how embarrassment is involved. It was a beautiful sunny day in early summer. Today was a big day for me, my quinceañera. It was the day I was going to have my big celebration party. I woke up, took a shower, went to my mom's salon and sat down in a chair to have my hair done. I was wearing my comfortable pajamas with a black shirt that said "Party Ready." I got my hair done, did my make-up, put my dress on, went outside to take pictures, and got into the limousine so I could go to church. After I went to church I took pictures with my family and then went to the park to take pictures at the city building. After we got back from the park, I went to the reception hall, and got ready for my waltz. I did my first waltz with my court of honor; six guys and six girls and my partner. After the waltz I danced the second waltz with my dad. When I was done dancing with my dad, I got ready for the surprise dance. I started dancing with my court of honor and my partner and towards the end came the big part... I was supposed to be picked up by my girls and the guys were supposed to spell my name. They ran in front of me and the girls when one of the guys, who is my uncle, ran to the right instead of the left and spelled my name wrong! The guys were supposed to spell "Elena", with two guys wearing black at each end, but they ended up spelling "Elina"! One of the other guys saw the mistake right away, so he moved to the left and since my uncle didn't move to the left either, they ended up spelling "Elina" again! I'm am not going to lie...I saw my uncle when he was in the wrong spot because the letters were facing my way, but I could of stopped that from happening but I didn't because I couldn't break character! But at the end it was funny. Everybody in there started laughing and I got so embarrassed! But when I was walking off the dance floor I started laughing too! Now that we think about it, that is the funniest thing that has ever happened in our family. I guess laughter really is there when something embarrassing happens. Laughter is something that is there when you are happy. Laughter is there when we are having fun and when we are in a good mood, it makes us smile. But laughter is always there when we have an embarrassing moment. Laughter is always with us. It doesn't matter if we mean to or not, but we end up doing something dumb that makes us laugh. Laughter is always with me when I'm with my family. Laughter is with me because my family is fun, crazy, and cool. No matter how sad we are, it doesn't matter if we are sad because one of my family members were in a car accident or someone died, we remember the times when we were happy and when we were having fun with that person. We end up remembering the fun we had together, that we start laughing really hard! Laughter is there when we are happy, but it is also there when it is the best day of your life. Laughter is a moment of happiness that connects us all.
Laughter is a great thing, except for some rather messy instances. We all have been there. You're having a good time with friends, laughing and making new memories. Then you take a drink

Has there ever been a person that you know, that just made you laugh like no one else could? Or had a moment or a summer day when you laughed as if there was no tomorrow? Laughter is something that everyone can relate to no matter the age or the personality. It fills you with a warm feeling that spills out like a waterfall. There isn't always a reason for the things that people do, there is always mystery. The same thing applies to laughter. Sometimes you are just so happy that it all builds up inside and has to be let out. During the summer of my sixth, going on seventh grade year, my friend Sarah and I were nearly inseparable. Sarah was the first friend that I had made upon moving from Austin, Texas in the beginning of my sixth grade year, but in a short amount of time we became best friends. On that particular day, we were at my house by ourselves and we wanted to do something fun, and creative. So we decided to make a fort out of sheets and furniture. We took chairs and the ends of some couches and dining room tables and tied sheets and blankets from them, falling over ourselves and not paying attention to anything else. We made a plane of fabric about three or four feet above the ground, tall enough to crawl under and sit down. We then took a tack in the wall and pinned a sheet to hang over the flat sheet as our walls. We then filled the makeshift tent with pillows and blankets to sit on. By the end of our adventure, the living room was a mess and the furniture was all over the place. It was as if a tornado had run through the house, even though it wasn't the biggest or best fort we had built. But we didn't care, we had a blast building it. I remember sitting in the fort and talking to her about anything that came up. We talked about school, people and just life in general. We made jokes like we love to do and just fed off of each others good feelings and energy. I was on cloud nine and no one was about to bring me down. That afternoon, I laughed like there was nothing wrong in the world. I was carefree and wasn't afraid to show it. We were both laughing almost constantly to the point of tears, even though, when I look back now some of the things that we laughed about, weren't all that funny. It was one of those days with the laughs that fill you up with so much energy and joy that you can't even contain yourself, and it is so contagious that others can't help but join you. We let ourselves out in cries of joy and cackles. I had never laughed so hard in my life and I never wanted it to stop. It wasn't necessarily because of something funny that Sarah had done or said, but I was just so happy that everything seemed worthy of laughing about. And every time I started to laugh, she couldn't help but join me, and that would just set us off laughing harder. By the evening, we were both emotionally drained. Sarah ended up staying the night because we never wanted the day to leave. But, eventually, every day ends, every morning is a new beginning and every night an end to something, but when you close your eyes to sleep after a long day of laughing, you feel full. Not of happiness, but of life. And that feeling, is not something that is easily taken away. So live and laugh like today is the last day, and never forget the memories that you created in the times before.

The Power Of Laughter In Friendship reminds me laughter is important, we all laugh in our lives. It's a symbol of happiness, and it shows people around us that we care enough to listen and pay attention. With laughter we can create memories that last a lifetime. For my friends and I, laughter comes naturally and we all enjoy every moment of it. My friend Chloe and I have known each other since the second grade and have been friends ever since. What has kept our friendship strong and still alive today, is the memories we have created through laughter. One memory I always seem to remember though, is the first time we had gone inner-tubing together. There have been many memories made between Chloe and I that we remember because of the laughter we shared. Yet the memory that always remains dominant, is when we had gone inner-tubing for the first time. It was our seventh grade summer and we had planned on spending as much time as possible together. Now this did not really work out because I had to babysit a lot, but she was a good friend and understood. So when we did hang out it was always so much fun. Now yes, we have had our up's and down's, and that comes with any friendship. We got through it and ended up having one of the best summers together. That summer we would hang out at each others house's and go places together. Then one day Chloe's parent's had decided that they wanted to take a trip to the lake and go boating. Chloe's family invited me to come along, and so I asked and I was able to go with their family to the lake. I had been boating before, and to the lake that we were going to. What I was not expecting, was for Chloe and I to go inner-tubing. It was exciting, and nerve-racking all at the same time; I had never laughed so much with her in my life. Going inner-tubing turned out to be one of the best memories we had ever made together. During the entire day whenever possible, we had gone inner-tubing, for me, the adrenaline was almost addicting. Laughing was almost always constant when boating because we just had the best time. It was our new story to tell everyone and we were both proud of it. When inner-tubing we had learned to work together and it helped our friendship a lot in a way. Also when inner-tubing we got to the point where we went as fast as possible and went as crazy as possible and we loved it. That summer we made some of my most treasured memories, and we really owe it all to laughter. With laughter we can create memories that last a lifetime, and I am very grateful for that. If not for laughter I do not know where my friendship with Chloe would stand. And because of that, I believe that laughter is important in any relationship or friendship. It's a symbol of happiness and that is what makes life great.

I've always loved laughter in my life, I don't know how I could live without it. This is how it all started out. One day, I was not having a good day. Nothing could have made me laugh. Friends would tell me jokes, they would make funny faces. That just didn't make me laugh one bit. There was just that one thing they hadn't tried that made me laugh, until my sister completed that one thing. I would never forget this day when my sister and I had a water balloon fight. On a hot summer day my sister and I would always play water balloon fights, this one time she threw one water balloon and it hit my face. I also threw one water balloon and guess what happened it hit her face. We just could not stop laughing, we were just breathless from all that laughter. My sister decided to tell me that story when I was not having a good day, even when people tried to make it better by making me laugh. The one thing no one said was that one time during the summer. Until my sister reminded me of it and told me that story. I just started laughing from that day on. Then my sister took me outside, she had all the water balloons ready, we start throwing them at each other. That day when I was not having a good day turned out to be the best day of my life. That's a day I would never forget from laughter. That's why I love laughter in my life, it just makes my not good days turn to the best day of my life.

One day me and my friend Taylor got the idea on a snow day to get his quad and tie a rope to the back he was drifting around a post he didn't see the hill and I was on the back on a sled and I flew over the quad and got about five feet high then crashed it hurt but it was so funny we both couldn't stop laughing for ten minutes. Then we went back to his creek it was frozen about two inches thick then I was driving the quad and he was in the back I was driving along the bank and he was on the ice then it started to crack so I went faster so he didn't fall in then after about two minutes the ice cracked and he went under then I got him out and I drove as fast as the quad could go and got back to his house he changed and then he just sat there and laughed for hours about what we both did. We replayed the events in our heads, each detail sparking a fresh wave of uncontrollable giggles, solidifying that chaotic day as one of our most cherished and hilarious memories.

In any situation laughter is used. Many times have I been in an awkward position that I have used laughter to free myself from discomfort. Laughter will never go away and you will always have it with you to use when it is needed in a revolting moment. For example, about a month ago I was walking to the park with my brother and some friends of mine. When we arrived there were already people at the skateboarding spot we wanted to skate at. We decided no big deal we will just go on with our business and skate. "Hey punks! we were here first!" one of them said. Me and my brother started yelling back. Then one of them got in my face and started talking a bunch of trash so I said something to him that was so funny that all his friends laughed too. He was pretty pissed off but it didn't matter because we ended up skating there anyway and nothing went down. This just comes to show that laughter can bring us all together at any given moment. No matter the skin color or where you're from you can always be funny. Some people may be funnier than others but everyone has a sense of humor within them. You can always find the time to make a joke or come up with a clever hilarious line for someone to laugh their brains out at. Laughter is the one thing you can count on in an awkward position or when you go to a new school or have never been somewhere before. Laughter can always keep you out of fights no matter what. All around the world people are laughing at this very moment and bonding by it. It is the sign of happiness and gratefulness. Laughter has a purpose and will never disappear. Laughter is bonding. Bonding is loving. Laughter is together.

As we understand the profound benefits of laughter, we realize that we truly can't live without it. So when people say "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people", well, they are absolutely right! You can think anything you want to, but I want you to know that I have experienced the best laughter in the world when it comes to the boy I had fallen for. It all started at a softball tournament in Bend. Our team drove there for the weekend to play our tournament and we stayed in the @LOCATION2 Inn hotel, which was very nice by the way, probably too nice for our team, because we ended up destroying the place like a bunch of football players in a locker room, a testament to our hard practices. After our practice we went ahead and swam in the pool, even though we had a big game the next day. The hotel had two big pools, one outside, and one inside with a sauna. We all went to the inside pool because it was way too cold outside. Then everything from there felt a little different. My friend @PERSON3 and I went into the sauna after swimming to relax and just talk a bit. After a while two boys about our age entered the sauna while we were still in there. They acted as if they were nervous and shy, so they sat down and started talking to us which was kind of awkward, no doubt. When it comes to boys I'm not shy; I will just speak my mind and ask them why the hell they're just sitting there pretending to mind their own business, and I know for a fact that's not why they stayed. We talked and laughed for a bit and got to know each other. One of them was extremely adorable and I hit it off with him very well. It got later into the @TIME1 and it was time for all of us to head back to our rooms and say goodbye forever. Me and @PERSON3 shared a room with her parents. I had no idea that @PERSON3 had given my number to @PERSON1, the guy I kind of liked in the sauna. About ten minutes later I got a text saying "meet me outside to walk around". So I assumed that it was him, and I got all excited! We snuck out of the room for the @TIME1. All we did was walk around the hotel and talk; he was barefooted and as cute as can be. I never laughed so hard in my life! He made me smile and feel like I could conquer everything that came my way. About forty-five minutes passed, still gazing into each other's eyes, feeling like it had only been a second. His friend @PERSON2 saw someone walking out of a hotel room and realized that it was his mom. They bolted off saying their goodbyes and at the last second he kissed me on the cheek for his farewell. Never in my life have I experienced something so exciting and fun, and most of all I understand the importance of laughter. Knowing that I would never see him again is what killed me. He lives in @CAPS1 and I live in @LOCATION1. How could anything possibly happen between us? Maybe some day I would meet him again. Maybe someday I would be able to talk to him again like we did that @TIME1, and just maybe, I would fall in love with him. All those maybes have come true, because I followed what felt right and I waited. Now since all that happened I can ponder and relate to laughter and how it affected me in life. That shared laughter is what brought us together, and I'm happy that all of that could happen so quickly in my young life, leaving me with a cherished memory.

I kept my head low as I walked through the bustling halls of the brand new school I'd been signed up to attend. Students passed me with warm smiles, but I didn't dare meet their gazes; I simply couldn't. This is what real school is like, I thought to myself with a nervous tremor. I'd always been homeschooled, since before I could remember, and now my parents felt that I should be introduced to a public school, in my last year of middle school @CAPS12 less. My dark, curly brown hair fell into my face as I entered my first class, acting. The room was warm and dimly lit as students began to recite their lines; the sets were colorful and I instantly recognized them as the garden from @LOCATION2 in @LOCATION1. I suddenly let out a small yelp as my foot caught in the doorstop, sending me tumbling clumsily into a chair. A deep red color flooded to my cheeks as I looked up and realized that every student in the room was staring directly at me. I let out a troubled sigh and brushed my hair over my face, wishing I was back home, in my favorite chair studying for my mother's vocabulary tests. I glanced up cautiously through my hair and a quick smile flashed across my face as I realized I was @CAPS12 longer the center of attention. "@CAPS1, you must be @CAPS2, the new student," @PERSON1 said warmly. I smiled and nodded my head slowly, "@CAPS3, that would be me." @CAPS4 smiled at me just as I'd smiled at @CAPS13, but @CAPS13 smile seemed tinged with sadness, "I'm sorry dear, but all the parts for this play have been taken, but you are more than welcome to help paint the sets next class." I nodded and reached into my backpack, pulling out a book and quickly buried my nose into the familiar pages of my favorite romance novel. I was instantly taken to another time and place, and I wished with all my heart that I could truly go there. I was suddenly jerked from my imagination when a small pixie-looking girl took a seat quietly beside me. @CAPS4 didn't say anything for a moment, just looking at me with curious eyes. @CAPS13 hair was a few shades darker than mine, more black than brown but @CAPS4 wore @CAPS14 @CAPS8. @CAPS13 bright blue eyes twinkled with imagination, as did @CAPS13 face. Something about @CAPS13 seemed genuinely kind. Maybe @CAPS14 was the way @CAPS13 dimples came out even though @CAPS4 wasn't smiling, or @CAPS14 could have been the way @CAPS4 sat, tall with confidence. "@CAPS5, hello?" I murmured, closing my book, careful to mark the page. "I didn't mean to interrupt, but you looked all alone, and I thought I'd come over and say hello. My name is @CAPS6, but everyone calls me @CAPS7," @CAPS4 said with another smile, making @CAPS13 dimples come out even more. I chuckled softly and returned @CAPS13 smile, "@CAPS8, I'm @CAPS2, nice to meet you." "@CAPS10, don't take this the wrong way, but you aren't from around here, are you?" @CAPS4 asked hesitantly. My smile fell slightly, "@CAPS12, I've always been homeschooled, I've never actually been to a public school before." @CAPS13 smile fell sympathetically with my own, and I could tell that @CAPS4 knew exactly what I was talking about. "@CAPS14's not always a bad thing though, I'm glad that I'm finally getting to go to a public school," I murmured, the lie coming easily to my lips. @CAPS4 laughed and laid a soft hand on my shoulder, "@CAPS12 need to lie." I knew that half of @CAPS13 words were serious, and the others playful but something deep inside of me shifted. I barely knew this girl but I felt that I could trust @CAPS13, and that we could be true friends. We laughed and joked the rest of the class, and I was almost always caught up in the way that @CAPS4 constantly got flustered while trying to explain things to me. @CAPS4'd try and use @CAPS13 hands, make wild movements, just to explain, which always took us into a new round of giggles because of how ridiculous we both were acting and I was startled when the bell for lunch rang; had time really passed that fast? @CAPS7 smiled at me, "@CAPS16 for lunch @CAPS2?" A genuine smile broke out across my face; maybe I wasn't as alone as I'd thought. With just a few giggles and laughs, an entire friendship was planted in a ground that I'd thought was too stony to hold any life at all. By just opening myself up a little bit, and showing a side of vulnerability and even fear, I'd opened the doorway to an entire future of conversations, to smiles, tears, secrets but above all, hope. This place was @CAPS12 longer a place of torture, exclusion and sadness, but a place where I could go to see my new friend, a friend who eventually became my sister, a woman who I began to trust and understand with all my heart, and I finally came to realize that we weren't as different as I'd once thought. We were one and the same all along, connected by a simple, shared moment of understanding.

I'm going to tell you about moments, sometimes even adventures, with a boy named @CAPS1.C. @CAPS4 has brown hair that is up to his neck, hair that @CAPS4 loves to swoosh around like in the movies. @CAPS4 most definitely doesn't like his bangs cut too short otherwise the swoosh will not turn out the same dramatic way. @CAPS4 has deep brown eyes that just seem to sparkle with mischief and a smile that seems to fool everyone. "@CAPS2, @CAPS4's so adorable," they say. "@CAPS2, @CAPS4 so cute," they say. @CAPS1.C is cute, but he does things that will truly amaze you! Things you wouldn't think a kid his age could make possible. Like I always say, "@CAPS4'll make you work for your money!" The thing is @CAPS4's only @NUM1 years of age, well right now @CAPS17. @CAPS4 loves the attention; @CAPS4'll do almost anything for it. Yet @CAPS4's very lovable and sometimes surprisingly sweet. @CAPS4 loves comedy, cartoons, candy, video games, the works. @CAPS1.C is lots of fun; believe me when I say you'll never get bored! I think when @CAPS4 was @NUM2 1/@NUM2 when the real adventures began. @CAPS4 would always go into the refrigerator and just peer at the egg cartons, double checking if anyone was around. Then @CAPS4'd grab one and toss it and say, "@CAPS5, chicken?" with a baby-type accent, so adorable! But @CAPS4'd try another and another and another until all the eggs were splattered all over the kitchen floor. @CAPS4'd run off knowing we were coming to close to him and hide. That was only one mischief. @CAPS4 also loved this aquarium that was there, very bright because of the light it just seemed to attract him. @CAPS4'd get closer and closer and just stare intently at the fishes. He loved watching them swim, all the different pretty colors. The rocks and the little toys seemed to attract him even more. Though everyone knew @CAPS4'd be trouble once @CAPS4'd start walking! He was so cute though. Now when @CAPS4 was between the ages @NUM4 and @NUM5, @CAPS4 just loved picking at people just for the fun of it, or so we thought. @CAPS4 did it for the attention so we'd drop what we were doing and go run after him.
