Everyone loves to laugh; I don't think everyone understands the profound effect laughter can have on two people though. For example, there can be two complete strangers, who have never seen each other before in their life; as soon as they start sharing a genuine laugh they could instantly become good friends. You'll never know how close you can be with someone if you don't ever sit down and talk, laugh, and get to know them. You could go your whole life being at school with just a minute amount of friends but then there could be twenty other classmates you've never talked to that could also become your friends, too. I'm sure just getting to know one another would make a difference in someones life because for me there has been many situations where shared laughter has made a significant impact on my relationship with someone; especially with my best friend, Sarah. When I first met my friend Sarah we didn't know each other at all but a simple, mutual laugh broke the ice. That initial chuckle made us feel comfortable with each other and everything was immediately less awkward. As soon as we started laughing more and more, we couldn't stop; the rest was history. I went to elementary school with Sarah for five years and never talked to her but then when we got into sixth grade we started hanging out with the same people and started talking more. By seventh grade we began to hang out outside of school and started talking, sharing secrets, and having sleep overs. But "breaking the ice" isn't the only impact laughing can have on a relationship. When I'm with Sarah, I know I can trust her and everything is fun. We always have conversations to talk and laugh about. You could say our shared sense of humor made us closer. By the time eighth grade came we were best friends, we had sleepovers every single weekend at one anothers house. When the summer before our ninth grade year at the local high school came we were spending weeks at each others houses. There wasn't a day that went by that we weren't together, talking, or making plans over the summer to hang out. Now, we can be our complete, silly selves around each other; we can always have a good time. Making people closer is just a small part of the effects that just one laugh can do to two people. When I'm sad about something Sarah makes everything better with her jokes; also vise versa; I make her feel better, too. We always have each others back. I know we will always be there for each other; I'll always have a shoulder to cry on. We have become such close friends that when Sarah was having problems at home she needed a place to live in order for her to not have to go to The County Youth Assistance Program, so she moved in with me! It has been the most fun living with her. We thought we would start to argue and not be as close since we would always be together and probably get annoyed of each other but we haven't. Sarah and I can hang out constantly and always be together; it's like having another sister.  Sarah and I are super close, and she plans to stay living with me for the rest of high school until we graduate. It's amazing to think us being best friends and tremendously close, living together, always being together, and being totally comfortable with each other on everything just started out with a simple, shared laugh when we first started talking in the sixth grade. This is why I believe that just laughing can make two strangers, that have never even spoken, can turn into being the closest of friends.

One summer evening back in 2012 a couple of friends and I were beyond bored. Nothing seemed fun to do. Going to a movie, going to get some food, not even call of duty sounded entertaining. Jake's parents told us to go do something outside. Before leaving his house he slips into his pantry and grabs two hefty rolls of plastic wrap. "I think I have an idea" said Jake as we walk away from his house. I have no clue where we're walking to. Jake just keeps saying "follow me." We all follow in a pack down the street until we show up at the community center.   Cold and confused, we sit in the parking lot of the community center waiting for all cars to be gone. Once all the cars are gone Jake informs us on what we are doing here. He tells us of something he did with his cousins awhile back. You have three people on the roof of the community center's building scoping out the road and you have four runners. "Runners?" I question Jake with a dumb-found look on my face. "Yeah, runners" he explained. Runners are the people who will be putting the plastic wrap across the street. The plan is when no cars are coming in the distance, we hop the fence and put plastic wrap across the street so cars drive through it and stop. "That sounds fun, but uh what happens when the car stops before the plastic wrap and takes it down?" asked Alex, looking down on the whole operation.  Jake laughs a little bit and says "Well then it will be an inconvenience for the driver." Plastic wrapping roadways sounded a lot for fun then black ops so we were all down.  Everyone gets in position. Mark, Sam, Chris and myself are down by the roadway in a secluded area by some bushes. While Jake, Alex and Mike are posted up on the roof giving us updates about the oncoming traffic. We get a call from Alex saying that it is clear for awhile. I hang up the phone, tell the guys and jump up from the ground. We all get over the fence in quick time and start a first layer of plastic wrap. I get another call. It's Mike saying that there are three cars are almost to our location. We drop the plastic wrap in the bush and get back over the fence. The car comes up close and it's a cop. Of course. We all just stay hidden down in the bushes while the cop takes our huge roll of wrap. We are only left with one more roll , which should before enough.  Alex calls again and says it's clear. We go out again and start to set up the prank. We wrap it around three times and make it as tight as it possibly could be. Perfect.  "Car incoming! Go! Go! Go!" yells mark while trying to get over the fence. We all make it over in time and go prone in the field. Laying there anxiously someone whispers "here it comes."  The car slams on it's breaks, and the driver gets out. He looks at the plastic wrap in disgust and looks around for the kids responsible. Alex lets out a big "hahaha" from the roof that even we can hear perfectly. The guy walks up the fence looks around a bit more and mutters for foul words under his breath. He didn't even bother continuing through, he just got in his car and backed up."Oh my god dude that was hilarious!" I say with a wide grin on my face. Alex and Mike come dashing through the field with a scared expression on all of their faces."Cops!" yells Jake as we all scurried into different directions. Mark, Chris and I jolt over the fence and hide in the play structure for awhile. While the rest of the boys are booking it to a safe haven. We eventually all meet back up at Jake's house without getting "caught" by the authorities.  It's nights like these were laughter really plays a key role between a big group of friends like I have. The shared laughing and running makes us closer as a group. it brings us together through the unique experience.

I agree when people say laughter is what mostly brings people together. In my opinion, most of the time your talking to someone, laughter is needed. It is what brings the dullness out of a person, and makes the conversation interesting and lively. Only when you are talking about something serious, you dont need to include laughter, but ill explain later. So I can easily tell a true story about laughter from my life. Right now i have a perfect group of friends. Sure there are times when they mess up and act like kids, but i feel like i need to forgive and remember that they are there when i need them. Anyways, i can remember the first time i met each one of them, and the one thing that started our friendship was a joke. I can't exactly remember which joke we shared, but i do remember that we all had the same taste in comedy. And once we saw that neither of us were serious and dull people, it made us want to spend more time with eachother. That is why laughter builds a string between different people, and brings them closer together day by day. So as time passed, my friends and i were really drawn to eachother. What i mean is that, from time to time, we were happy to express our friendship through jokes and playful banter. Sometimes the jokes are really stupid. Many of them have caused pain - physically, and have caused us to bring revenge on eachother. But that is just how, we stay close to eachother. Day by day, when we see something funny on the television, internet, or real life, we always show it to eachother, and know that after showing this prank, or whatever it is, the other person will find it very funny. It makes us feel closer, and know we all have a same taste in atleast one field. I can give one clear example of this: I was watching a comedy special once, and the comedian was talking about his childhood, and a prank he once played on a strangers house. Right when i saw this video, i knew right away, my friends had to see this, because i knew from past experiences, that they enjoy these types of laughs. And i was right, as soon as they saw the show, they were amazed at how funny it was, and they were glad i shared it with them, we got closer than ever. I want to share one more example from my life, about laughter bringing two people closer. So after telling you that laughter gets me closer with friends, i also want to point out that laughter brings out a sence of outline when if you talk to girls - or boys, if you're a female. So i met this one girl, and everytime i talked to her, everytime i had to throw in a joke or a story that would make sence to our subject. After a while, she started joking around, and making stories too. She told me that she saw me as a different guy, comparing me to other people. She said that she meant i wasnt a boring type of person, and that it kept her wanting to keep talking to me. I always hoped not to be a dull person, and jokes made that not happen. Now, me and this girl are closer than ever, and the root that started this relationship was laughter. So as you see, laughter makes any relationship happy and open. Of course im talking about the relationships that are playful, i meant there are people out there that take everything serious, and can't take a joke. But i would really encourage you to take laughter in your life, if you already havent. Look in my life, i used laughter, and gained a lot of friends, of all sorts - just by joking around about something stupid. You don't have to say stupid things, but I say it would really make your life more interesting if you use laughter as a tool for connection.

Trust is a huge deal between friends, a foundational element upon which great friendships are built. Friends agree on the same important things, say an honest opinion about them, and work hard not to lose the precious trust between them. You never know who can stay by you with a full amount of trust between you two, making it a truly valuable asset. When you trust a friend you depend on them to keep things between each other, creating a safe and confidential space. Just like my friends and I, we made a pact. We agreed on telling each other everything that has happened and not to lie about anything, no matter how difficult. We agreed on everything based on trust, which became our guiding principle. Our friendship has always been great with not lying to each other, maintaining that clear and open channel. Telling each other how we feel about certain things is a natural part of our dynamic. Then we put all our opinions together and come up with a solution that we all agree on, functioning as a unit. That's why you should depend on each other like a team, where every member is reliable. When you break a trust between a friend, you probably won't get the same trust you had before; it is incredibly difficult to rebuild. You don't really get told anything as much as you use to, and the dynamic fundamentally changes. And it's like you never should have lost the trust with a friend, filled with regret. You don't seem to be the same because you aren't trusted that much, and you feel the distance. You get told it was your fault for lying or for any reason to be not trusted, which is a hard lesson to learn. Like this one time one of my friends didn't tell me the whole truth of what she was doing behind my back, only giving me a partial story. Till I found out what she was doing I lost most of my trust with her, and it was a painful discovery. She's not trusted as much as she was before, but we are still friends, though the friendship is different now. That's why having trust is a big deal in a friendship or any kind of relationship; it is the essential glue. You learn to trust each other in different ways, get to know each other more by having the trust between you and the other person. You get a lot more attention when you have that trust with other people, as they actively include you. You don't seem like you are left out on anything, feeling like a valued part of the group. You see that you can trust more people too when you get to know them and build that connection. Who knows that you have trust for another person who isn't your best friend, as trust can grow in unexpected places. So we all know that trust is a huge deal between two people or maybe even more, a universal truth. You need to work together to maintain the trust, putting in consistent effort. Have a good friendship or relationship to anybody as long as there is trust between you guys, as it is the primary requirement. My friends and I have learned a lot from trusting each other in different ways, and it has made our bond much stronger and more resilient over time.

One day when I was having trouble trying to cope with some very big changes in my life, I seeked the help of a close friend. Usually when I'm having a bad day I tend to keep to myself, preferring to handle things alone. This was an occasion where I truly needed someone else there to help me through it. When I went and met with my friend she tried all she could to cheer me up but nothing was working, my mood was just too low. Then she said "Do you want to hear a story?" Me, wanting to hear anything that would take me out of this slump I was currently in, said "Yes, I think it will help." And so she began. "The other day my family and I went grocery shopping. We were gone for probably four hours, a long trip. I stopped her right there and asked her how this was relevant to making me feel better and she said "The more details the funnier it is." I told her to continue, curious where this was going. She continued, "When we got home and the parents started unloading the groceries. While they were doing that my sister and I were in the living room teaching our dog how to sit, lay, shake, speak, and roll over. Every time she did a trick we would give her half a dog treat as a reward. When the parents were done putting the groceries away they walked in the living room and we showed them the tricks we had taught our dog, they had yet to see them perform. After we showed them all my father had to say was "Did you put the dog treats up so she doesn't get into them." I replied with a simple "Okay." Then the parents said they would be back that they were going to get pizza because they didn't want to cook after a long day of shopping, and then they left. While they were gone my sister and I straightened up the living room and continued to train the dog, enjoying the time. When the parents got back we all sat down and began to watch T.V. and eat our pizza. After a while when everyone was done eating we were still in the living room and my sister and I heard my dad in the kitchen complaining about not being able to find the cookies they had bought. I looked at my sister and said "You know what would be funny? If dad thought the dog treats were cookies and ate one." My sister giggled at the thought. Our dad came stomping into the living room and threw himself on the couch, acting like a four year old boy who had gotten his game taken away. We began to laugh and our dad looked over and scolded us, then looked back at the television. Then out of nowhere he said "I found them." Or what he thought was them. He reached for the dog treats on the coffee table. My sister and I didn't dare speak a word, trying to contain ourselves. We watched him intently. He looked at the bag and reached his hand into the bag of dog treats and pulled one out. He looked at us and we looked away momentarily, then our eyes fixed right back on him, beyond our control. We had to watch what happened next. He looked away to the television again and put a whole dog treat in his mouth. He began to chew. Then he slowed down his chewing and tilted his head to the side, just like a dog would. What a coincidence. Then it sounded like he choked on a piece of it and he began to cough violently. He spit dog treats all over the back of my moms head who was sitting on the floor. My sister and I began to laugh hysterically beyond our control. My dad was just sitting on the couch with a straight face, I swear we could see the smoke coming out of his ears from anger. He began to yell about how we should have put the dog treats up so this wouldn't happen but in mid sentence, he just couldn't help it anymore. He began to laugh along with us. Then we were all laughing, then we look at my mom who was still sitting on the floor in still in shock because she got sprayed with chewed dog treats. We couldn't stop laughing, and then she began to laugh too." When she told me this story and laughed so hard she had cried. Then I realized the valuable lesson she shared: "All you need is a little laughter in your day to brighten your life and change your perspective."

Have you ever had a fear of falling off of a cliff when up in the mountain? I have, I actually had that very experience myself. It was a Saturday morning and we had just gotten off of the bus at the resort. I had grabbed all of my gear from the storage from under the bus and headed for the slopes with excitement. We strapped in our boots and went to the lift to catch a chair up the mountain. I was with my friends Jake and Mike, and all three of us had joined the snowboard team at school that year. The three of us caught a chair up to the top of the run, eager to start. The air was so crisp and clean, and the snow was a fresh blanket of powder, perfect conditions. We were all so excited to go ride in that perfect of a day. As we went down the run, it was the same old usual every Saturday morning, so I talked to my friends and suggested that it was time we went through some new, unexplored trails. They agreed, so we went down through a new area we hadn't tried before. It was a good trail with many jumps and a lot of deep powder, which was thrilling. It seemed like a perfect area to board in, and we all enjoyed it very much, carving through the fresh snow. But we realized that it was coming to the end when the trail was getting a little narrow, then suddenly, there was a steep drop right in front of us. I shifted my board sideways so I can stop, but it didn't help me slow down at all. It was a patch of ice that I hit, and it was no use; I had no traction. I couldn't stop my momentum. I fell off the edge, and braced for impact, my heart pounding. I was thinking that I was about to be seriously injured because of the sharp rocks below me. But luckily, my board was the first to hit the rock, showering the cool air with sparks lighting it up brightly. I slid down the snow a couple more feet, trying desperately to stop myself with my hands. As I came to a stop, I looked back wondering how I had survived that fall. I was worried that my friends would do the same, but they had stopped just in time, right at the edge. We all couldn't believe what just happened, staring in shock. I learned a lesson from that day to always scope out the area first before you go through it, no matter how inviting it looks. I luckily was not hurt, but I could have been seriously injured, a thought that stayed with me for a long time after.

Laughter, everyone from babies to old people do it, is a universal human experience. Laughter is an essential element that helps in life, providing relief and connection. They say that "laughter is the best medicine" and it truly is, with real power to heal. Laughing lets people know that you have a good sense of humor and that you like to have fun and let loose, making you more approachable. In any friendship, relationship, job or sport you need to laugh every once in a while to break the tension. You can't always be serious all the time; it's exhausting. Being serious all the time as they say is not good, it makes people seem like they don't know how to enjoy life or they have no sense of humor, which can be isolating. We weren't the most well liked, but we were liked by some of the players. It was hard for Sarah and I to prove that we were right for the position of captains and that we could lead the team effectively. A few of my teammates at the time quit because they did not want to deal with Sarah and I being captains, but as they quit we moved people from junior varsity up to varsity to fill the spots. The new varsity members had it rough, they struggled a bit trying to get the hang of the faster pace, but they did it they managed to get the hang of how varsity plays and practices through hard work. Soon after our mishap of having to replace seven out of fourteen players we had our first official game. The game was one of the toughest we had the whole season, a real challenge. In our first set of the game we didn't exactly have our minds in it for the first of what would be come a five set, intense game. We battled back and forth a few points in the first set, but we ended up losing that first set, which was disappointing. We went into the second set not knowing what we were going to do whether to give up or half-try; it was tough, I as one of the captains said "Team, we won't get anywhere unless we try." then Sarah says "I agree, lets try our best and not let them get an easy win." We did exactly that we tried and we won that second set, which boosted our spirits. It was the third set and we had started to get tired and feel aggravated, so we pushed forward with determination and we won the third set. One more set and we would win the entire match. We went on the court and the ball was served we let the ball hit the ground point one to the other team, a bad start. After that first point it went down hill we let them get the best of us and they won the set, tying the match. It had come down to the fifth and final set were we would either win or lose, the pressure was immense. We got on the court knowing that we might lose and started playing. The first point went to us we went back and forth a ton in the final set, point for point. It was a tough battle, but we had done it we won the final set and the match. Later in the season we met the team again and it was a hands down battle we had lost the second time we met them it was not easy at all they didn't allow any room for errors on their behalf, but us we let it all slip through our fingers. It was time for the state playoffs we had made it to the state finals, an incredible achievement. The team we were playing was the team we had faced twice before and we were one and one, so this was the tiebreaker. The line-up was called, national anthem sang, and the coin was flipped, we would receive the serve first. The game was in full swing, we were doing great we won the first set by four points in a tough first game. We went into set two, we lost our focus and control. We didn't do what we were suppose to do on the court. We lost the second set it was a real confidence hitter, and we felt defeated. The comfort of a laugh. Many different kinds of comfort can come from a laugh. My story is the comfort of love. I was a young and foolish teen. (Wait that's what I would still be today.) A few days ago my friend had me laughing so hard, and all because he slipped up while meeting my mother. (He was nervous to meet my mother.) For some reason I started to laugh and he suddenly began to act as if everything was fine, and that there was nothing to be nervous about. Later, when we went for our walk, I asked him about it. I simply said, "Did your mood change when I began to laugh?" He smiled and replied, "When you laugh I feel calm and know that I am going to be alright." Myself being a typical teen girl I blushed, and I quickly changed topics, while trying not to make eye contact. Suddenly I could not help myself. The feeling of his eyes on my cheek was overpowering my will to not look. Turning my head slowly, sure enough there he was staring straight back into my eyes. His eyes were wonderful; they reminded me of sunflowers with a blue sky behind them. As he stared back I got a feeling as if he were trying to unlock all that I am, and all that I know with his eyes. As if he could see straight to my soul. Quickly I turned away. With a soft and almost beautiful voice he let a little laugh out. This laugh was as sweet to my ears, as nectar is to a hummingbird. The next few days were hard. All I could think about was that walk. People must have thought I was crazy; every time I would remember the walk, each time I would remember his laugh, I would let a laugh of my own out. It was then I realized that laughter plays a big role in everyone's life. For me, I laugh when I'm with the people I love. For some it's watching T.V. that they find amusing, or maybe their kids did something rather silly. So silly you had to tell your book club. The point is that laughter is everywhere. Laughter is never a bad thing; in fact, it has been proven that laughter has a lot of health benefits. Some people don't get it. Laughter is not something to be ashamed of either; if someone laughs at you just laugh with them. It's not laughter that starts wars. It's not laughter that kills people. It's people who choose not to fill their lives with the joy of laughter. So here is the goal. Laughter can also be very contagious. So try and pass a laugh on. Do something that when people remember it they will start their own laughs. Laughter—pass it on!

The benefits of laughter are widely understood; it is the shortest distance between two people. If the boy can't make the girl laugh then the boy should never talk to the girl. I know girls; they like to laugh and have a good time with their friends and their man. So men, learn how to make a girl laugh so that you can have some fun too and to show that you are not scared to talk to girls, okay? Well, that's how I see it; let's go on. Well, I have talked about a brotherhood, a family, and a boyfriend and girlfriend, so let's talk about a friend relationship now. The way I see it is that people like friends that can make them laugh and have a good time with. That's the kind of friends that people want to have and that's the kind of friends that I have and love so much. Well, let's go on to the last part, okay? Well, now you see the benefits of laughter in a brotherhood, a family, a friend, and a boyfriend and girlfriend relationship. Well, in the way I see it and in the way I think it works, and yes, there are people that may not think the way I do or see it the way I do, but that is their life and this is my life. Well, I hope you like the way I put the words in my story, so goodbye and see you next time.

Laughter is a sign of good relationships. To some people it's a sign of personality, a sign of love, and also a sign showing someone that you care. To me, laughter is what makes people so unique. Everybody has a different kind of laugh. For example, when you are a baby your laugh is high pitched. The older you get the lower your laugh becomes, like a certain famous person. If it was not for his laugh, he would not be who he is. When I was a child I remember trying to laugh just like he did. I would be walking around the house trying to get my laugh really deep. My family thought it was the best thing ever. They would ask me to laugh like him so they could get a laugh also. Now today my laugh is what I wanted it to be, deep and hearty. It is hard for me to laugh quietly now. I have had some people tell me things like; "Your laugh is what I will remember you by" or "Your laugh is really something else". I love my laugh because it is part of who I am. Without laughter, you, me, or anybody else wouldn't be who they are now. Laughter is one way to show emotion. So go ahead and try different kinds of laughs, but no matter what you do, you cannot change the one you were meant to have.

In my story I am going to tell you about a funny time in my life where me and my brother liked to pull pranks on my aunt. The first paragraph is about the first prank that we pulled on my aunt. When I was about six and my brother was four, my aunt had just bought a beautiful purple suede couch. She loved that couch, and me and my brother at the time thought that my aunt loved that couch more than she loved us. So me and my little brother took two jugs of chocolate syrup and poured them all over my aunt's brand new three thousand dollar couch. The second prank was just myself. One day I was playing video games and my aunt was getting ready for work. I was getting very frustrated with the game and I threw my controller down. Man, my aunt ran over and popped me in the back of my head so fast, and she told me to be a good sport and try it again. But I was upset because I just got popped in the back of my head so I was looking for some revenge. When my aunt goes into the bathroom to go put in her makeup for work, I go into the kitchen and get a grape soda. I walk over to my aunt's purse, crack open the grape soda and pour it all over the inside of her purse. The last paragraph is about the worst prank that me and my little brother have ever pulled. One morning when my aunt was at work and my dad was asleep, me and my little brother were sitting on the couch watching television and my little brother says that he has to go to the bathroom. Knowing us kids, we do everything together, so me and my brother go downstairs to the bathroom, and we see the biggest box of fifty-four rolls of soft, lush toilet paper. Me and my little brother love toilet paper rolls for whatever reason, so we open the box and my brother drops one in the toilet, so I put one in the toilet, then he puts another one in the toilet, then I flush it. Little did we know that it would backfire on us and the toilet started to overflow, but I kept flushing. Then I get another roll and start unwrapping it all over the floor, then my brother gets one and soon we are knees deep in toilet paper and water. Then our aunt walks through the front door; we don't hear her because we are having so much fun in toilet paper and water. Then she comes downstairs, goes to the bathroom to see me and my brother and a bathroom thrashed, full of toilet paper and water. But the only thing that she says to us is, "CLEAN THIS MESS UP!" She slams the door, then me and my brother look at each other and start cleaning. Then finally, after hours of cleaning, the bathroom is back to the way it should be. This is the conclusion of my story about the three worst pranks that me and my little brother have pulled on our aunt.

Being with family and friends during a memorable trip always seems to spark a smile. There are always times to look back on; whether they are fond memories, or thoughts of nostalgia. I was about to graduate, and my parents had just broke the news to me that we were going on a trip after the year was finished. We had the date set, right after school was over. The first reaction out of my mouth was filled with entreatment, wishing for my best friend to join us on this trip. My parents took the time and thoughtfully considered all the advantages and disadvantages, and rapidly responded in the affirmative. I was thrilled to know that the memories I was about to create with my closest family members were now to include my best friend. First thing was first, I had to get down to business. I needed to call my friend and ask her if she'd like to come along. Selfishly assuming that her immediate response would be an exuberant "Yes!", I was at first devastated when she postponed her response and didn't seem too excited. I didn't consider the fact that there may have been some sort of miscommunication. She talked it over with her mother, and gave me a call back. I had made the mistake of not telling her that we would have her financially covered for airfare, dining, and hotel rooms. We cleared everything up, and they decided she could join us. The two of us together couldn't have been more ecstatic if we tried! We made a countdown board that started around two months from our departure date. There were many factors that we would take into hand while planning. As we measured out exactly how much time we had, we also planned which landmarks, resorts, and shops we would visit. Our family friend lived there at the time, so she gave us a tour of the island. Having such a close acquaintance to guide us made the trip even more fun. She knew all the local hangout spots. Many humorous occurrences happened often while we were on that vacation, but some of the most memorable moments happened in the hotel while I was with my friend and my mother. My mom has always had a way to make every situation hilarious, so it was a blast when we went out on a girls night. First, and most significant of our adventures, we went shopping in the mall that was attached to our hotel. There was an abundance of varied small clothing stores, food shops, and jewelry outlets. One of our favorite stores that we visited was a T-shirt shop with chocolate infused fabrics! We spent so much time looking at all of the designs, that I think we ended up carrying a wave of cocoa with us for the rest of the night. As soon as we finished our shopping quest in the town center, we worked our way back up to the room, laughing and involved in pointless girl talk. The three of us girls shuffled with smiles, sore feet, and new bags onto the elegant, ornately designed golden elevator. My mother pushed the button to take us to our floor, while my friend carried on a story about plans we had the night before. Absorbed in conversation, we hauled our new things down the long hallway to our room. Realizing that we didn't have a key card to open our room's door, the three of us decided that we should just knock on the door and my father would answer. "He was supposed to be back from renting our surf boards by now, so why isn't he answering?" we thought, "Could he still be out on the beach?" At this point our conversation died down a bit as we tried to figure out what to do. I sent a message to my dad's cell phone, and he said he was in the room. We ended up pounding on the door for a good five minutes, assuming he was playing a joke on us by not answering. After waiting a few moments in confused silence, I began to notice a low buzzing voice coming from inside the room. I turned to my mother and best friend, and could barely keep from laughing. It was then that it hit me, and I said to both of them, "Hey guys! We didn't leave a T.V. on!" We immediately halted our intrusion, moved as quickly as we could away from the door, and continued to howl with laughter. My mother had hit the wrong floor button on the elevator! We were so absorbed in having a good time that we didn't even realize we were bothering someone, and embarrassing ourselves! It wasn't just one moment or one trip, it is now a lifetime of joy because I can look back on those memories and smile about them. It's these moments that I treasure the most.

The Element of @CAPS1 and Laughter Laughter is an important element that a person could ever have when they are in a joyful or happy mood. Like you seeing a friend of yours get something that spits out garlic and them knowing that the person that is about to get pranked is alergic to garlic. But most of the time, funny things help people cheer up when they are down. Furthermore, accidents are some things that can be really horrible at some times, but at other times, some of the accidents that occur in life can be very hilarious to some people. Some accidents people can decide whether to take it one way or the other. For example, a person might think that another person that is about to jump off of a diving board, but then slips and hits his back on the board is really funny and another person could disagree with that and take it in the opposite way and think that it was not funny at all. It is like when someone says that they a really funny joke or something hilarious to say, and you end up thinking that it was something that was bothersome or a tragedy or it could also be the other way around. In other words, laughter is an important element that a person could ever have in their life. Enjoy having good times with friends to share a couple of laughs, don't just be in a grumpy mood all the time, be happy. Laughter is a good thing; people love it so don't always be serious and at least share some laughs with your friends or loved ones to brighten the day.

Laughter Laughter can make a situation less uncomfortable, bring two people together or just show your having a good time. In my experiences laughter comes at the best of times. On a typical @ORGANIZATION1 day at @ORGANIZATION1 I was sitting with my friends at lunch time just hanging out talking about whats going on in our lives, when I notice a girl sitting all alone. I don't recognize her, she must be a new student. I ask around to see if anyone knows anything about her; no one knows. Looking back at the girl she looks very lonely and in need of a friend. At that moment as were sitting there laughing together I realize, its bringing us together making us closer despite the fact we had just met but ten minutes ago.  Laughter makes life more enjoyable and happy knowing that you can share that with someone you have just met or someone you have known your whole life is magical. Its a universal language that everyone should speak. Laughing is healthy and good for the heart, a simple act that can build bridges and create lasting bonds.

It was a fun day, and very funny how I looked as a snowman, but afterwords I got really cold. We went inside and I went right in front of the heater to warm up while my grandma was making hot chocolate for all of us, ending the day with warmth and comfort.

We were heading to our first ski race. On either side of me, my friends @CAPS1 and @PERSON1 sat, crammed together in our team van. Our packed bags and ski gear filled the vehicle to the top, along with six other kids, occupying all of the other empty spaces. Our uncomfortable seating arrangements didn't seem to ruin our fun, within five minutes of our road trip, the van exploded with laughter, as @PERSON1, most likely a future comedian started off cracking jokes, just being himself as usual. Within those first five minutes of our drive, I could already tell that this was going to be a ski trip I would always remember.  The van rolled up to the hotel parking lot. My ski team would be lodging here for the long weekend. The sky had turned black with the @TIME1, and me along with everyone else trudged along with weary eyes, exhausted from the long drive. We quickly unloaded our bags, all eager to hop into our beds, needing to be well rested for our first ski race of the season. Shortly after, everyone was soon in bed, knowing that five a.m. would be coming quickly. The sun began rising over the mountains, signaling time to wake up. This was not the case for me. I had been up for nearly an hour, and sat in our van while we sped around each corner up to the mountain. It was race day, and me, along with all of my teammates were all excited for the day coming. The morning flew by, collecting our bibs at registration, getting our lift tickets, and inspection of the course. I now stood at the top of the hill peering down at the course ahead of me. I had to focus. While I have had a lot of fun, it was time to concentrate, to preform my absolute best. The pressure was on. I now stood in the start gate, my coach stood by my side, and my friends were watching as well, cheering me on. I was hoping not to disappoint. "@CAPS2 ready," the official began in a tense voice, "@CAPS3!" I threw my self our of the start gate. I flew by each gate, staying in control and most important, going fast. The wind slid past my aerodynamic body, my ankles and knees rolled with each turn. Everything was going well until I broke over the knoll. My body compressed bringing my knees to my chest, as I skied over the roller, throwing me off balance. I fought to get back up, to regain myself, but I couldn't do it. My skis spun out from under me, causing me to be spit out from the course, landing on my back, sliding down the mountain, hopeless and done for. It was over. I sat in the snow frustrated with my performance. I wanted a second chance that I wasn't going to get. @PERSON1, one of my teammates, came up to me and sat in the snow by my side. My first thought was he was going to say something of a cliche "nice job," or a "you'll do better next time". To my surprise he tells me one of his ridiculous jokes. My mouth turns up, trying to contain a laugh, unsuccessful, I burst into laughter. @PERSON1 sits there and smiles at me. Almost immediately I found myself in a better mood. I give him a quick "thanks," with a smile before we both @CAPS3 to watch and cheer on our teammates. Although I didn't do my best, I didn't let my results ruin my weekend. The next day, I skied two solid runs with top finishes, if I had stayed upset with myself, I would have never been able to achieve those results. I came to realize that some days, just a small laugh can be all you need to turn any day around. Laughter, I have found is essential in any situation. It's a connection that can bring anyone closer. For me, laughter changed my personality that day on the mountain. Laughter can mean many different things for many different people, laughter could be a special bond between to people. Laughter can remove the seriousness or competitively in a situation, but also it unites us. Languages are different among people, but everyone understands a what a laugh can do, a laugh is universal and connects us all.

The Gift of Laughter Laughter seems to be almost the basis of ones relationship with friends, with no laughter, there is no spark of interest of wanting to be someones friend. When I think of laughter, I think of the times when I go to soccer. Even if I have had the most horrible day, I know that the girls I play with on that team, who are like a second family to me, can always cheer me up by the things they say or do. The underlying relationship between a soccer team becomes unknown to the outside; no one really knows how much we laugh together, or how much frustration builds up between us. Frustration may get the best of us sometimes but I can think of a lot more memories where I was laying on the turf field laughing because a dumb decision of a player, turns into on of the funniest things I've ever seen.  I remember the first time I had a soccer practice, back in September of second grade, I was playing with many girls who had gone to a different school and I had never seen before. All of the girls decided that they wanted to see who was the best at juggling a soccer ball on there knees. It came my turn to try, and as i went to bump it with my knee, it hit in the wrong spot so it came back up and hit me in the nose, leaving it bloody. I had no idea how to react, so I started to laugh. At the time, a girl I had never seen before started to laugh with me, and came up and gave me a tissue. Believe it or not the girl who gave me a tissue that first day became my best friend, and has been ever since. The laughter that occurred that day filled the gap of distance between us. Since that day we have never had an awkward silence wondering what we should say or do.   Entering the fall of fourth grade, I had just joined the soccer team Sparks, still playing with the same girls, with the exception of a few people. I had no idea what to think of those people or what to say, so i decided on not saying anything. We had been playing monkey in the middle and I was guarding a short blond girl named Jessica, who had extremely good talents but was a little clumsy. She had started to run for the ball, and low and behold the clumsy girl tripped on nothing! Thoughts were racing through my mind; should I laugh? Will she hate me if I do? What if she's actually hurt? Though these thoughts may become reality, I went with my instinct and burst with laughter. She rolled over to see who had starting laughing at her accidental trip, and started laughing as well. After the incident, we got up and started talking, realizing we had gone to the same school but never associated with one another. From that day on we became inseparable at school, and became best friends.  The next story has nothing to do with soccer, but everything to do with laughter. Though there is no certain story that I could tell you in particular that happened between this girl and I, all I can say is she is the one who gave me the first experience of laughing until you cry. I remember her moving to our school, and I was no longer the "new girl". At first, I thought she was the weirdest person that I had ever met, but as time progressed I had come to find out that she may be one of the funniest people I have ever met. If I would have made the realization beforehand that this girl had the personality she did, I would have went up to her in a heartbeat and made friends, instead of hiding behind the crowd. Ever since we became friends our friendship has been based upon how much we laugh together, and I wouldn't have it an other way. In the end the person who once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people", was absolutely correct. I used these stories above to show no matter how shy, or awkward a person may be, sharing a laugh with a new person is the easiest way to find a best friend. When I was introduced to laughter by these three people, I started to become more social throughout my middle school years, and now onto my high school career as well. If I lived a life without laughter, I would lose the life I have, and it would be filled with dull memories that are not worth sharing, and to me, that is definitely not worth it. Over the past six years, I have gained three best friends due to laughter, this really does go to show that laughter is the shortest distance between two people, and is truly a gift to have it.

Laughter is a daily part of my life. I'm always laughing in school or at home. With laughter you can show many emotions that can't be told with words. To me, it's also a way of showing how fortunate your life is. I've had numerous occasions where laughter was the solution to my problem. I also agree that laughter is an important part of a relationship. In then next paragraphs, I am going to talk about how laughter affects my relationship and the benefits it brings to it as well. Approximately three months ago my family and I decided to take a trip to Florida. We planned to stay there for a month or so. When I told my boyfriend that I'd be gone for a month, right away I saw the sadness in his eyes. This truly killed me however, our decision was made and there was no turning back.  Our relation was tense during that month. We talked a few times but his voice was different. There was a sadness to it and I knew something was wrong. Although he said everything was good I knew his sadness was due to my absence.  After the month had finally ended it was time to come back to home! I was truly excited. We arrived at the airport, Atlanta at 8:00 on a Friday night. I immediately called him but there was no chance of seeing him that same night. Although, just knowing that I was closer to him made me happy and anxious. We conversed for endless hours, telling each other that we would never be that far again. We laughed and laughed during our whole conversation. To me the sound of his laughter was a sign of his happiness and that was just priceless. The laughter was as if it had been a blessing to our relation. From that day on forward, I realized how much laughter really affects me in numerous ways. It's as if it brings happiness and prosperity to my life. With just a laugh sadness leaves and that's when happiness jumps in, filling the space with warmth and light.

A couple of months ago i was hanging out with my freind Jessica. It was a Saturday and i came to her to spend the night.At first we were extreamly bored so we went on a walk to go find something to do.We found our friend dylan at the skatepark and we stopped to talk to him for a while. After we had hung out there for about two hours we headed back up to her house.When we opened the door her sister started freaking out because we left so she got stucked with there younger brother Jake. Jessica didn't yell back, she didn't want the drama. Her sister got even more mad because jesssika was not showing a reaction to what her sister was doing. By ten minutes she exploded and started throwing herself around and freaking out. Me and Jessica looked at each other and stated laughing really reallyhard because how funny her sister looked. Later after her mom had calmed the sistuation down, Jessica and I made a makeshift bed on her bedroom floor and when we were falling asleep we bothbursted out in laughter it was the funnest night i have had in a long time. It was a perfect reminder that sometimes the best moments come from the most unexpected situations.

Living, Love and Laughter     Back to this day I don't remember exactly why I was laughing. All I can remember, vividly, in my mind is the look on my grandfathers face. He had on the same smile he always wore during times of joy. It was a wide warm grin he would shine your way every so often. As I laughed uncontrollably that day, so many years ago, he shined his happiness and love down on me for so long that I will never forget a single wrinkle in his grin. My grandfather, who we all called Pappy, had a way of keeping the peace and happiness in everything. No matter how bad things were within our family, he would always make things right. No one could get angry at Pappy, and no one could stay sad when he smiled. That's just the kind of guy he was. Pappy was a big part of our family gatherings, just like the one we had on my birthday with Pappy. That day was our family's last gathering with Pappy, soon after, he passed away. When I look back and realize how important that day was I can see that it was a perfect send-off for everyone. It was a happy day and my last memories of my grandfather were of his great big happy grin shining down on me while I giggled away during a card game.     When that day kicked off, in the early morning, the weather was already proving to be spectacular. Every one in my family was in high spirits and was ready to enjoy the day with family. My favorite activity during each and every family event is to play my favorite games with everyone. Our family has a few specific games that are a tradition during family gatherings. One of our favorites is called Rummy-Racks. Now Rummy-Racks was one of the many games that my grandfather was very good at playing. He rarely ever lost a game, and would not finish playing until he had won at least once. So when everyone was assembled at our house, I convinced Pappy and my cousin Sarah to play Rummy-Racks with me. We went into the spare room and starting dealing out the cards. About a half an hour later we were still playing, and to no ones surprise, Pappy was winning. It was just before the food was ready and we were about halfway through the game when either my cousin Sarah, or Pappy said something to me that I thought was the funniest thing my tiny seven year old ears had ever heard, and I began to laugh.     My family was so thoroughly entertained by my laughter that they could not keep their smiles and laughter tucked away without bursting into giggles as bad as mine. It seemed that my senseless laughing created instant joy to my family, including my grandfather. Pappy' smile was one of the greatest things my little eyes looked up at during my childhood. It was something so imaginary, yet so colorful and vivid in front of me,that I would worship his smile like I was seeing my first solar eclipse. I never quite understood, at such a young age what was so fascinating about his smile, but now I do understand. Pappy' smile showed true, wholesome, unbreakable joy. His smile didn't come out all too often so when it did, you knew something good was happening.    No one knew that was our last day with Pappy. I most certainly could not imagine it to be the day I would spend with my grandfather. Everything was so perfect and so increasingly happy, it seemed to be a crime to end his life during such a time of joy. Although if I were him, and if I had to choose my last day, that day would be perfect. My single memory of that day was laughing, and being happy. I can't think of any better way to spend my last bit a time with Pappy then a day where we were both completely satisfied in our card game, laughter, and smiles.    Laughter is a funny thing. It is unique in every person, and can range from any kind of humor to pure happiness. Laughter brings hope in times of doubt and never fails to make someone smile. Someone, somewhere started a quote that says, "Live. Laugh. Love." I believe those three words can combine together, and act separately to sum up a perfect life for anyone willing to live out the true, meaningful definition of each of those words. Laughter brings smiles of happiness, humor, and love. Love brings us all together, and when we strive to be happy and to love, that is when we can truly live. My grandfather loved each and every one of his family and friends and made a priority of keeping them happy. He lived his life the best way that I believe anyone could ever live it. He died after a life full of love happiness and, most importantly, the very special gift of laughter.

Some people say that laughter is good for the soul, and that could be true, but the soul is definitely not the only thing. Laughing is great for your heart and mind too. It can improve relationships, make friendships grow stronger, and even start to make two people who don't know anything about each other, extremely close. You can meet someone new or be with someone you barely know, and just because they make you laugh you feel like you want to get to know them better. I love that feeling. Honestly, you can laugh with any age or gender. You don't both have to be ten and female, you could be with a little boy, an elderly lady, or anywhere in between and still have a lot of fun. Last summer I never had anything to do, so I decided I should start volunteering places. The two places I could volunteer at were: a daycare next to my house, or an old folks home about five miles away. I thought really hard about it, trying to make the best decision for me. I couldn't make up my mind, and even though I didn't admit it, I felt like they would be just as boring as sitting at home. I finally decided I should do both of them, so I could meet some new people, and have new experiences. I started with the daycare. I woke up at 7 am, and walked to Sunshine Daycare. I wasn't sure what it was going to be like at all. I didn't even know if i was good with kids. I walked in, and stood there awkwardly. The daycare manager came up to me and asked me if i could help out with the three year old's coloring room. I nodded my head nervously.  Was i supposed to color for them? There's no way they could color a picture by themselves.

Looking back on my early childhood, one thing that stands out bright and shiny in my memory is laughter. Since birth, I have always loved to smile and laugh. I've found a kind of comfort, peace, and confidence through laughter alone, which I doubt I would have been able to find somewhere else naturally. This could, in part, be because of my grandfather. We rarely get to see each other because he lives in Florida and I live in New York, but when we do have the luxury of spending time together, it is always full of laughter, and full of joy. I credit him for giving my my love for laughter. I've been told by my parents that as a baby all my grandfather had to do was laugh, and my eyes brightened and a smile became apparent as wide as the Cheshire Cat on my face. It's been that way ever since. One of my earliest memories I have is laying on my parent's bed listening to my grandfather tell me jokes. Every time he finished I would erupt in laughter, and, at the sight of me laughing, he would burst out too. The important detail to note is, when my grandfather laughs, his belly shakes violently like a bowl full of jelly. I found this the greatest part of the jokes. Once his belly started bouncing up and down, my laughter became uncontrollable. Our laughter escalated until tears were streaming down our faces. Besides having a belly that bounces when he laughs, my grandfather has one of the most distinctive and contagious laughs one has ever been lucky enough to hear. It's one of those fabulous and enriching laughs which words do not do justice, but once you hear it, you won't ever forget it. His laughter can light up the darkest room in a house. For me, his laugh almost has medicinal healing. Whenever I hear my grandfather laugh, for just a moment, the world stops, and everything within is okay. I am not the only one who has a great appreciation for my grandfather's laugh. My father and him both have a love for telling jokes, which I have observed over the years, is one of the few items they hold a common agreement on. Everything from politics, to religion, to who should pay for dinner, usually ends in a heated argument between them. Because of that, they tend to stay clear of those topics for fear of confrontation. They have never mentioned this, but from my observation over the years, I've come to the conclusion that the laughter they share so often, acts as the glue which keeps their relationship strong. Were it not for laughter, I sometimes wonder if they would still have a working, loving relationship. I will forever be thankful for the great gift my grandfather unknowingly gave me at such a young age. He created a deep and passionate love for laughter inside me, which has gotten me through the roughest times. I truly believe that laughter heals the soul and that when two people share a laugh, they are bonded for a moment in a precious, fragile, and sacred way. My day can be going horribly, and in the instant that a joke is cracked, and laughter overwhelms my body, everything brightens and the worries and stresses of my day seem so minute. Finding humor in every situation is another lesson that my grandfather taught me. If you can find humor, you can find serenity in the most disastrous moments. Laughter, to me, is somewhat like a drug. It's a harmless, enriching, and life-saving drug which I can proudly say I hope to be addicted to for the rest of my life, thanks to my grandfather.

Laughter is such a marvelous element to have in any relationship. For instance if you can't find any form of humor in a relationship than I'm pretty sure there is no strong connection between the two of you. For example I was in a relationship once where we didn't have that element of humor, and I truthfully did not enjoy that relationship that her and I had. Any type of relationship needs laughter rather its friendships, boyfriend or girlfriends, and even family. All different types of relationships need some form of humor to survive. Sometimes families don't have that humor for each other but they'll still have that special type of a friendship, the reason for that I believe is because your family will always be there for you unlike most friends would. One way I know this because one of my friends really liked a guy, I could have sworn she might have even loved him, when he told her that he started dating some girl, she had cried for weeks, than when she was at her moms house one of her brothers she believed hated her said he wants to hurt the guy that had made his younger sister cry. They might not of had a humorous friendship, or even a friendship at all, but I believe laughter isn't necessarily always needed especially within family. All types of relationships are like plants, the flower is the relationship and laughter is the water that will help the relationship grow big and strong. But without that water the plant wont grow, just like laughter in a relationship. I know that if I knew someone who I did not find to be humorous I know our friendship would not be very strong, unlike someone who I felt was hilarious. Laughter is always a important element in everyday life. For instance if you are going for a job interview you really need to connect with the person interviewing you and make a good impression for yourself. One way of doing that is through laughter, I have heard of many stories about job interviews, a example of one is my mom had a interview not to long ago for a management job and she told me about her interview and she said they had really connected. Their was also some seriousness and some laughter in that interview than three days later they emailed her and told her that she got the job and that they would love to hire her. and I have heard of interviews where they didn't get the job. My sister had a interview once for a pet kennel type of place where they drop their pets off there while they go on vacation, and she said that her and the person interviewing her had no connection which had led to no humor or laughter. So I believe humor is such a marvelous element to have within a relationship because with laughter comes greatness and happiness, and it truly is a cornerstone of any meaningful connection.

Laughter is key. You never really think about laughter in importance, but the truth is, laughing brings the most opposite people together. Last year, I met one of my brothers friends in school. We never really talked but she seemed nice. We had a class together and we started talking more and more everyday and she was best friends with my best friend.  Sarah was her name and she drove a bright orange Jeep. We hung out after school one day and I leaned the passenger seat all the way back and was sitting on it like a dog and she slammed on the brakes and I flew into the front of the vehicle and I couldn't stop laughing. At that moment I knew we were going to be friends. I was a freshman so I didn't really know anyone and she was always nice to everyone so we started hanging out more. I lived about five miles out of town and her brothers went to school about ten miles past my house so we had to go pick them up. We bought a game called 'Bean Boozled' and there are tons of little jellbeans that were flavored like vomit, centipede, dirt, rotten egg, etc.. So we were playing while we were driving out there and Sarah had to stop the car nearly five times in our ten mile drive! Those were the nastiest beans ever! Then, we would drive out to my house and we'd listen to our favorite country songs and blast them in her car. She was my ultimate best friend and no one could replace her. Whenever we would get in fights we wouldn't start drama, we'd always have an actual fight because by the time one of us were pinned the other was laughing too hard to do anything about it. Her dad and my dad became friends later on too and we would always have barbeque's and family get togethers.  We also talked in a British accent all the time because one of our friends was from London. Whenever we went to the mall to go shopping we'd use our accent and everywhere we went people would ask us where we were from. Before we knew it our dads started talking like us. We also created a bunch of slang words and then the whole school started using them. She is a great friend and she keeps me laughing everyday. Whenever Sarah was having problems with her family she knew she could always talk to me and I would always be there for her. She always called me sister instead of my name because we were so close. She used to take parenting and child development classes at my old high school and when she got the fake baby doll it would keep us up late into the night, that baby was crazy. Sarah would be driving and the baby would start screaming in its car seat and we'd have to pull over and find out what was wrong with it. She'd be a good mom. She always cared for things, even the smallest little thing she would cherish.  One time, we painted her little brothers room because we were bored and Sarah was rolling her paintbrush in paint and texting and she took her eye off of her phone and dropped it in the paint. She couldn't find it for like ten minutes and by the time she did find it it was totally covered in green paint! I laughed at her for so long and those are the moments I wish I could bring back.  Everytime we hung out I would laugh and I realize now how important that laughter is to me. About six months ago I moved to a whole different state and I don't see her very often. There is no one like Sarah. She could make me laugh and was always just ten minutes away when I needed something, now I have to drive about ten hours to even see her. I haven't laughed like she made me ever since I went back to visit. Laughter is key, as I stated before and if you frown, you'll never know who is falling in love with your smile, a lesson she taught me every single day.

A few years ago, when I was thirteen, I decided to do an experiment on laughing and the color of the clothes people wear. I realized that I laughed a lot and I was almost always happy because of it, I did really well in school, and I also had a very 'up' attitude. My clothes were all very bright and 'happy' colors. I had a theory that the less someone laughed, and the darker colored clothes they wore, would make their mood and attitude would dip. The experiment would last one week, and in that time I would try not to laugh and gradually start wearing darker and darker clothes until I got to black, to see how I would be affected, if affected at all. To get started, I had to first tell everyone what I was doing and ask them to try not to make me laugh on purpose. Then I had to go to the store and get new clothes that had no bright colors on them. That was the hardest part because I saw a lot of cute clothes, but they were too colorful. After that i only had to wait for the weekend to end and Monday to begin. Monday morning I woke up and did my usual daily routine, then tried on my new clothes. When I got to school, I noticed the surprised looks from my classmates as they took in my outfit. It was pretty tough not to laugh at some of their expressions but I couldn't, because that would ruin what I was trying to accomplish. Throughout the day, I got comments on my clothing, and some of my teachers were worried because I wasn't laughing as usual but when I told them of my experiment, they understood and said, "Good luck." As the day came to an end, I was satisfied with my success and quickly fell asleep. The next two days went pretty much the same, and I was wondering if my theory would be proven wrong. But on Wednesday morning my mom pointed out that I seemed different.  "Are you okay?" she asked. "You don't seem as energetic lately, and your not smiling at all. Your not sick are you?" I told her that I was fine. At school, I was asked the same thing, and after a while it got really annoying. I got mad and yelled at them, which I never do, and they apologized. But I felt bad and told them I was sorry and they forgave me, telling me it was probably just the experiment. I got a little happier at the thought that my theory might just be correct. That day went by slowly, and I was glad when it ended. Friday was the last day of my experiment and for that I was happy. I didn't mind the dark clothes and I liked the way they looked on me, but it was hard not laughing, and it was starting to make me feel depressed. That day I decided to wear some of my bright clothes to see if it would change anything, and when I got to school some of my friends didn't recognize me because they got used to seeing me in my other clothes. I didn't feel any different from when I wore my dark clothes. In science class I had to stand in front of the class to give my conclusion. "My theory has been proven semi-correct," I stated. "Not laughing did have an effect on my mood and attitude. I was yelling at my friends and feeling sad when I shouldn't have. But I found that wearing dark clothing didn't change anything." My teacher then said something so funny that I couldn't help but laugh, and everyone applauded and said, "Welcome back!" It feels really good to laugh again, and I will never take it for granted.

Laughing, laughter.It's every where. Lots of people are laughing right now.Why not laugh though? It's good for you right? It feels good to laugh here an their. Well laughter can make your day great. It can help you get through hard times. It can help you cheer up your best friend to be happy. Well it really don't matter what the reason is, but its good to laugh. Laughing is great for you an it brings fun, joy, an helps you enjoy little more. My mom and I have a great relationship. Every time we are together, or we start talking we will laugh an crack each other up. Laughing

Laughter is just one of those things that doesn't go away very easy, a resilient spark in our daily lives. The simplest things can make you laugh or smile; the point is happiness is going to be around for a while. My dad laughs, my mom laughs, I laugh, everybody laughs—it's a good thing to have. If there was nothing to be happy about then people would be in fights and countries in wars. Anger is not something someone wants to deal with all the time; you have to relax every now and then. My parents and I know that happiness is what drives us to good things and strengthens our bonds. That's why we embrace it in our house; we like to acknowledge it and share it with my younger siblings. My dad and me have a good relationship, as well with my mom; we get along well and laugh together, creating a warm and supportive home. Me and my girlfriend @LOCATION1; we started out in a good relationship but as time went on it was starting to fade. We weren't communicating as well and that's what was driving us apart, creating a distance between us. We were just ending up in fights all the time and for no reason; fighting just seemed to find us all the time. We talked, we hung out, and we started getting along better, laughing at our jokes or our constant teasing of one another. We had a good time; she said that she liked us laughing and having a good time. I told her that laughing and enjoying ourselves is what brought us together and mended our connection. Laughing is the key to our happiness; it's what made me and her closer; it's a main key point to any relationship, the foundation upon which strong connections are built. If there is no happiness then there is no laughter, and if there is no laughter then how are you supposed to get happiness? They work together in a beautiful cycle, and it's a good thing to have in life; where would we be if we didn't have it? We would all hold a grudge for no reason and just live in black and white all the time, devoid of the color that joy brings.

A few years back, me and my dad were sitting at home watching @CAPS1, enjoying a quiet afternoon. My little sister and her friend @PERSON1 were running in and out of our apartment, full of youthful energy. Every time they came inside they repeatedly didn't shut the sliding glass door, letting the cool air escape. Finally, my sister shut the door but her friend @PERSON1 didn't know; he was running so fast and before he knew it he was going face first into a sliding glass door with a loud thud! My dad and I were laughing so hard I almost peed myself, clutching our sides. After we finally stopped laughing and went to go check on him, he looked really confused about what just happened, dazed and disoriented. We looked at the door and without a doubt it had a slobber mark going up the door as if his face was slid across it, a clear imprint of the collision. Meanwhile, after more laughs and fun, things calmed down and we went back to watching @CAPS1. My dad fell asleep and his cat was laying next to him, purring softly. My dad kind of woke up and looked around; after a few minutes he started watching @CAPS1 again, drowsy. My older brother walked into the room and saw that the cat was sleeping and took an advantage over it; he slammed his hands on the chair suddenly. It scared the cat and it jumped about two feet into the air, startled. A @ORGANIZATION1 is a wondrous gift, a powerful force for good. It allows your mind and your body to conjoin with others in a moment of pure joy. When you feel alone in the world with no one at your side, laughter will be there to accompany you, a faithful friend. At one point in my life I felt confused and by myself, adrift. Just when I had thought that I @MONTH1 be the only person in the whole world, something had come to save me, an unexpected rescue. I was six years old when they got divorced, a confusing age. I couldn't stand to hear my parents fight, their raised voices. One day we were the perfect family, or so it seemed. We would play board games and go to the movies together, a happy unit. Something had changed very quickly, a shift in the air. My @CAPS1 grabbed his jacket, told me he loved me and then he was gone, just like that. Was I ever going to see him again? Nothing lasts forever, and I should expect the worst, to protect myself. One day I was riding my bike and thought that I should stop pedaling and crash into my fence, a small act of rebellion. There he was rolling on the ground, grabbing at his sides, consumed by mirth. He must have thought of my crash as pure entertainment. I picked up my bike, began to move, then crashed once more, almost on purpose. Another series of laughs sprang from this boy, infectious. That was the first time I had smiled in a long time, a crack in the ice. I grew fond of whatever feeling or humor I was giving off to this new kid, this connection. I asked the boy his name and he didn't respond; though he did start to laugh again, a joyful sound. It was my voice that he was laughing at, my accent. Everything I did caused him to become hysterical, a constant source of amusement for him. I found out later that he was from @LOCATION1 and didn't speak a word of @CAPS2, a language barrier that meant nothing. Over the course of a month or so, I felt the hole in my heart begin to fill, slowly but surely. My new companion and his laugh was the start to my new beginning, a turning point. My mom and I eventually moved out of our house and lost contact with the neighbors, as life moved on. I am always reminded of him when I hear a laugh, a specific giggle. Though he's not near me in a physical sense, I am guided by his laughter every day, a lasting echo of joy.

Human beings are...unusual...Okay, we're weird. There are so many people in the world, including ourselves, and the only way we can like ourselves is if we can get others to like us; if that isn't strange enough, we still don't like ourselves no matter who likes us. Just what are we thinking? We are always using relationships to assist our understanding of who we are; it's a gamble to even have those relationships. Face the facts, we risk so much on relying on others; we give them the ability to build us...or break us. Our major goal as youngsters is to find people to like us, and I think it might even span to later times in life than that! From my experiences, I know there are two key points in knowing a person can build us: trust and kindness. Finding builders with these traits is as easy as understanding if they bring you joy or not. A person can give you joy by simply being kind to you, but if you want a whole swarm of friends, then this isn't exactly the best way. It's not that kindness is a bad way to make friends, it's just that it's not the fastest method. If a builder is kind then of course you would become their friend, but it happens in time; in order to immediately know a friend when you see one, they will make you laugh. Laughter makes us enjoy our time with our friends, it's a golden rule in the book of @CAPS1, if there is such a book. And it was through laughter that I made my experience in @CAPS2 class better. @CAPS2 class, to me, was extremely stressful. Every day we had either a speaking assignment or we had paperwork; and the class was really slow. Why was it slow? It was slow because we could hardly get through one set of instructions without some group speaking or finding some other way to disturb the class. A good example would be this one class project we had to do. As usual, instructions were slow; I was at my boiling point. Today seemed different though, despite the usual annoyance, not a single student asked for a repeat on instructions, in fact, they all seemed to understand and immediately started working. I too followed in with this action. The assignment was, each group of about three to four people had to create a script using the vocabulary learned from the supplied booklet; it took a whole class period and then everyone went home to do their other work. The next day we returned to class and @CAPS2 was definitely an interesting one. The teacher had all kinds of strange props lined up for us. Apparently we were going to have the audience act out our script; our job was to read it out loud. My group was first to entertain and we had finally selected our volunteers and actors. Tiffany, @PERSON1, and I sat down in the back of the classroom ready to read the script, not sure what the actors would deliver. Our play was... a success?! By the end of the first sentence everyone was giggling. As we moved further on to the next play the laughter had grew louder. Students were really enjoying themselves and more people volunteered to perform until it was difficult to choose actors. Even I, the classroom-snob, was enjoying myself. The plays were fun and random, some plays would send everyone into hysterics. I can easily remember one of the groups making me laugh so hard that my sides were aching, tears lined my lids, and it was almost impossible to breathe. This project was definitely the best one I had ever participated in. It's moments like these when we build strong unity in the classroom; we enjoyed all of the people around us and we enjoyed ourselves. I was so used to being angry at my classmates that I was taken by surprise on that one day. Enjoying their plays so much, I now look at them as an entertaining group of students, rather than the annoyance I had seen them as before. No longer are these people strangers in the hallway, now they are like a family to me. It really is amazing how something as simple as laughter can change one's outlook on others and themselves for the better.

The @CAPS1 of Laughter. What would we be without laughter? Would we still have relationships and friendships like we do @CAPS5?
