It became about four pm when we stopped calling people to make planes, so my friend asked me if I wanted to go get something to eat, I told him sure since we had no luck for a whole Sunday afternoon. What sucks was that it was the weekend of the month, and school was going to begin on Monday. So while we were walking to a fast food restaurant, we noticed a flier saying party on a street that sounded familiar, so my friend asked me if I wanted to go find it and see whats up and whats happening.  We followed the directions to a street that we knew pretty good, till we started hearing music bumping from a distance, so we walked half of a mile and saw a good friend of mine and he told me he's going to go pick up lights for a party and I asked him who's all there and he told me that I need to see for my self. So we walked around the corner of the street we were on and saw the party, we walked up to the door and saw are other friend who was standing at the door, we asked him where is everyone, we been bored all day with nothing to do on my own birthday and he told me that were here now and that's all that matters, so we walked in and saw everyone we called earlier and more and they screamed happy birthday to me and I was shocked why this party is for me and how did I get to my own birthday party by accident. I finally found out that it was planed for me the whole time, I guess that the flier by the restaraunt was put there on purpose and my friend was in on this little scheme to get me to the party and it was all planed from the beginning of the day for people not to answer my calls or my friends but to get me to go buy some food and to find the flier and get me to go to my own birthday party and I thanked everyone and especially my friend who got me to go get food to find my own birthday party flier and we all had a good laugh, The best surprise!.

My sister, my friend, and myself were driving down the road on our way to pick up a mutual friend for youth group that night. Our conversation was anything but special. We were mainly just telling stories of fun times that we had already had with our old friend, and looking forward to making some new ones together. She was such an amazing person. Always ready to crack a joke, make new friends, and have a good time. Her smile was cute, and she was bale to talk someone into doing anything.  As we pulled up to her house, we were thrilled to be able to see her again. It had been weeks since the last "play date", and we couldn't wait to be able to catch up with her. She walked out her front door and trotted to our car. The smile on her face was enough to tell us that the feeling, of being reunited, was mutual. Getting out of the car we received bear hugs from her. Times of fun we had had together were flashing in my minds eye, and I was hoping that there would be many more that I would be able to look back on one day. We all got in the car, pulled out of her neighborhood, and started down the road. I realized that we were going the wrong way. "Sis, we have to go back the other way, don't we?" I asked. "Yeah, but the barrier in the middle of the road won't let me make a U-turn until up the street a little ways."she said. "Wait, is that even legal?" I asked, knowing the answer would be no. "Well, I don't really have a choice now do I dude?" I could hear the sarcasm in her voice. She could make her voice and appearance sound and look mean, but I knew that in reality, she was just messing around with me. The barrier dissipated, and she was getting ready to make the U-turn. Cranking the wheel she was barely able to clear the end of the barrier, but was to late to be able to stop in time to clear the curb on the other side. She accidentally backed up onto the curb making those of us in the back seat jump, and sway, from the impact. My friends and I were all laughing, knowing that she was usually very careful, and had good driving skills. "Sorry everybody," she said. Her body language showing that she was having fun, but that she truly was sorry for giving us a jolt like that. Our reply was pure laughter. "Well, I guess that's our fun for the month," she said, her eyes sparkling with joy about making us laugh. She was always very quick to make jokes about situations we were put in.  She pulled forward, the back fender scraping the curb again as we drove off it. Driving away, my friends and I were still laughing , replaying what had just happened to us in our minds eye. It was one of our fondest memories together. A continual joke that we can just mention, and burst into laughter because of it. "Thanks for the ride Sarah," my friends said as we got out of the car. We walked into youth group, laughing, knowing that this would be one of the many memories that we would cherish forever, bringing us closer than ever before.

My best friend Sarah and I have known each other since we were two years old. We've helped each other through good times and bad, and are there for each other like chocolate on a bad day. Sarah's best quality is the fact that she can make me laugh no matter what mood I'm in. This year Sarah decided to go to St. Mary's, an all girls catholic school in the city, instead of continuing on to public school like me. The first day of school, I could feel that something was missing. Sarah. Without her cackling laugh ringing down the hallways, it felt oddly quiet. It reminded me of a place where we made most of our hilarious memories, and where we were told to "shush" a fair amount too. Our little brick catholic church!  Most Sundays, I stood up on the alter with the priest and helped him prepare the bread and such. And most Sundays, my best friend Sarah was in the pews. One particular Sunday I will never forget, Sarah thought it would be funny to sit in the front row with my family and make faces at me all throughout the mass. See Sarah, she has the power to make you laugh just by smiling at you. When she makes faces, I usually and up with tears in my eyes. I was standing up in front of the whole congregation and was using every ounce of self control I had not to bust out laughing. The congregation must have thought I was really being changed by the spirit because I had the biggest smile on my face.  I'm sure you've been in one of those situations where it feels like it is physically impossible to stop laughing. You have to bite you lip, think about something sad, or try breathing excercises. Every time I glanced in her direction a new wave of giggles washed over me, and every time I glanced in my mom's direction, her evil eye burned brighter. After what felt like eternity, the choir sang the closing hymn and once we left the building, I couldn't stop laughing for at least ten minutes. I had bitten my lip so hard that there were ridges indented on the inside of my mouth. Usually after church, we walk over to the parish hall for coffee and doughnuts. We catch up on school, and each others lives now that we don't see each other as often. She tells me about her new friends and I tell her about our old ones. I always look forward to hearing the hilariously stupid stories of her days, and I always inform her of the latest and greatest gossip from her hometown. But the thing that we always count on is a good laugh with a good friend.  Laughter keeps Sarah and I close. If laughter really does add years to your life, we are probably going to be the two old ladies that live on the hill with twenty cats, and nobody really knows how old they are because they've been around forever. I can be myself around her and know that she accepts me because if I do something stupid I know she'll laugh and then we'll go play with her cat, Mittens, or make popcorn and watch Harry Potter three. My family must be tired of our never-ending inside jokes. When I laugh, it feels like liquid gold is bubbling in my stomach and everything is at peace in the world. It is one of the most comforting feelings in the world. That's what I feel when I'm laughing with my best friend Sarah.

Shafts of light escape through fogged windows casting a shadowed glare upon the surface of the table. A tremendous sign hovers on a wide oak shelf that borders the entire dining area. It read's "Joe's" in great letters buried under decades of dust. My eyes dance among the plethora of mismatched antiques and statues strung throughout the room easily filling every crevice. These objects form a family of outliers, each individually unique belonging to the restaurant. Huge posters of All-American athletes tower among sixty-inch flat screens while an acrid scent of molded wood and fermented beer lingers. Numerous bras fall from the ceiling of the bar that sits next to the entrance. The sound of crunching echoes in my ears as waitresses maneuver over fallen peanut shells. That's what sets this place apart from the others. The entire floor is littered with barrels of yesterday's broken shells and mashed peanuts as it is custom for the customers to throw them on the ground. Of course there's my family; a vivacious group of five squeezing our round frames into a booth that comfortably seats four. We seem to mesh quite nicely with the crowd of miscellaneous objects dressed in our 'Sunday best' attire of skirts and dress suits.  Distracted, I busy myself in the menu browsing for something with a little zest and a lot of calories. A loud smashing noise breaks my attention and I slide the newspaper style menu below my eyes. Across the table sits my grandmother; a petite old lady standing proudly at eighty who devotes her free time in attempting stand up comedy. I study the glass jar of ketchup she's holding and watch her pound the corner on a single peanut. The shell cracks open and she picks out the nuts sweeping its kernels onto the floor. I giggle to myself surprised at what limits this old lady is willing to go to. She proceeds to repeat this process with ten more peanuts until the entire family has stopped in curiosity. Looking up, Grandma pauses with the jar suspended in her hand. "What? I'm just trying new ways of cracking open the nut." Grandma exclaims pausing for a comical response. With no reaction we resume position contemplating our meal choices. Minutes later a hefty waitress reeking of drugstore perfume and last nights hangover sets down glasses of water and drags off sluggishly. Raising his glass, Dad motions us to follow.  "Cheers!" Mom calls clinking each of our glasses in turn.  "Cheers! And cheers to cherry people!" Grandma pitches in. "Stand up comedy!" I shout automatically. Immediately my parents chuckle because my grandmother has never been funny. It's a joke that nobody in the family laughs at Grandma's comments but herself and that's how it remains. Years ago, my brother deemed her jokes the "stand up comedy" because she poses as a comedian but truly isn't. From then on, each time Grandma would crack a "joke" someone was quick to respond with yelling "Stand up comedy!" To this day, she has neither improved nor given up daily opportunities to attempt to win over her audience. In quiet defeat Grandma chuckles to herself and focuses down on the menu. Seconds later she's back in the ring for round two.  "It's noon. So are we having breakfast or lunch? Or should we have..brunch?! I'm dying here just laugh already," she pleads. For a moment we all just stare at her. Innocent eyes gaze back; the predator calmly sits awaiting the move of its prey. Then, as if a switch had been flipped, we eye each-other and the ribbon is cut. Tea party giggles erupt into hoarse cries as rolls of thunderous laughter echo through the room. I hand my mother a napkin which she uses to dab jubilant tears. The thick wooden table shutters under the pound of my father's fist slapping the surface in hysteria. I laugh so hard my gut aches and yet I cannot understand why everything is so funny. All the while she sits in pure delight, tickled by the success of finally earning a sincere response to her notorious off-the-cut "jokes." It's a wonder we aren't thrown out of the restaurant. Customers in surrounding booths peer over the edge of their bench eying us with distaste. However, this isn't the first and certainly wouldn't be the last time my family causes a scene. Plain yet obnoxious jokes is a loosely run comradery in our family that always finds its spot in our books of lasting memoirs. The remainder of the meal was spent in bursts of giggles and we were more than kindly shown out the door once our meal was finished.  Its when you break into hysterics for no monumented reason and can't get through retelling it someone else who doesn't find it nearly as humorous. It's those insignificant moments in life when we're reminded of who we are and the bonds we share. Laughter is a connection, a form of love that cultivates within society and in families with grandmothers such as mine, every "stand up comedy" is worth it.
A long time ago, my family and I went to the lake to see my great aunt and uncle. They

Laughter can be a very important thing in everyone's life because it's something that can help you in many ways. As far as I remember, laughter has helped me get through a lot of emotional problems that I would have with a lot of my ex-boyfriends. One day my mom saw me crying because my ex had broken up with me and I got really upset, so the only thing my mom said to me was that "laughter was the best medicine." At that point, I didn't understand what she was trying to say, but now that I'm getting older I start to realize what she meant by that: being bummed about something like that is just useless, and that I had to live my life to the fullest because I was too young to cry over someone who I just had a simple crush on, and she was totally right about that. But then again, it's not only for boyfriend and girlfriend things; it's also to keep a healthy friendship with your friends. Laughter is a way to show how you feel inside. Even when I don't feel like laughing, I still do because that's a way to show people that I'm a strong and independent girl who knows how to take care of herself and live her life. I also try to make the people around me laugh and just have a good time when we hang out because those moments create the best memories. I'm actually surprised at how much a simple laugh or smile can make someone feel better, and sometimes one person can make another one smile just by simply laughing at the most simplest things. On the other hand, there are people who fake laugh, meaning that they just laugh but it's not because they think you're funny; they are laughing because they think you're acting dumb. But the truth is that sometimes it's hard to see who the real people are from the fake because there are many people who fake laugh just to pretend that they like you when they really don't, and I truly think that's dumb because you end up believing that they are your friends when all they do is laugh behind your back. But I don't let that get to me because those kind of people are the kind that it's not even worth taking your time with. When I make the people that I care about smile and just have a good time, it also makes me happy because it makes me feel like I've made a difference in that certain person's day; I know I can't change their life, but I can always try to make their day a little easier by just making them laugh. My little three-month-old sister is always laughing, always cracking up for no apparent reason, and it's kinda funny to watch because when she laughs, I laugh too. That's kinda what I meant to say when I say that a simple smile or laugh from one person to another can make a difference. I mean, she's only three months and she's always happy and always has a smile on her face for no reason; sometimes without knowing, she makes my day even better when she starts laughing out of the blue, which I think is somewhat cute. My mom sometimes tries to make me laugh because she knows that I sometimes have bad days at school, and she tries her best to make me laugh because when I laugh it makes me forget about all my problems and everything. But I know that laughing can't always be all good; for example, laughing at other people's pain is just bad, and that's something that isn't funny, and people do laugh at other people which can really hurt someone. Meaning in many ways, laughing can be good or bad, but that also depends on the person who is laughing and the situation they are in.

I personally do believe that laughter is very important in any relationship. Who doesn't enjoy laughter every once in a while? I know I do. My true story is on the relationship of my two-year-old toddler daughter and I. I will tell you why I think laughter is important, how it is important, the part it plays in my relationships, and the benefits I believe it can have for any person's relationships. Everyone needs to smile and just laugh, forget about the things that make you frown, so you can turn it upside down. My relationship with my daughter has mixed emotions at all times and is constantly changing. The emotions range from complete happiness and admiration to anger, frustration, and a whole lot of stressfulness. Of course, during all of these different feelings, I always love her with every inch of my heart. But during the midst of feeling so stressed out that I want to scream, she will say the funniest thing or make the most adorable face. And you can't help but smile and laugh, which, let me tell you, makes all the difficulties go away for that brief moment. The most cold, angry, and hurtful people in the world never laugh. They isolate themselves and don't have good relationships with other people. We all need some laughter in order to not be depressed and sad. If you are always frowning and stressing out, there won't be any room to look at the good things and just laugh. When my daughter does her little thing and it makes me laugh, then she laughs and we are all in better moods. She knows that mommy still loves her, and she knows just the right ways to make me smile and I just wanna pick her up and squeeze her. Because at the end of the day, when you think about all the things that went on in your day, good or bad, there really isn't anything you can do but laugh, and that makes your whole day worth it. It doesn't have to be your children that make you laugh; it can be any relationship with anyone. Maybe it's your relationship you have with your boyfriend, and you have been together for a long time; you guys laugh, right? Because honestly, how could you stand being with a person all the time, and saying you love them and what not, yet you never laugh with them? They never make you laugh? That just wouldn't add up. No relationship can really be a good one unless there is some laughter. Especially if it's someone that you love and are with constantly. The good things in life need to exceed the bad things, so the more laughter the better. I know that parenting is super stressful, especially as a teen mom, and when she puts that smile on my face, I forget about my stresses for that moment and it makes everything better. I wanna give an example of when laughter really made a difference in my day, even my whole week. So you know when you have those days where nothing is going right, you're arguing with your parents or boyfriend or whoever, and you have just been feeling like crap all day and week. You have not laughed, smiled, or done anything fun because the past couple of days just seem to be dragging on and on with the same old routines. Then, the weekend rolls around, and I personally find a babysitter, and you go hang out with a friend or two. We all get together and start talking about old memories, both good and bad ones, ones that make you embarrassed or ones that make you want to cry. But then you get to the story that always makes you bust up laughing if it's told the right way. And you're all laughing for hours it seems, but really, it's only been fifteen minutes. Finally, you're forced to stop laughing because you were laughing so hard you started crying, and your stomach hurts like you did fifty crunches, and it hurts so bad, yet you feel so good. Then we would all just lay there, catching our breath. The only noise you hear is a little sputter of a laugh coming out of someone's mouth every thirty seconds or so. So, all-in-all, that's how I see laughter, and why I think it's important in everyone's lives. When you're sad, it will make you happy. And when you're stressed out, it makes you forget everything bad and just think about the good for a second. When you have had the worst week of your life it seems like, and then you finally get to have your weekend with the girls, and you laugh your heart out, you feel like a new person. Laughter is good for the soul, and it exercises some kind of muscle in your stomach too, I think. It doesn't really matter who you are or what the issue is; laughter will make you feel better and forget the bad things, bringing a sense of renewal and connection.

San Francisco wants to travel, and while traveling is fun, it is more exciting to go with people you love, but sometimes you go somewhere with people you may not know very well. Every two years or so, the choir at my high school has an opportunity to go on a trip together. During these trips, the students are able to work with college professors, eat tons of junk food, get away from their parents, and just have a great time together. It's an experience that every high school student dreams of. At the beginning of my sophomore year of high school, my choir director announced that we would have the opportunity to go to San Francisco. I was ecstatic to be going, but I'm an extremely introverted person and I knew that I didn't really have any friends in the choir. I also can't walk, and was scared I would be left behind in a store because I couldn't open the doors or they would go across a street corner that didn't have a curb cut down into the street, and thousands of other things that were racing through my mind. I was so terrified that I would be separated from Sarah, my one friend who was in choir, that I almost didn't go. I'm not really sure how, but my mother convinced me that everything would be alright, and I had nothing to fear. Once we arrived in San Francisco, we split up into groups to see who wanted to go to explore the piers and who wanted to go up Lombard Street, one of the windiest roads in the world. My worst nightmare came true; I was separated from Sarah. I tried to tell myself that nothing would go wrong and that the chaperons wouldn't leave me behind, but in the back of my mind I just kept coming to the same conclusion: I would be alone with a bunch of strangers in a city I knew nothing about. Somehow, I got on the bus that was slowly taking me away from her. One of the other girls, Jessica, came to sit by me and attempted to start a conversation. That was one of the longest bus rides of my life. When we arrived at the bottom of Lombard Street we split yet again; one group was going to walk to the top of the steep hill and the other was going to ride in one of the old trolleys up to the top then walk down where the hill wasn't as steep. I was forced to go on the trolley because the hill was so steep part of the sidewalk contained steps, and since I can't walk, the only alternative was the trolley. Several of the other kids went with us and once again Jessica was in my group. A couple hours later, after getting lost and turning on several wrong streets, we found the trolley station and bought our tickets. Luckily, I managed to avoid conversing with Jessica this whole time, so the ride up the hill was enjoyable. Some of the local people smiled at us because we were so excited to be riding on the trolley. We saw houses, stores, and parks on our ride. There were six people in our group at the time, two chaperons and four kids. Once we reached the top of the hill, two of the kids, Mark and Emily, decided they really had to go to the bathroom, so one of the chaperons, Mrs. Smith, and the two kids raced back down the hill to find a public restroom. This left me, alone, with Jessica and Mr. Jones, who was the remaining chaperon. We walked leisurely down the hill, Mr. Jones and Jessica doing most of the talking. Every so often they would ask me a question and I would answer in as few words as possible, and that's what was going on when we walked past a group of men, arguing, in front of a store and one of them yelled, "Hey, little lady! Whatcha doing? You goin' to your grandma's house?" We didn't really know who he was talking to or what he was talking about, so we just kept walking, but as we reached the end of the block Jessica and I simultaneously broke into laughter. The man was talking about me. The rest of the way down the hill we started coming up with different weird responses that I should have said to the man, each one being more hilarious than the last one, and as conversations go, we eventually got on different topics, which made me realize that Jessica and I really did have many similar traits. We both loved musicals, we both enjoy reading, and we both have annoying, younger brothers. Ever since that day, Jessica and I have been fairly good friends, all because we took a moment to laugh together over a strange comment from a stranger.

Laughter is a huge part of building friendships, relationships, and partnerships. On the first day of work I walked in the the daycare nervous; they sent me to the preschool classroom. I am pretty sure my boss could tell I was nervous and she made a joke that made me laugh. It made me feel welcome to be there and like we could be friends. The children in that class room made me laugh with the funny things they did. Laughter, family, and friends on an annual summer holiday. One of my favorite holiday traditions is the visit to the house of our friends, the Millers. They live on eighty forested and meadowed acres outside of a quaint, old town. Their small green house overlooks brown fields and a blue pond, with tall trees forming a backdrop. We arrive midmorning. We either find our friends in the house or encounter them tromping out of the woods to meet us, shovels, chainsaws and other trailbuilding implements in their hands. After the customary hello, how have you been, we often wander around the yard, exclaiming at the new fruit trees or hearing stories about the latest tenants of the birdhouses. During the hottest part of the afternoon, we head for the shade of the lush woods. A short walk will bring us to a trail. I love walking among the sun-streaked ferns and fallen logs, treading carefully the rickety bridges over burbling streams, bouncing confidently on the sturdy new bridges, and trying to avoid the dogs as they galumph in and out of the water. Mr. Miller knows all about the flora and fauna of the region, so we get a constant stream of knowledge as we hike. He also, of course, has to tell us about the trees he's planted -- a redwood here (look how well it's doing! A foot since last fall!) and a douglas fir over there (not as well. That big redwood is shading it too much). One of the best parts of the hike is when we see the dead-end section of trail that my family helped construct three years ago. We always walk to the end of it and discuss where it could go from there -- over the stream or beside it, or up the hill and if so, where would the switchbacks be? could you really bike up a trail like that? After our walk, we arrive back at the house, sweaty and talkative. Then it's time to put on swimsuits and jump in the pond! They recently built a dock that we can jump off of -- a great improvement over wading in from the edge. We swim for the majority of the afternoon, racing from one end of the pond to the other, splashing on innertubes, having pondweed-throwing battles. Finally we get tired and sit by the side of the pond, drying off in the warm sun. By evening, dinner is ready. Laura usually makes salmon, accompanied by a plethora of delicious side dishes. We drag chairs out to the hill above the pond and enjoy a leisurely supper. From the hill, we can see turtles and birds on the pond, bugs over the fields, and more birds swooping through the air feasting on the aforementioned bugs. After the meal, we haul chairs and dishes back to the house and sit on the porch into the night. Mr. Miller's favorite part of the day is at dusk, when the sun is at just the right angle to show all the bugs swirling through the air. At one point, all the bugs gather together and create a tornado, twisting upwards into the darkening sky, and then -- they're gone, until the next evening. It's an incredible spectacle; thousands of tiny insects disappering at one swoop. The best thing about these days is the friendship and comradery we have with this wonderful family. The parents knew each other long before us kids were born, so we have a lot to talk about; Mr. Miller is very interested in science topics, and he always finds a way to bring up the latest article he read. And, as with all great friends, we laugh constantly. I consistently get hiccups at least three times just when we're lounging on the porch after our busy day. Even on the most serious topics, my dad or the Miller boys can find a joke to make, usually "politically incorrect" but always very funny. Now don't even get me started on the summer camping trips, winter ski trips or autumn cider pressing we do with the Millers, as those are filled with just as much joy and shared laughter.

"What the heck is her problem," is what I thought as I glanced over and she gave me a nasty look. She obviously thought the new girl was weird. She really had a killer look in her eyes. I observed the way she glared at everyone in the room, and how her facial expression never changed. "Weird huh," my cousin, Sarah, asked while staring at her, who was, of course, the new girl. I glanced over at her and then back at Sarah. "Come on! You can say that! She can't hear us," she whispered. Sarah's whispers weren't exactly as quiet as she thought. The new girl could probably hear everything we were saying. I glanced over at her again, and I noticed behind those cold eyes, she seemed kinda lonely and sad. I guess that's possible, she has been the talk of the whole seventh grade class since she arrived about three days ago. "Hello! Taylor? Are you there?" Sarah was now in my face and blocking my view of the new girl. "She does look weird on the outside, but maybe she is actually a nice person," is what I said, but I knew that would not satisfy Sarah at all. "What? Definitely not. Her parents probably belong to some mafia or something. She gives off that type of aura." "You shouldn't judge someone by their looks," I responded. Sarah gave me a sort of confusing look. "I mean, you never know unless you ask." "Well if your such the expert on that why don't you go sit with her at lunch, and ask her." Oh man. There was no way I could possibly do that. I know I just said not to judge someone by their appearance, but she looks like if I even open my mouth to speak to her she will kick me in the shins. What a predicament that is. "Aren't you the one who wants to get to know her? You ask." That one won't get past Sarah either. "No? No way. We already decided you were going to ask. You can't come back with the same thing," she argued. Sarah is a very stubborn girl, and though she likes to pick on me, she really is a nice person. Also, despite her obnoxious exterior she has a lot of friends, unlike myself who is shy. "Fine," I muttered. I had to give in. No matter what I say, I am going to have to face the new girl. "That's what I thought. That's a good opportunity to make a new friend. I am just helping you out." She had a mischievous grin on her face. I glanced over at the new girl one last time, and then at the clock. It was ten in the morning, give or take a minute or two since I am nearsighted, but lunch is at noon. I couldn't pay attention at all during class. I was too busy playing out possible scenes that might occur at lunch. Maybe she isn't mean, maybe she is actually nice, and people are just misunderstanding, including me. That aside, I don't even know what to say; I can't just casually walk up, sit down in front her, look her in the eye, smile and say "Hi. How are you?" The impossible is just impossible and people should just accept that, in fact it should actually be a fundamental law. I looked over at the clock again, it was now eleven and still ticking. "One hour," Sarah said in some type of singing tone. I sighed. "What? I kept watching you during class. Looked like you were going to jump through that window and run away at any second." She laughed. My seat was by the window, and that option had not slipped my mind. "I have no clue what I am going to say," I finally said. "Just say anything that won't offend her. Ask about her hobbies or what she likes. Talk about school even," she replied. "It's time. Go." Everyone piled out of the class room and in to the cafeteria. After I got my lunch, I started walking toward the table the new girl was at; no one was around her, no surprise there. "Hello, may I sit here," I asked. My voice was kinda shaky and I thought I was about to have a heart attack from nervousness and from surprise at what I said. "By all means, go ahead," she smiled. Wow, she is really cute when she smiles. I smiled back and sat down. I created a conversation by introducing myself and asking how she was and how she liked the school. To my surprise we actually shared a common interest, and bonded. She was laughing. I was laughing. We were laughing together. After that day, and even still today we are the best of friends. That slight feeling of laughter is just so nostalgic, it's almost indescribable. Just something so minor such as laughter, or even a little giggle, can bring anybody together to form a simple bond, friendship. Laughter is truly an essential part of life, a simple yet profound connector of souls.

It is often said that laughter can bring people together. I hold that knowledge to be true. We've all laughed at one point in our lives, whether it was in a group of people, or just laughing, and having a good time. Reality is we are all connected to each other in one very simple way, we all have laughed in our lives. Laughter to everyone means something different. To me laughter can mean that I'm happy and full of life and other times it can simply mean that I feel I really don't know what to do. There's one time though that it meant both. It was a cold, and rainy Saturday day in October. I was with my friends watching movies. When I'm with my friends typically that means we're talking about the latest thing, guys, hair, and whatever else. "Oh my gosh Jessica!" We heard Emily scream as Ashley and I walked into my room. "Oh boy." I thought, "Here we go again. I new it would be a mistake to have both of them over at the same time." Ashley and I exchanged glances, I new she had the same thought going through her head. "Okay, what happened this time?" Ashley sighed as we entered the room only to see the two of them going at each other, violently tugging each others hair, slapping each other, they did everything imaginable to each other before I lost it. I hate seeing my friends mad at each other the way they were. "Okay!" I finally yell. "Here's what we're going to do. You," I pointed to Jessica, "go and sit over there." Jessica walked out of my room and sat down. "Okay, good. Why can't you two just relax and enjoy this time and act like you two are friends? For at least another six hours?" I looked at each of them, they nodded in response. "Good, now lets just finish the rest of this movie, or play a nice quiet game." I sighed, hoping the worst was over. Jessica walked back into my room, and laid on my bed, we continued through the movie peacefully. "Isn't he just a comical genius?" Emily said starring at the screen. We started laughing at her because her eyes seemed to be stuck on only him. "Oh my gosh Emily!" Jessica said laughing. "Now who's calling who crazy?" Me and Ashley both looked at each other and started nervously chuckling. The tension in the air was almost to thick. Emily had on her game face for that comment. I leaned over to Ashley and whispered, "Oh this is not going to be pretty." We started preparing for the worst. "Just grab Jessica's arm and drag her if you have to, out of this room." Ashley jumped to her feet and got Jessica out of the room, with just enough time for me to pin Emily to my bed. When they had left and the door was closed I let her up but kept myself between her and the door. "Okay, what is going on with you two?" I nervously asked her. Emily started to laugh a sort of villainous cackle that sent chills running down my spine. I couldn't help but give out a scared sounding chuckle, that

Laughter is one of the most important elements in one's life. If you're down, one smile, or laugh, causes your body to send messages throughout you body making you feel better. Scientists also say that it takes more muscles to frown than smile. I believe that this is true, because in order to frown, you have to make your whole body look like it's frowning, like your shoulders and your face, but only a little smile shows people that you're happy. In that way, my family is extremely beneficial to each other. Everyday when we're having a conversation, someone will bring up a story, or movie quote that they were reminded of and say it out loud to everybody with just the right accent so that it sounds exactly like the movie, and cause everyone to laugh. For example, every now and again, my brother or sister will bring up a quote from @PERSON1 or @PERSON2, two comedians we really enjoy listening to, and every person in the room would pitch in with hilarious quotes they said and this could go on all night. Or, a little while ago, my favorite movie wasGet @CAPS1 because it was quite entertaining, so we would have rampages over supper or just randomly in the kitchen quoting that one movie for at least half an hour and the room would be filled with non-stop laughter. On the other hand, someone will make a random comment because they heard wrong, or just don't understand. Like when we were having a dinner party at my house. My family and our guests were sitting at the table just finished eating when we got onto the topic of @CAPS2 @CAPS3 because my little sister was learning about them in school. We verbally completed the train of "Which @CAPS4 ruled @CAPS5, who they came from, and @CAPS5 they're other names were". But according to my little sister, we missed one. So, out of the blue comes "@CAPS5 about @CAPS6?!". Her intentions were about the @CAPS4, but I believe everyone in the room heard "@CAPS5 about @CAPS9 @CAPS10?!", until we paused for a second and processed @CAPS5 she meant, and we all laughed and she had no idea why until she stopped to think about it herself. Our family has good times filled with laughter and jokes, but there are also a few very depressing times. About four years ago, an incident happened with my next door neighbor that caused him to be brutally attacked and pass away on our door step. He was very dear to my family and the rest of the cul-de-sac we live in, and for him to die like that was extremely unexpected and terrible to wake up to in the middle of night. After that, there was a period of not very much laughter and fun because we were all haunted by this horror. But, we all knew that his spirit was there to protect us, and so whenever we thought of that, there was a gap between the mourning of his loss, only to be filled in with happiness and laughter. I believe that my family and I have a really tight connection between each other, because we're so funny. There's never any stress between us, but always a calm sense of familiarity and bonding. Someone once said "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." I believe that, whoever that person is, is right. Even between two strangers that run into each other on the street, if they stop and have a conversation, and one person cracks a joke causing them both to laugh, it's the spark to an immediate connection, and they could become friends for a long time. This is one of the most important values that people have, and most people overlook how much it really matters to humanity.

"@CAPS6 @CAPS5 wont! The next morning, however, was not how @PERSON2 had planned. @PERSON3 woke up alright, but did not have the expression on his face @PERSON2 intended on. But I saw the genuine fury in @LOCATION1's eyes. @CAPS5 was beyond irate. His body was crusted over with dried, white tooth paste. Quarters, dimes and penny's were drilled into his skin and the peach rings dangled moldy off his legs. @PERSON3 rushed into the bathroom to look into the mirror. @CAPS5 stormed back into the room with a shampoo bottle clenched tightly in his hand. @PERSON2 turned to face him and her confident smile instantly disintegrated. "@CAPS4 are you gonna do with that shampoo bottle?" @PERSON2 questioned, her voice now confused and a little worried. @PERSON3 grew closer to @PERSON2, and she backed away slowly, not quite sure what @CAPS4 his intentions were. They both switched positions, her back now facing the hotel room door and @PERSON3 across the room by the window. @PERSON3 raised the shampoo bottle over his head. "@CAPS9 fast," @PERSON3 shouted and chucked the bottle as hard as @CAPS5 could at @ORGANIZATION1's face. But sadly for him, @PERSON2 ducked just in time for the bottle to miss her face and create a nuclear explosion on the door behind her. Thick blue liquid spewed out all over the walls. There was a clear indent of where the bottle had hit the door. @PERSON2's whole back side was covered in blue sludge. I hopped out of bed and ran to the entrance where the explosion had taken place. @PERSON3 reached @PERSON2 and immediately burst into roaring, uncontrollable laughter. @PERSON2 sat down in a puddle of shampoo and ruptured in chuckles. I stood there, simply smiling at them both. There was @PERSON3, still crusted over with toothpaste and coins, and @PERSON2, covered in blue goop that looked like someone had thrown up a blueberry smoothie on her back. I finally sat down with them, and we all starred at each other for a moment without a word. And just like that, everything was fine. It then occurred to me that @CAPS6 matter @CAPS4 we do to each other, whether we enrage or try to explode one another, we will always find a way to laugh about it in the end. A sense of humor is merely our souls telling us everything will be okay. Its that one value in life we can truly cherish forever.

It was my thirteenth birthday, a milestone I had been eagerly anticipating. I woke up on a surprisingly sunny day which was odd for @ORGANIZATION1 because it was late @DATE1 and usually overcast. I got up with excitement buzzing through me. I ran to the kitchen where my parents were already waiting. My dad smiled and asked me if I wanted to go to work with him that day and i immediately said yes. My dad is a roofer, so i knew i couldn't go on top of the houses because i was too young. My job was to stay on the bottom and pick up the bits of trash and shingle that they would throw down. I was doing that for a while, diligently cleaning up, but then I got bored and retrieved my soccer ball from my dads truck. I started running around the yard, kicking the ball between my feet. As i was running, my eyes caught a slippery spot on the grass, probably from the morning dew. I had in mind not to go there but in my excitement, i forgot and i stepped directly on the slippery spot. My feet flew out from under me and i fell, but while i was falling, some how my flailing leg kicked the soccer ball hard. It hit the nearby wall of the house and it came rocketing back to hit me square in the face. My dad and uncles, who were working on the roof, were laughing their lungs out while i was turning red and utterly embarrassed. They were shouting down, telling me how funny it would be if it was in slow motion, replaying the ridiculous scene. i was so embarrassed i put the ball back in my dads truck and i went back to work, my cheeks still burning. The sun was coming down later, painting the sky orange, and we were finally heading home. we arrived at my house and i walk towards the house door, tired and dirty. I opened it and i hear a loud, sudden "@CAPS1!" from inside. @CAPS2, I jumped and looked around, and my eyes widened as I saw all my friends and family were there, crowded into the living room. It turned out the reason my dad took me to work was because my mom was going to throw me a surprise @CAPS1 party. i go and say hi to my family and friends, my earlier embarrassment forgotten. Just then, the lights flickered back on. My entire family and all my friends looked at me and started to laugh uproariously. In my head im thinking why are they laughing at me? I ran to my room as fast as I could, my feet slipping on the floor, and i put some clothes on. Once I was dressed, I took a deep breath and went back to the living room, where I eventually managed to shake off the shame and enjoyed the rest of my party.

Laughing is a healthy drug; it affects you and other people for the best, creating a positive feedback loop of joy. There are many times in my life where all I needed was a good, hard laugh. All I wanted was to have someone there to make me smile and bring up my dampened spirits. I have a perfect example from my own life. I had just moved again; it was my @NUM1 high school in three years. I felt totally alone; I knew nobody, and nobody was there to help me feel less alone in the crowded hallways. I wanted a friendly face to smile at me, or just to talk to me. The whole @NUM2 hours at this new school was dreadful and seemingly endless. When I was finally waiting for my mom to come get me, I was hating my new life here, convinced it would never get better. "@CAPS1 @CAPS4 one talked to me on the first day, then @CAPS4 one will talk to me at all" is what kept passing through my mind, a depressing and lonely mantra. I remembered with a pang how, everyday after school at my old home, I'd be walking home with my group of friends; we would all tease each other, or just say something stupid and meaningless. As I looked up, utterly surprised, I found my friends @PERSON5, @PERSON1 and @PERSON2 sticking their heads out my moms car window and wildly waving at me. I exclaimed, my voice full of disbelief and sudden joy. My unhappy thoughts instantly disappeared and I was smiling a real smile for the first time that day. My mom had told them how unhappy I was, and that what I needed most was a friendly face. She couldn't have been more right. After hugs, smiles, and laughs were exchanged, my friend @PERSON5 said his classic, silly line: "@CAPS2 @CAPS3 @PERSON3?" @CAPS4 one could help but laugh, even my mom broke a wide smile. When getting in the car, I forgot all about my bad day and how horrible I had felt just minutes before. I forgot about how badly I wanted my friends there to make me feel like me again. When they actually came, I couldn't have been more happier. My life felt great in that moment, and school after that was great, too. I made great friends there because my three buddies had reminded me who I was, and pushed me to be that person. They made me laugh and when I smiled at my new high school, people were more open and welcoming to me. It wasn't long after that I @PERSON4 was able to go to school with a genuine smile and laugh everyday. Friends have a great influence in your life; they remind you to smile and how great a real laugh is. Laughing is the truth between happiness, I would have to say. It was because of me smiling and laughing that I made new friends and had another great high school life. Laughing brought people to me because it made me seem like a friendly, fun person that I am. I see laughing being the ultimate cure to all unhappiness.

@PERSON1 of laughter. Once upon a time, in a not-so-distant future, there once lived a girl named @PERSON1. The year was two thousand and fourty eight and there were only a few scattered people that were alive after @

When we look back on the past, everything seems to have had a deeper meaning. When we grow older, however, we see the world with new eyes. We see the truth, harsh, stripped of the glossy film that hid it. Laughter helps us see the joy once again, to remember it is there. When is the last time you got lost in laughter? Studies have shown that laughter releases feel-good chemicals in the body. It can add years to a life because, believe it or not, our bodies like to be happy. Laughter is a highly addictive and contagious drug and the best part is that it is free, legal and healthy! Laughter makes us feel better in times of need and brings us closer together. Through whatever is happening in our lives, laughter is one of the only things that can distract us from the pain and stress. As life gets more and more complicated as we grow older, we find that laughter is harder to come by, but no less needed. I remember a time when I was excited every day to go to school. I loved to arrive at the familiar classroom and see everyone who made my days brighter. We would tell jokes and reminisce of fond memories and in the process would make brand new ones for the future. Life was simpler, the worst of our worries surrounded the desperation to be older, to shed our youth and step out of the powerless shells we were imprisoned in. Of only we knew what that really meant. Smiles were not hard to come by and we all enjoyed the simplicity that our lives had to offer. Through all the memories and laughter, I began to realize that love existed aside from movies and family, the love that you find for a friend that you treasure. Laughter was the key variable, revealed in understanding my relationships. When you learn how to fall deeply in love as a kid, that patience and trust can get you through ever day of the rest of your life. All we need to do is to is remember not to forget. The simplicity of childhood is what makes it so precious. Unfortunately as we all grown older, the future looms over our heads, casting a shadow over the things we cherish. There is a predetermined way we are supposed to live our lives that for some reason, erases the plausibility of our true aspirations. Laughter gives way to sighs and tears while dimples are forgotten and replaced with furrowed brows. Everything in adulthood orbits around the office and is held to a nine to five obligation. Businessmen walk past looking like identical mindless penguins. Where did all the fun go? It seems that the pleasure is evaporated with every passing day. We no longer get to know our colleagues around a circle of carpet squares. Instead we are confined to our felt paddock and swivel chair. All the stress makes us forget to laugh, but we simply can't forget. Laughter is the amnesia that makes the cubicle into a fort and the chair into a rocket ship that will take us from our fort to follow our dreams.  So when is the last time you got lost in laughter? Make it now. Take the pen and turn it into a quill. Step out of your cubicle and find the world that you enjoy. Laugh every day because life is too short to forget.

It all started with a book a few years ago. My mom had noticed I was struggling to find friends, so she took it upon herself to help me make some. She had a few friends from school who had kids of their own, some my age. I had been around these girls a few times as a child, but not recently. I'm not sure today what my mom saw in that particular friend that made her think we would click, but she was right. What seemed like such a small action would change my life drastically. In the spring, in my new house I first met Sarah. That evening before she arrived I couldn't help but be very upset at my mom for doing this. I felt I was fine and fully capable of making friends myself. She acted like she knew me, but the few acquaintances I had she didn't believe would be good for me. I didn't think she could be right this time and I didn't want to waste my time. An abrupt knock on the door interrupted my train of thought, I could hear her muffled voices and footsteps downstairs. Quickly I retreated to my room and onto my bed. The bulky front door opened and closed again followed by footsteps coming up to my room. When Sarah first walked into my room my first thought there was no way we would get along. She was a gorgeous blond girl, obviously popular and very confident. I couldn't stop thinking how she was going to call me freak and poke at my differences like the other girls at school did. "Hey, what are you reading?" Sarah asked as she sat on my bed. "Come look for yourself." I replied offering her the book in my hands. I knew she would hate this book. It was about all the microorganisms that live and feed off your body. I was right and as she leaned over cautiously Sarah read the book with a disgusted look on her face. Laughter was boiling up inside me, I couldn't hold it much longer. My small, dull room buzzed with my laughter. Sarah looked over at me with another strange look on her face and began to laugh along with me. Once the laughter had stopped and the ice was broken we began to talk about other interests. A few short hours flew by and we were finding plenty of things we had in common. We shared funny stories, introduced new music to one another, and talked about hobbies. I couldn't remember the last time I felt so in-tune with someone, especially someone I had just met! Suddenly our conversation was interrupted by a brisk knock on the door downstairs, we looked at each other and smiled. In that smile I saw a real person smiling at me with real pleasure showing through. Very much unlike previous encounters with kids at school. Downstairs we said our good-bye's to one another. As the new, cool evening air began to rush through the opened door I reached out to hug her. To my surprise she took my gesture and ran back to hug me. Her hair smelled of hair products and powder, a smell very unfamiliar but surprisingly comforting. Once she was gone for the night I began to think. I really liked Sarah and I wanted to see her again soon. I felt accomplished in some way and fulfilled to have this bright future opportunity brought to me so easily and perfectly. Guilt also struck me as I realized how I had felt about Sarah at first. For someone who had been judged through most of school I had been very hypocritical. That night I stayed up later than usual thinking about the next time I could see her, how she had looked and tried to understand how we could get along so well. Despite these questions haunting the edge of my every thought I slept happily, thinking of the next time I would get to see her. All of those initial questions and concerns have been answered in the years since, and we are the closest friends. Not long after we started hanging out more often, we began to like one another a lot. One of my favorite parts about our relationship is how people get so confused to see us two different so close to one another. We can take the stares, comments and anything else we struggle with today and find a way to laugh together to reduce the importance of it. I have thanked my mom over these years for many things, but mostly for what she has done for my relationship. If it hadn't of been for her my life would probably of been much darker. No one on that cold night expected this one meeting to evolve into our beautiful relationship. Laughter is an extremely vital part of a relationship whether it is being built or being kept up. Thanks to laughter excelling conversation that one evening a few years ago, I have had the best experience I could of ever asked for.

Since I was a little girl I've lived without my bio mom, she gave me up for adoption when she was only sixteen, she wasn't ready to be a mom. She has always been a risk taker and never thought about her consequences. My adoptive parents have always been truthful with me about her and why she gave me up. I accept how my life has turned out and I'm very grateful, because if I wasn't adopted I wouldn't have gotten to know my Grandma, the most loving, adventurous, funny, wise women you would ever meet. As soon as I could walk Grandma would have me out camping and hiking with her. If it was a nice sunny day no one would have any doubt were we would be. If we were at Grandma's house in the morning or afternoon we would always be out in her garden, boy how Grandma loved her gardens and flowers. No wait that's a lie, Grandma loved nature period. She has taught me how to appreciate everything around me especially nature, with me and her we are closer then anything you could think of, if she's the sky I'm her stars, if I'm a bird she's my wings. It's that simply. It hasn't always been easy for her and me, but the way we know how to cope is to laugh at everything and everyone, not in a bully or make fun of kind a way, but a good way. Laughing for me and my Grandma comes like a second nature to us, it's what keeps us going and know that everything will be okay. A few months ago my favorite cousin Jake had passed away, Grandma and I had barley seen each other in a while or had talked, but then everything happened so fast with his passing. That when we saw each other it was at his funeral. My Sizemore family was all there, even though Jake was gone he had a presence that was still there. That night after the funeral everyone went to my aunties house and just spent time together. Finally Grandma and I got the chance to talk, yes we were both teary eyed but we were laughing too. We were laughing at all the funny times we had with Jake and all the crazy things he did. One time he had went to go get my uncle from the airport and he was waiting there in his Elvis costume holding a Sizemore sign. Boy was Jake a goof. Grandma was just telling me all these things, and it was then that I realized Grandma had taught me something else to appreciate. Grandma had taught me how to appreciate laughter at a time of sorrow. To rejoice in a time of death, to have hope when you felt like you had none left. I learned that even though people might not think so, laughter is the key medicine to everyone's pain. People don't think of laughter as a cure they think of it as something you do after you hear a joke. Laughter is so much more then people give it credit for. My Grandma taught me all those things, plus the real meaning of laughter, and that will always be with me.

Laughing is one of the things we do best. Chloe and I talk almost everyday and never get tired of laughing. We talk about everything and even if it is the saddest thing in the world we will be able to make it funny in a way, it's just one of those things we do. As best friends it's our job to make each other feel better, and if one calls the other crying it's their job to make the them laugh and if it is funny for both then you know it was a job well done. In the winter, my uncle died, I called her crying my eyes out, she said, everything was going to be okay and to just think of all the good memories I had of him. One of the only ones I could think of was the funniest story of my life and even though I was still crying, through those tears there was laughter and I knew my uncle would want me to laugh and he was right there laughing with me. Chloe and I met last year, at summer camp, where we spent a week out of our summer to get to know new people and getting closer to God. That week was one of the funniest weeks out of my whole life, though me and Chloe didn't "click" at camp that week, we later found out we were more alike then we thought. Some people say when two people are to much alike the friendship doesn't work. Well, this is true yet false. When you are alike you can talk to each other about everything, yet when you hit those differences, and the other disagrees it starts a fight, but fights just bring people closer together. Even though me and Chloe don't see each other much, doesn't mean we can't be best friends. What if your best friend lived in a different state, does that mean they aren't your best friend anymore? No, it just means you don't see them as much as you would like to. Even though we live close to each other we don't always have time to see one another, but, when we do finally get to see each other there isn't a dull moment. About a month after Chloe had gotten in a bad car accident, we went to Skate World, Chloe was on crutches so she couldn't skate, but that didn't stop her from having fun and making the night full of laughter. She was up dancing to the music, on top of seats yelling, "You wont ever see these people again in your life, why not just have a little fun? ". By the end of the night she got almost everyone in our group dancing up on the stools and I don't regret one thing that happened that night, it was the most I had laughed in about a year. We were dancing and screaming for about three hours, before one the parents got their and after that we all went home. That is a night I will never forget. A girl that was recovering from a horrible car accident made the best out of what she had! When things don't work out the way we wanted, we just go on with life wishing that it had happen differently, but when we look back a couple years down the road we will see that it was just fine, and it might just make you laugh. Some things are hard to laugh about, but a good thing to do when you get to that point is think of something happy, or funny and try to laugh. Laughing has always made me feel better, and knowing that I can make someone with a difficult life laugh until they are about to pee makes me feel good. It makes me feel like I have done something good with my life that I was willing to help Chloe with her struggles. To me that makes this life, a life worth living. Though you cant help everyone through every single one of their struggles, just being there sometimes helps them more then you might know. Chloe and I have planed out many lives we would like to live and looking back now on them all I can do is laugh, because in my heart I know they will never happen. Even if we try our best to make them happen I doubt they will. But, it was worth the laughter and a good time to make them up, and believe they were going to happen for awhile and I know looking back in a few years we will both laugh. Laughing is a good way to get rid of fear, anger, and stress. It makes you think of all the good times you have had in your life, and lets you know that you had fun in your life. Though we fight, in the end, I don't think anyone will be able to tear Chloe and I apart, with all the laughter that is done. We are true friends.

Laughter. Something everyone does. Its natural, organic, normal. They say children laugh more than adults, maybe that's what keeps them children. They can still let that deep instinct to enjoy themselves be expressed in bursts of happy noise. Laughter is always unique to every person. Some have musical laughs, others have deep belly laughs. Then there are those who snort or snicker, the kind of laugh that makes you laugh because you hear it. Those are my favorite. Someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people" and I couldn't agree more. Laughing with people has been the greatest influence in my relationships with my friends. I have five girlfriends that I would not be able to live without. They support me, love me, and get me to be bold and get out of my comfort zone. There have been many sleepovers where at two in the morning all you can here is the laughter of all of us at some shocking late night confession or horror at the "would you rather?" someone just came up with. One night in particular was especially funny. It was last summer and we were sleeping on my friend's porch. It was a spectacular night, the stars were out the air was cool but comfortable and a meteor shower was happening later on that evening. Emma started the conversation with her favorite catch phrase, "Hey guys, hows life?" We all laughed because if you are around Emma for more than and hour you will here this saying a few times. "Same as five minutes ago," I replied. "Well guys my life has completely changed," said Mia sarcastically. "Oh really?" Lily asked, her little body curled up in her sleeping bag, "Did you have a personality flip, are you now blond and stupid?" "Sure." Mia said sarcastically, rolling her eyes, a very common gesture. We laughed at the ridiculous mental picture of "the brain" being stupid. "You guys want to play would you rather?" Sophie piped in. I had thought she was asleep by now. All I could see was her red hair covering her face

The last two boy's showed up and their names are @PERSON2 and @PERSON3 and @PERSON1 is showing up tomorrow after noon. @PERSON6 was so exited that he was turning @NUM1 years old , he said " I'm @NUM1 years old now no one can tell me what to do" and I laughed and said "@PERSON6 go make me a sandwich" and he said "@CAPS3" and I said "so much for no one can tell me what to do" and everyone laughed at him. He gave me my sandwich and all the boy's went to the apartment to clean @CAPS7 but when I got in there they set up @PERSON5's x-box @NUM3 and was playing @CAPS7. They finally cleaned the apartment and got the x-bow back. @TIME1 all of us were watching movies and playing broad games then mom told @PERSON4 and I to clean my room , maybe a hour after that she walked by and said " bed time" and boy's go to the apartment. The next mourning.  The next mourning @PERSON4 and I woke up to the sun hitting us in the eyes and I said "what a great way to start off the day" and @PERSON4 said "I know". The best part of today is that we get to hang out with the boy's. When @PERSON4 and I got into the living room everybody was in the kitchen and partly in the living room. @TIME1 that @TIME1 the boy's thought @CAPS7 would be fun if they played cops and rubbers. The apartment was the jail. @PERSON2 , @CAPS2 , @PERSON6 were the cops and @PERSON5 and @CAPS1 were the rubbers. @PERSON4 and I wanted to play so we went outside and ran into @PERSON5 on the otter side of the apartment , he was the only one who knew we were outside.
